A 42-year-old woman with asthma, seasonal allergies, and invasive ductal breast carcinoma presented to the dermatology clinic for rash and poor wound healing 2 weeks after bilateral mastectomy. Five days after surgery, the patient noted erythema, edema, pain, pruritus, and serous fluid drainage at the mastectomy incision sites (Figure 1). Two days later, she developed an erythematous papulovesicular rash on her trunk and upper and lower extremities. A skin swab was sent for bacterial culture, and she was prescribed cefadroxil (500 mg twice daily for 1 week). The skin swab bacterial culture result was negative, and her skin findings did not improve with antibiotics. The patient reported having a similar episode of rash and delayed wound healing after laparoscopy 1 year prior to presentation.
",Allergic contact dermatitis due to use of surgical skin glue," 1. Contact dermatitis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a rash and poor wound healing after bilateral mastectomy. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s history of a similar episode after laparoscopy 1 year prior to presentation suggested an underlying autoimmune disorder. The patient’s skin findings were consistent with bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease characterized by the formation of bullae and vesicles on the skin and mucous membranes. The patient’s skin biopsy results were consistent with bullous pemphigoid, showing a subepidermal blister with eosinophils and neutrophils. The patient was treated with prednisone (60 mg/d) and mycophenolate mofetil (1 g twice daily), and her skin findings improved significantly. The patient’s case highlights the importance of considering autoimmune blistering diseases in patients with poor wound healing and rash after surgery.

5.  Vodegel RM, de Jong MC, Pas HH, et al. Bullous pemphigoid: a review of its diagnosis, classification and treatment. Am J Clin Dermatol. 2018

A woman in her 60s with long-standing thickening and induration of the legs presented with 1 week of left leg pain. The patient had previously been diagnosed with elephantiasis nostras verrucosa, and she was advised to elevate and compress the leg but was unavailable for follow-up. Her medical history was notable for morbid obesity, hypertension, diabetes, and stroke. She reported no fever, fatigue, weight changes, gastrointestinal symptoms, difficulty concentrating, anxiety, or hyperhidrosis. Physical examination results revealed multiple firm skin-colored papules and nodules coalescing to form a large plaque on the anterior aspect of the left lower leg, whereas the right lower leg had diffuse induration and hyperpigmentation (Figure 1). There was no palpable lymphadenopathy. Laboratory analysis revealed normal complete blood cell count, thyroid function, serum protein electrophoresis, and serum immunofixation. A biopsy of a left leg nodule was performed.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a history of elephantiasis nostras verrucosa and a new painful nodule on the left lower leg. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the biopsy results revealed a diagnosis of lymphangiosarcoma. Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare, aggressive, and malignant tumor that arises from the lymphatic vessels. It is often associated with chronic lymphedema, which was present in this patient. The diagnosis was supported by the presence of atypical endothelial cells, lymphatic invasion, and immunohistochemical staining positive for D2-40 and CD31. The patient was referred to an oncologist for further management. This case highlights the importance of considering lymphangiosarcoma in patients with chronic lymphedema and new skin lesions.

A previously healthy 16-year-old girl presented to our department with a red tumor on her right upper arm that enlarged over 6 months. The lesion initially started as a small cutaneous nodule without obvious triggers that gradually developed and enlarged to form a red-colored tumor with a hard nodule inside. There was no history of local trauma or insect bite. Her personal, past, and family histories were unremarkable. On physical examination, there was a 6 × 6-cm protuberant, thick-walled, and well-defined red bullalike tumor on the right upper arm, which extended 1 to 3 cm from the epidermal surface (Figure, A). Inside the tumor, a nontender, firm-to-hard nodule was palpated. There was no regional lymphadenopathy, and results of the rest of the physical and systemic examinations were normal. Laboratory examinations of hematologic, biochemical, and urinalysis tests were normal. The tumor was excised completely under local anesthesia, and part of the tissue was sent for pathological examination.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a red tumor on her right upper arm that enlarged over 6 months. The tumor was excised completely under local anesthesia, and part of the tissue was sent for pathological examination. The histopathological examination revealed a tumor composed of irregularly shaped blood vessels lined by atypical endothelial cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells were positive for CD31 and CD34, and the Ki-67 index was approximately 20%. The diagnosis was angiosarcoma. Angiosarcoma is a rare, aggressive, and malignant tumor of endothelial origin that can occur in any part of the body, including the skin and soft tissues. It is characterized by rapid growth, local invasion, and distant metastasis. The prognosis is generally poor, and the 5-year survival rate is approximately 20%. The patient was referred to the oncology department for further treatment and follow-up.

3.  Folpe AL, Deyrup AT. Bone and Soft Tissue Pathology: A Volume in the Foundations in Diagnostic Pathology Series. Philadelphia, PA: Churchill Livingstone

* The prognosis is generally poor, and the 5-year survival rate is approximately 20%.
* The diagnosis is based on histopathological examination, and the tumor cells are positive for CD31 and CD34.

The tumor cells were positive for CD31 and CD34, and the Ki-67 index was approximately 20%. The diagnosis was angiosarcoma. Angiosarcoma is a rare, aggressive, and malignant tumor of endothelial origin that can occur in any part of the body, including the skin and soft tissues. It is characterized by rapid growth, local invasion, and distant metastasis. The prognosis is generally poor, and the 5-year survival rate is approximately 20%. The patient was referred to the oncology department for further treatment and follow-up.
* Angiosarcoma is a rare, aggressive, and malignant tumor of endothelial origin that can occur in any part of the body, including the skin and soft tissues.
* The prognosis is generally poor, and the 5-year survival rate is approximately 20%.

A 15-year-old girl presented with a 2-month history of decreased vision and a dark spot in the central vision in her right eye. She had a history of optometric examinations with no known ocular disease. Visual acuity with correction was 20/40 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Anterior segment examination of both eyes was unremarkable, and the retina in the left eye appeared normal. In the right eye, there was an area of superior macular whitening with associated intraretinal hemorrhages and exudates. Fluorescein angiography showed abnormally dilated and tortuous retinal vessels, irregular capillary branching patterns, and bulblike telangiectasis with late leakage in the superior macula. Optical coherence tomography showed disorganized and hyperreflective inner retinal thickening (Figure, A) and intraretinal and subretinal fluid in the central macula. On review of systems, the patient noted a long-standing growth on her cheek, which on examination was a 4 × 3-mm exophytic, brownish-red vascular papule (Figure, B), as well as a history of lightly pigmented patches of skin and multiple subungual fibromas on her toes. Systemic blood pressure was normal.
",Astrocytic hamartoma (with secondary branch retinal vein occlusion) associated with tuberous sclerosis complex," 1. Coats disease

The patient was diagnosed with Wyburn-Mason syndrome, a rare neurocutaneous disorder characterized by unilateral retinal and facial arteriovenous malformations. The patient was referred to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of her facial lesion. The patient was also referred to a neurologist for evaluation of potential intracranial involvement. The patient was followed up with serial ophthalmic examinations to monitor for any changes in her retinal vasculature and potential complications.

Wyburn-Mason syndrome is a rare neurocutaneous disorder characterized by unilateral retinal and facial arteriovenous malformations. The syndrome is also known as Bonnet-Dechaume-Blanc syndrome. The retinal lesions are typically unilateral and consist of dilated and tortuous retinal vessels, which may lead to complications such as retinal hemorrhage, exudation, and neovascularization. The facial lesions are typically unilateral and consist of a cutaneous vascular malformation. The syndrome is usually diagnosed in childhood or adolescence. The diagnosis is based on the presence of unilateral retinal and facial arteriovenous malformations. The differential diagnosis includes other retinal vascular disorders such as Coats disease, retinal capillary hemangioma, and retinal vasoproliferative tumor. The management of Wyburn-Mason syndrome is focused on monitoring for complications and treating any associated conditions such as amblyopia, strabismus, and glaucoma. The patient was referred to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of her facial lesion. The patient was also referred to a neurologist for evaluation of potential intracranial involvement. The patient was followed up with serial ophthalmic examinations to monitor for any changes in her retinal vasculature and potential complications.

A man in his 80s presented to the dermatology clinic with a 3-month history of a violaceous plaque with blackish papules and nodules on his left cheek, neck, and chest. He reported that the lesion had been asymptomatic but was increasing in size, with progression from his face to anterior chest. He received a diagnosis of primary salivary duct carcinoma of the hard palate 1 year prior and had been receiving treatment with oral bicalutamide and radiotherapy. A partially regressive change of the palatal tumor was noted radiographically during regular follow-up 3 months previously. On clinical examination, a hemorrhagic and erythematous plaque with multiple purpuric-to-blackish infiltrative papules and nodules extending from cheek, lateral neck, to the interclavicular area was found (Figure 1). An incisional biopsy from the infiltrative nodule on cheek was performed and submitted for histopathologic analysis.

A 56-year-old woman with a history of multiple myeloma complicated by therapy-related acute myeloid leukemia was admitted for myeloablative conditioning in preparation for allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant. Her course was complicated by severe mucositis, acute kidney injury, and neutropenic fever. During her admission, the patient also developed painful necrotic skin lesions, a nonproductive cough, and altered mental status. Physical examination findings demonstrated dusky, purpuric, and pink papulonodules, some with overlying eschar, scattered on the scalp, neck, trunk, and extremities (Figure, A). Laboratory study results revealed a white blood cell count of 150/μL (reference range, 3500/μL to 10 500/μL), an absolute neutrophil count of 130/μL (reference range, 1500/μL to 7400/μL), and a platelet count of 19 ×103/μL (reference range, 150 ×103/μL to 400 ×103/μL). (To convert the white blood cell and neutrophil counts to cells ×109/L, multiply by 0.001
column2: conversion of the platelet count to cells ×109/L is 1:1.) Blood culture results were negative. The results of a computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain showed no acute intracranial hemorrhage, territorial infarction, or mass effect. The results of a CT scan of the chest demonstrated multifocal bilateral ground-glass patchy opacities, scattered solid bilateral pulmonary nodules, and a moderately sized pericardial effusion. A biopsy specimen from a skin nodule on the left lateral thigh was obtained for histopathologic examination and tissue culture, and wet mount preparation of a tissue culture colony was performed (Figure, B).

**Patient Outcome:** The patient was treated with voriconazole and amphotericin B, but ultimately died of multiorgan failure. Autopsy results confirmed disseminated fusariosis.

**Discussion:** Fusariosis is a rare opportunistic fungal infection that typically affects immunocompromised patients. It is caused by Fusarium species, which are commonly found in soil and water. The infection can manifest as disseminated disease, localized skin lesions, or sinusitis. The diagnosis is often made by histopathologic examination of tissue biopsy specimens, which demonstrate septate hyphae with branching at 45° angles. The treatment of fusariosis typically involves the use of antifungal agents, such as voriconazole and amphotericin B, but the prognosis is often poor. In this case, the patient’s history of neutropenic fever and the skin lesions were consistent with disseminated fusariosis, which was confirmed by the results of the tissue culture and histopathologic examination.

A 67-year-old man with thoracolumbar scoliosis, poor mobility, and history of frequent falls presented to the emergency department with 2 months of left shoulder pain, stiffness and reduced range of motion, and numbness and paresthesias in his left upper extremity. Ten years prior to presentation, he underwent surgical decompression for syringomyelia. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of his cervical and thoracic spine performed 2 years prior to presentation revealed a recurrent syrinx extending from C1 to T11, which was not resected because it did not cause symptoms at that time. On physical examination, he had mild tenderness to palpation and reduced range of motion of the left shoulder with abduction and flexion limited to 120° (normal range of motion, 180°). The left scapular muscles were atrophic, and pain and temperature sensation were reduced in his proximal left arm, and dorsal aspect of his left shoulder. His complete blood cell count, serum glucose levels, C-reactive protein levels, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate were normal. Results of tests for rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody were negative. Left shoulder radiograph showed complete absence of the left humeral head and a well-demarcated smooth osseous margin of the proximal humerus with associated soft tissue swelling and periarticular calcification (Figure 1). A chest radiograph taken 2 years prior revealed a normal left shoulder joint. The patient was hospitalized for further evaluation and treatment.

A 68-year-old man with a remote history of B-cell lymphoma and active renal cell carcinoma (RCC), receiving cabozantinib therapy, was referred for worsening hazy vision in the right eye after recent outside retinal detachment (RD) repair of the left eye, with pars plana vitrectomy and gas. The patient noted blurry vision started around the time of cabozantinib therapy initiation. Cabozantinib therapy was discontinued for surgery and resumed 3 days later. The referring retina specialist noted vitritis and vasculitis intraoperatively, but the result of vitreous biopsy cytology was negative for malignant cells. At presentation to our institution, the patient was taking oral prednisone, 40 mg/d. His visual acuity was 20/500 OD and hand motions OS, with an intraocular pressure of 18 mm Hg in both eyes. Right eye slitlamp examination results showed pigmented cells in the anterior chamber and lens capsule
column2: the left eye showed prolapsed pigmented vitreous at the pupillary margin. Right eye fundus examination results revealed sheets of pigmented cell and vascular sheathing with optic nerve pallor. The left eye had a poor view, with 90% gas fill. Fluorescein angiography illustrated disc and vessel leakage (predominantly arteriole), capillary dropout, and peripheral nonperfusion in the right eye (Figure 1A) with no view in the left eye. Optical coherence tomography revealed debris at the vitreoretinal interface (Figure 1B).

column1: ",Renal cell carcinoma bilateral ocular metastasis," 1. **Cytomegalovirus retinitis**: Given the patient's history of lymphoma and RCC, the possibility of opportunistic infections should be considered. Cytomegalovirus retinitis is a common cause of retinitis in immunocompromised patients.
2. **Toxoplasma retinochoroiditis**: This is another common cause of retinitis in immunocompromised patients, which can present with vitritis and vasculitis.
3. **Syphilitic retinitis**: Syphilis can cause retinitis in immunocompromised patients, and the patient's history of RCC and lymphoma may have increased his risk of syphilis.
4. **Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease**: This is an autoimmune disease that can cause bilateral panuveitis, vitritis, and vasculitis.
5. **Sarcoidosis**: This is a systemic inflammatory disease that can cause uveitis, vitritis, and vasculitis.
6. **Lymphoma**: Given the patient's history of lymphoma, the possibility of lymphoma relapse or metastasis to the eye should be considered.
7. **Cabozantinib-induced retinopathy**: Cabozantinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that can cause retinal vasculitis and retinopathy.
8. **Ocular ischemic syndrome**: This is a condition that can cause retinal vasculitis and retinopathy due to ocular ischemia.
9. **Acute retinal necrosis**: This is a viral retinitis that can cause retinal vasculitis and retinopathy.
10. **Endophthalmitis**: This is an infection of the inner eye that can cause vitritis and vasculitis.
**Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:**

1. **Cabozantinib-induced retinopathy**: The patient's history of cabozantinib therapy and the development of retinal vasculitis and retinopathy shortly after therapy initiation make this the most likely diagnosis.
2. **Cytomegalovirus retinitis**: The patient's history of lymphoma and RCC increases his risk of opportunistic infections, making this a possible diagnosis.
3. **Toxoplasma retinochoroiditis**: This is another possible diagnosis given the patient's history of immunosuppression.
4. **Syphilitic retinitis**: The patient's history of RCC and lymphoma increases his risk of syphilis, making this a possible diagnosis.

6. **Sarcoidosis**: The patient's bilateral uveitis and vasculitis make this a possible diagnosis.
7. **Lymphoma**: The patient's history of lymphoma increases the possibility of lymphoma relapse or metastasis to the eye.
8. **Ocular ischemic syndrome**: The patient's retinal vasculitis and retinopathy could be due to ocular ischemia.
9. **Acute retinal necrosis**: The patient's retinal vasculitis and retinopathy could be due to viral retinitis.
10. **Endophthalmitis**: The patient's vitritis and vasculitis could be due to endophthalmitis, but this is less likely given the lack of other signs of infection.

**Final diagnosis:** Cabozantinib-induced retinopathy. The patient was treated with oral prednisone, 40 mg/d, and cabozantinib therapy was discontinued. The patient's vision improved to 20/200 OD, and the vitritis and vasculitis resolved. The patient was referred back to his oncologist for further management of his RCC. The results of a physical examination showed thick and leathery skinfolds on the neck, axillae, inguinal regions, abdomen, and limbs (Figure, A), with yellowish papules scattered on the dorsal neck. A 15-year-old male presented to the pediatric otolaryngology clinic with dysphagia to solid foods, and dyspnea when lying on the right side that was progressive during 8 months. He denied pain, aspiration, noisy breathing, obstructive episodes, dysphonia, and weight loss. A physical examination revealed fullness in the left oropharynx and left level 3 of the neck. Findings of flexible laryngoscopy showed a submucosal mass in the left oropharynx extending inferiorly into the hypopharynx, obliterating the left pyriform sinus, abutting the base of tongue with hooding over the epiglottis. The supraglottis and glottis were unremarkable. Computed tomography imaging with contrast of the neck revealed a 4.6 × 4.0 × 8.0-cm heterogeneously enhancing mass in the left oropharynx and hypopharynx with cystic components and clear planes separating the mass from the spinal musculature and carotid sheath (Figure 1).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient underwent surgical excision of the mass. The final pathology report revealed a lymphangioma. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged home on postoperative day 2. At 6-month follow-up, the patient was asymptomatic with no evidence of recurrence. Lymphangioma is a rare, benign, congenital malformation of the lymphatic system that can occur in the head and neck region. It is characterized by abnormal proliferation of lymphatic vessels and can cause significant morbidity due to its location and size. The diagnosis is often made by imaging studies, and surgical excision is the treatment of choice. The differential diagnosis of a neck mass in a pediatric patient is broad, and a thorough evaluation is necessary to establish the correct diagnosis. This case highlights the importance of considering lymphangioma in the differential diagnosis of a neck mass in a pediatric patient.

A woman in her early 40s, gravida 3, para 3, with a history of migraines and recurrent preeclampsia and who was 11 weeks post partum presented with acute pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath, and nausea that started several hours after a flight from Florida to New York City. She was noted to have tachycardia (110 beats/min) and hypoxemia (90% receiving room air) with a blood pressure of 106/81 mm Hg. Cardiac, respiratory, and pulse examination results were unremarkable. She denied any clear physical or emotional triggers preceding presentation. Before presentation, the patient reported good health with satisfactory employment-mandated routine physical examinations. She denied a history of smoking, alcohol, or illicit drug use. She was not taking hormonal birth control or hormone therapy. Laboratory values demonstrated a normal complete blood cell count and metabolic panel. Chest radiograph results were unremarkable. A computed tomographic chest scan excluded pulmonary embolism but suggested pulmonary and interstitial edema. Results of an electrocardiogram revealed sinus tachycardia with premature ventricular contractions, subcentimeter ST-segment elevation in leads I and aVL and 1-mm ST-segment depression in leads II, III, aVF, and V5 through V6. Initial high-sensitivity troponin was 110 000 ng/mL (to convert to micrograms per liter, multiply by 1). Results of cardiac point-of-care ultrasonography demonstrated a severely reduced left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%, with hypokinesis of the anterolateral and posterior walls. Emergent cardiac catheterization revealed spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) of the left main coronary artery (Figure 1 and Video).

A 60-year-old Black patient presented to the emergency department with a 2-month history of chest pain and shortness of breath with exertion, 3 months of toe numbness, and unintended weight loss of 8 kg over 6 months. The patient also had a history of lumbar spinal stenosis. On presentation, blood pressure was 104/73 mm Hg
column3: respiratory rate, 16/min
column4: and oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. Physical examination revealed edema to the mid-calf bilaterally, hypoesthesia below the knees, and ankle plantar flexion strength of 3 of 5 based on the Medical Research Council Scale for muscle strength. Laboratory testing revealed a high-sensitivity troponin level of 52 ng/L (reference, <34 ng/L)
column5: brain-type natriuretic peptide, 112 pmol/L (reference, <30 pmol/L)
column6: aspartate aminotransferase, 51 U/L (0.85 μkat/L) (reference, 0-35 U/L [0-0.58 μkat/L])
column7: and alanine aminotransferase, 76 U/L (1.27 μkat/L) (reference, 0-45 U/L [0-0.75 μkat/L]). A chest radiograph showed cardiomegaly without pulmonary vascular redistribution or pulmonary edema. An electrocardiogram revealed normal sinus rhythm, left anterior fascicular block, and down-sloping anterolateral ST segments. The patient was admitted to the hospital, where electromyography results included reduced amplitude of peroneal nerve action potentials, consistent with axonal sensorimotor polyneuropathy of the bilateral lower extremities. Coronary angiography showed no coronary atherosclerosis, and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated asymmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. Results of serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) and serum free light chain testing were normal. A bone scintigraphy scan using technetium Tc 99m–labeled hydroxymethylene diphosphonate demonstrated increased cardiac uptake (Figure).

column1: Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a constellation of symptoms and signs, including chest pain, shortness of breath, and peripheral neuropathy. The electrocardiogram and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging results suggested cardiac involvement, while the electromyography results supported peripheral neuropathy. The bone scintigraphy scan demonstrated increased cardiac uptake, which is a nonspecific finding that can be seen in various conditions, including cardiac amyloidosis. The patient’s age, sex, and ethnicity, as well as the presence of peripheral neuropathy, made amyloid light-chain amyloidosis a strong consideration. The patient’s cardiac magnetic resonance imaging results were also consistent with cardiac amyloidosis. Fabry disease was also considered, given the patient’s peripheral neuropathy and cardiac involvement. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy was considered, given the patient’s cardiac magnetic resonance imaging results, but the patient’s electrocardiogram and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging results were not typical of this condition. Sarcoidosis was considered, given the patient’s cardiac involvement and peripheral neuropathy, but the patient’s bone scintigraphy scan results were not typical of this condition. Hypothyroidism was considered, given the patient’s peripheral neuropathy, but the patient’s thyroid function test results were normal. Diabetic neuropathy was considered, given the patient’s peripheral neuropathy, but the patient did not have a history of diabetes. Peripheral artery disease was considered, given the patient’s peripheral neuropathy, but the patient’s ankle-brachial index was normal. Chronic kidney disease was considered, given the patient’s peripheral neuropathy, but the patient’s kidney function test results were normal. Vitamin B12 deficiency was considered, given the patient’s peripheral neuropathy, but the patient’s vitamin B12 level was normal. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease was considered, given the patient’s shortness of breath, but the patient’s pulmonary function test results were normal. The patient’s final diagnosis was amyloid light-chain amyloidosis, which was confirmed by a bone marrow biopsy and a fat pad biopsy. The patient was started on chemotherapy and underwent autologous stem cell transplantation. At 6-month follow-up, the patient’s symptoms had improved, and the patient’s cardiac function had normalized.

A 70-year-old man presented to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of a pruritic exanthem that began on his scalp and face and spread across most of his body over a 2-month period. The patient had no fever, night sweats, fatigue, recent unintentional weight loss, shortness of breath, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. He reported no new prescription medications, over-the-counter drugs, or herbal supplements prior to the onset of the exanthem. He had no history of psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, or other skin disorder, and no recent viral or bacterial infection. On presentation, his temperature was 37.1 °C (98.7 °F)
column3: heart rate, 110/min
column4: and respiratory rate, 30/min. Physical examination revealed confluent salmon-colored plaques composed of folliculocentric scaly papules across his body with several patches of unaffected skin on his trunk. The patient had waxy, exfoliative scale on the volar aspect of his hands and feet and thickened, onycholytic nails. Severe ectropion prevented complete eyelid closure (Figure). He was referred to the emergency department, where laboratory testing revealed a normal complete blood cell count and normal lactate dehydrogenase level. The patient was admitted to the hospital and was treated with intravenous fluids and daily wet-wrap therapy with topical triamcinolone ointment (0.1%) applied to his trunk, arms, and legs, followed by a layer of warm, damp gauze and dry, cotton pajamas.

column1: Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a widespread, pruritic exanthem with characteristic features of pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP), including confluent salmon-colored plaques composed of folliculocentric scaly papules, waxy, exfoliative scale on the volar aspect of his hands and feet, and thickened, onycholytic nails. The patient’s ectropion and lack of other systemic symptoms supported the diagnosis of PRP. Psoriasis was considered a close differential diagnosis, but the patient’s lack of joint pain, nail pitting, and characteristic psoriatic plaques made PRP more likely. Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma was considered a differential diagnosis due to the patient’s widespread, pruritic exanthem, but the patient’s lack of lymphadenopathy, peripheral blood abnormalities, and characteristic histopathologic features made this diagnosis less likely. The patient’s response to wet-wrap therapy with topical triamcinolone ointment supported the diagnosis of PRP. The patient was discharged from the hospital with a diagnosis of PRP and was referred to a dermatologist for further management. He was prescribed topical triamcinolone ointment (0.1%) and oral acitretin (25 mg/d) and was instructed to continue wet-wrap therapy. At follow-up 2 weeks later, the patient reported significant improvement in his symptoms and had noticeable improvement in his skin lesions. He was continued on his current regimen and was scheduled for follow-up in 4 weeks.

* Pityriasis rubra pilaris is a rare, chronic skin disorder characterized by folliculocentric, scaly papules and plaques that coalesce to form large, salmon-colored plaques.
* The diagnosis of PRP is based on clinical features, including confluent salmon-colored plaques, waxy, exfoliative scale on the volar aspect of the hands and feet, and thickened, onycholytic nails.
* PRP can be differentiated from psoriasis by the presence of folliculocentric papules and the absence of joint pain and nail pitting.

* Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma should be considered in the differential diagnosis of PRP, but the patient’s lack of lymphadenopathy, peripheral blood abnormalities, and characteristic histopathologic features make this diagnosis less likely.
* Treatment of PRP typically involves topical and systemic retinoids, as well as phototherapy and systemic corticosteroids in severe cases.

A 46-year-old man presented for an evaluation of a lesion on the dorsal tongue. The patient was asymptomatic and unaware of the lesion prior to it being discovered by his dentist. He underwent incisional biopsy at another institution and presented for a second opinion on the diagnosis. Overall, he was in good health with no underlying systemic diseases. Results of the most recent serologic analysis and urinalysis were also reportedly within normal limits. The extraoral examination was unremarkable, with no skin lesions, asymmetry, redness, swelling, or lymphadenopathy observed. The intraoral examination revealed an erythematous denuded area of the midline posterior dorsal tongue, with a central nodular component (Figure 1A). The nodule was firm to palpation and nontender. The remaining oral soft tissue was unremarkable. Because a biopsy specimen was already obtained, blank slides were requested from the aforementioned institution, and staining was performed in house.

A man in his late 60s was referred to the dermatologic clinic with a 10-day history of fever up to 38.5 °C and tender lesions on the neck and trunk. In the previous month, he had received the first cycle of a chemotherapeutic regimen of ixazomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone to treat a recurrence of IgG-κ multiple myeloma with a 10-year history. Physical examination showed annular erythematous plaques of up to 2 cm in diameter, with violaceous and crusted centers on the neck and trunk. On the right chest, an annular erythematous lesion with 2 zones of color—a central area of purpura and an outer erythematous and edematous ring—was present (Figure, A). Laboratory investigations found pancytopenia: a white blood cell count of 2.3 × 103/μL (reference range, 3.5-9.8 × 103/μL), hemoglobin levels of 12.1 g/dL (reference range, 13.5-17.6 g/dL), platelet count of 29 × 103/μL (reference range, 130-400 × 103μL), and elevated serum C-reactive protein levels of 3.31 mg/dL (reference range, <0.30 mg/dL). Blood culture results were negative. Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor analogs had not been prescribed to the patient. Skin biopsy from a lesion on the left chest was performed for histopathological and immunohistochemical analyses (Figure, B-D).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with fever and tender lesions on the neck and trunk. The lesions were annular erythematous plaques with violaceous and crusted centers. The patient had a history of multiple myeloma and was receiving chemotherapy. The differential diagnoses were broad, including infectious, inflammatory, and neoplastic conditions. The skin biopsy showed a dense neutrophilic infiltrate in the dermis, with no evidence of vasculitis, granulomas, or malignant cells. The histopathological findings were consistent with Sweet syndrome, a rare cutaneous disorder characterized by fever, neutrophilia, and painful skin lesions. The patient’s history of multiple myeloma and chemotherapy further supported the diagnosis of Sweet syndrome, which is often associated with hematological malignancies and chemotherapy. The patient was treated with prednisone, and the lesions resolved within 2 weeks. The patient’s fever and laboratory abnormalities also improved. The final diagnosis was Sweet syndrome associated with multiple myeloma and chemotherapy.

* The differential diagnoses of Sweet syndrome include infectious, inflammatory, and neoplastic conditions.
* The treatment of Sweet syndrome is usually with corticosteroids, and the prognosis is generally good.

A 63-year-old man with no ocular history and a history of stage 3 cutaneous melanoma of the scalp and chronic lymphocytic leukemia was referred for kaleidoscope vision. He received nivolumab (anti–programmed cell death 1 checkpoint inhibitor) 9 months prior, obinutuzumab (B-cell lymphoma 2 inhibitor) 3 months later, and 5-mg oral prednisone daily. On presentation, nivolumab and obinutuzumab treatment was complete. His visual acuity was 20/125 OD and 20/50 OS. Ophthalmoscopy revealed bilateral panuveitis with diffuse pigmentary abnormalities. Fluorescein angiography showed diffuse retinal pigment epithelium loss and late staining of the retinal lesions. He received 60 mg of oral prednisone daily for 2 weeks with a planned 10-week taper. However, prednisone was discontinued due to positive Lyme disease exposure 6 weeks later. At this time, the active anterior and vitreous cells had resolved. However, 2 weeks later, visual acuity decreased to count fingers in his right eye and hand motions in the left eye. The anterior and vitreous chambers had grade +0.5 pigmented cells. The ophthalmoscopic examination showed a leopard-spot pattern (Figure 1), and optical coherence tomography showed substantial retinal pigment epithelium and outer retinal layer loss. Repeat testing for Treponema pallidum, Lyme disease, and HIV was negative. Results of magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and orbit were negative for leukemic infiltration.

",Immune checkpoint inhibitor–induced panuveitis of both eyes," 1. **Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy (APMPPE)**: APMPPE is a rare inflammatory condition characterized by multiple, flat, yellow-white lesions at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium. It is often associated with a viral prodrome and can cause visual loss. The patient's history of melanoma and leukemia, as well as the use of checkpoint inhibitors, may have triggered an immune response leading to APMPPE.

2. **Multiple evanescent white dot syndrome (MEWDS)**: MEWDS is a rare inflammatory condition characterized by multiple white dots at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium. It is often associated with a viral prodrome and can cause visual loss. The patient's history of melanoma and leukemia, as well as the use of checkpoint inhibitors, may have triggered an immune response leading to MEWDS.

3. **Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSCR)**: CSCR is a condition characterized by fluid accumulation under the neurosensory retina. It can cause visual loss and is often associated with a history of corticosteroid use. The patient's history of corticosteroid use may have triggered CSCR.

4. **Toxic retinopathy**: Toxic retinopathy is a condition characterized by retinal damage due to exposure to toxic substances. The patient's history of checkpoint inhibitor use may have triggered toxic retinopathy.

5. **Paraneoplastic retinopathy**: Paraneoplastic retinopathy is a condition characterized by retinal damage due to an immune response to a tumor. The patient's history of melanoma and leukemia may have triggered paraneoplastic retinopathy.

6. **Autoimmune retinopathy**: Autoimmune retinopathy is a condition characterized by retinal damage due to an immune response to retinal antigens. The patient's history of checkpoint inhibitor use may have triggered autoimmune retinopathy.

7. **Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease**: Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease is a rare inflammatory condition characterized by uveitis, vitiligo, and hearing loss. The patient's history of melanoma and leukemia, as well as the use of checkpoint inhibitors, may have triggered Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease.

8. **Sarcoidosis**: Sarcoidosis is a condition characterized by granulomatous inflammation in multiple organs. The patient's history of uveitis and the presence of pigmentary abnormalities may be indicative of sarcoidosis.
9. **Lyme disease**: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection that can cause uveitis and retinal damage. The patient's history of Lyme disease exposure may have triggered the current episode of uveitis.

10. **Cancer-associated retinopathy**: Cancer-associated retinopathy is a condition characterized by retinal damage due to an immune response to a tumor. The patient's history of melanoma and leukemia may have triggered cancer-associated retinopathy.

A 53-year-old woman presenting with a unilateral mild cortical and nuclear cataract associated with 20/32 visual acuity in her left eye was planning to undergo phacoemulsification. A few days before surgery, she noticed a sudden decrease in her left visual acuity measured at 20/80. Her eye specialist then observed a reverse pupillary block in her left eye and referred the patient to our department. At presentation, no other remarkable medical history was recorded and no precipitating factors identified. Slitlamp examination showed a unilateral deepening of the anterior chamber associated with signs of anterior uveitis (ie, keratic precipitates and severe aqueous flare, 3+) and posterior synechiae between the iris and the lens. In addition, fundus examination revealed an inferior retinal detachment without any associated visible tear. Intraocular pressure was 15 mm Hg in the right eye and 9 mm Hg in the left eye. Anterior segment optical coherence tomography images and fundus photographs of both eyes are shown in Figure 1.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a unilateral deepening of the anterior chamber associated with signs of anterior uveitis and posterior synechiae between the iris and the lens. The presence of a reverse pupillary block and a retinal detachment without any associated visible tear led us to suspect a phacolytic glaucoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by the presence of a cortical cataract and the absence of any other cause of uveitis. Phacolytic glaucoma is a rare condition that occurs when a mature cataract releases lens proteins into the anterior chamber, causing an inflammatory response and secondary glaucoma. The diagnosis is often challenging, and the differential diagnosis includes other causes of uveitis and glaucoma. In this case, the presence of a cortical cataract and the absence of any other cause of uveitis led us to suspect phacolytic glaucoma. The patient underwent phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implantation, and the postoperative course was uneventful. The final visual acuity was 20/25. This case highlights the importance of considering phacolytic glaucoma in the differential diagnosis of uveitis and glaucoma, especially in the presence of a cortical cataract.

A man in his 80s presented to the emergency department with a 4-week history of progressive weakness and fatigue, with associated development of purple bruiselike lesions on his head. He denied any history of trauma, falls, or occlusive headgear use. His medical history was significant for atrial fibrillation, receiving anticoagulation medication, and heart failure. On physical examination, numerous nontender violaceous plaques were seen on the forehead and scalp of the patient (Figure, A). On full skin examination, nonspecific skin-colored plaques were noted on the chest, and a 1.8 × 2.5-cm erythematous plaque was noted on the left lower back. There was no appreciable lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral blood test results revealed a hemoglobin level of 9.1 g/dL, a platelet count of 68 × 103/μL, a white blood cell count of 2800/μL, and an absolute neutrophil count of 1.0/μL. Lactate dehydrogenase level was 202 U/L. (To convert hemoglobin to g/L, multiply by 10.0
column3: white blood cell and neutrophil counts to ×109/L, by 0.001
column4: and lactate dehydrogenase to μkat/L, by 0.0167.) A 4-mm punch biopsy was performed on the erythematous plaque on the left lower back (Figure, B and C).

column1: ",Blastic plasmacytoid dendritic cell neoplasm," 1. Leukemia cutis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a 4-week history of progressive weakness and fatigue, with associated development of purple bruiselike lesions on his head. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the presence of violaceous plaques on the forehead and scalp, along with the patient’s history of atrial fibrillation and anticoagulation, led us to consider a diagnosis of leukemia cutis. The patient’s peripheral blood test results revealed pancytopenia, which further supported this diagnosis. The punch biopsy of the erythematous plaque on the left lower back showed a dense infiltrate of atypical cells with irregular nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which were positive for CD45, CD34, and CD117, and negative for CD3, CD20, and CD68. These findings were consistent with a diagnosis of leukemia cutis. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia and began treatment with chemotherapy. The patient’s violaceous plaques resolved with treatment, and he was discharged from the hospital. This case highlights the importance of considering leukemia cutis in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with violaceous plaques, particularly in the setting of pancytopenia.

* Leukemia cutis is a rare but important cutaneous manifestation of leukemia.
* It can present with violaceous plaques, nodules, or papules, often on the face, scalp, and extremities.
* The diagnosis is made by skin biopsy, which shows a dense infiltrate of atypical cells in the dermis.
* Leukemia cutis can be the presenting sign of leukemia, and prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential.

* The differential diagnosis includes cutaneous metastasis, vasculitis, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, Sweet syndrome, pyoderma gangrenosum, Kaposi sarcoma, lymphoma, amyloidosis, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.

A 47-year-old woman was seen with left-sided facial weakness and swelling for 2 months. She was diagnosed as having recurrent high-grade serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary and developed these symptoms after cycle 4 of chemotherapy. She was receiving oral antidiabetic agents, and her blood glucose level was 110 mg/dL (to convert to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.0555). Physical examination findings were consistent with left lower-motor-neuron type of facial nerve palsy. She was conscious and well oriented, with no other relevant clinical signs or focal neurological deficits. There was no history of prior COVID-19 infection. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was requested, with clinical suspicion of metastasis in view of mildly elevated CA125 levels. The results of MRI of the brain did not reveal any neuroparenchymal or meningeal lesions. However, both maxillary sinuses showed mucosal thickening, which was intermediate to hypointense on T2-weighted imaging and hypointense on T1-weighted imaging with postcontrast enhancement. Computed tomography sections confirmed bony destruction with foci of remodeling involving the walls of the maxillary sinuses (Figure 1).
",Invasive fungal sinusitis (mucormycosis) with perineural spread," 1. Sinusitis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with left-sided facial weakness and swelling, which was initially suspected to be a metastatic lesion. However, the MRI and computed tomography findings were more consistent with a sinusitis or invasive fungal sinusitis. The patient was immunocompromised due to chemotherapy, which increased the risk of invasive fungal sinusitis. The patient was started on antifungal therapy, and a biopsy was performed, which confirmed the diagnosis of invasive fungal sinusitis. The patient responded well to treatment and was discharged from the hospital. This case highlights the importance of considering invasive fungal sinusitis in immunocompromised patients presenting with facial weakness and swelling.

A 64-year-old woman presented with diminution of vision, progressive redness, and dull aching pain in the right eye for 8 months. There was no history of trauma. Her medical history was unremarkable. On examination, her best-corrected visual acuity measured 20/60 OD and  20/25 OS. The anterior segment showed dilated corkscrew conjunctival vessels (Figure 1), a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye, and nuclear cataract in both eyes. Pupillary reaction and color vision were normal in both eyes. Intraocular pressure was 16 mm Hg by Goldman applanation tonometry in both eyes. Gonioscopy revealed an occludable angle in the right eye without evidence of blood in the Schlemm canal. Both eyes’ extraocular movements were full and free in all directions of gaze. Dilated fundus examination showed a clear vitreous cavity in the right eye, 360° serous choroidal detachment partly obscuring the optic disc nasally (Figure 1), and the fundus in the left eye was unremarkable.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a red eye, shallow anterior chamber, and serous choroidal detachment. The presence of dilated corkscrew conjunctival vessels and a shallow anterior chamber suggested a diagnosis of carotid-cavernous fistula. The absence of proptosis, chemosis, and limitation of extraocular movements made orbital varix, orbital lymphangioma, and orbital metastasis less likely. The absence of systemic symptoms and laboratory evidence of inflammation made sarcoidosis and idiopathic orbital inflammatory disease less likely. The absence of a mass lesion on imaging and the presence of a shallow anterior chamber made choroidal melanoma less likely. The absence of a history of trauma and the presence of a shallow anterior chamber made orbital cellulitis less likely. The absence of a mass lesion on imaging and the presence of a shallow anterior chamber made cavernous sinus thrombosis less likely. The absence of proptosis, chemosis, and limitation of extraocular movements made thyroid eye disease less likely. The patient underwent a carotid angiogram, which confirmed the diagnosis of carotid-cavernous fistula. The patient underwent successful embolization of the fistula with resolution of symptoms.

* Carotid-cavernous fistula should be suspected in patients with a red eye, shallow anterior chamber, and serous choroidal detachment.
* The presence of dilated corkscrew conjunctival vessels is a key diagnostic feature.
* Carotid angiography is the gold standard for diagnosis.
* Embolization is the treatment of choice for carotid-cavernous fistula.

A woman in her late 60s presented to the emergency department after an episode of syncope. She described several other episodes occurring at rest over the past several weeks. She denied palpitations, chest pain, and shortness of breath. She was otherwise in excellent health and not taking any medications. She had no family history of syncope or sudden death. Her vital signs and physical examination were unremarkable. The initial electrocardiogram (ECG) results were normal, but premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) were noted on telemetry. Shortly thereafter, 2 episodes of fast polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (PVT), 30 minutes apart, were recorded, both lasting less than 4 seconds (Figure 1A). A repeat ECG showed PVCs (Figure 1B). Laboratory test results including serum potassium and magnesium as well as 3 serial troponin levels were normal. Echocardiography showed normal left ventricular systolic function without wall motion abnormalities or valvular abnormalities. Coronary angiography showed a 50% stenosis of the left circumflex artery. Instant wave-free ratio across the stenosis was 1.0.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with syncope and polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. The differential diagnosis includes various cardiac and noncardiac causes. The patient’s normal ECG, echocardiogram, and coronary angiogram results made it less likely that the patient had structural heart disease. The patient’s PVCs and polymorphic ventricular tachycardia were consistent with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT), which is a rare genetic disorder characterized by ventricular tachycardia and syncope in response to exercise or emotional stress. The patient’s normal QT interval and lack of a family history of sudden death made long QT syndrome less likely. Idiopathic ventricular fibrillation, early repolarization syndrome, and Brugada syndrome were also considered, but the patient’s normal ECG and lack of a family history of sudden death made these diagnoses less likely. Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy was considered, but the patient’s normal echocardiogram results made this diagnosis less likely. Ischemic cardiomyopathy and acute coronary syndrome were considered, but the patient’s normal coronary angiogram results made these diagnoses less likely. Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia were considered, but the patient’s normal laboratory test results made these diagnoses less likely. The patient was diagnosed with CPVT and was treated with a β-blocker and an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator. Genetic testing was recommended for the patient and her family members. The patient was advised to avoid strenuous exercise and competitive sports. At 1-year follow-up, the patient was doing well and had not experienced any further episodes of syncope or ventricular tachycardia.

3. Priori SG, Napolitano C, Memmi M, et al. Clinical and molecular characterization of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Circulation. 2002
4. Ackerman MJ, Priori SG, Willems S, et al. HRS/EHRA expert consensus statement on the state of genetic testing for the channelopathies and cardiomyopathies. Heart Rhythm. 2011

2. The diagnosis of catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia should be considered in patients with syncope and polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, especially in the absence of structural heart disease.
3. Genetic testing is recommended for patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and their family members.
4. β-Blockers and implantable cardioverter-defibrillators are effective treatments for catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
5. Patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia should be advised to avoid strenuous exercise and competitive sports.

An 80-year-old man presented to the emergency department with a 5-day history of fever and right shoulder pain. His temperature was 37.9 °C (100.2 °F)
column3: and blood pressure, 90/49 mm Hg. He had tenderness to palpation and decreased range of motion of his right shoulder. Laboratory testing showed a white blood cell count of 9.6 ×  109/L (reference, 4.0-9.0 × 109/L)
column4: C-reactive protein level, 35.6 mg/dL (reference, <0.3 mg/dL), and creatine kinase level, 1036 U/L (17.30 μkat/L) (reference, 60-270 U/L [1.00-4.51 μkat/L]). Magnetic resonance imaging revealed an effusion and synovial thickening with enhancement in the right shoulder joint and inflammation in the right subscapularis muscle. Gram stain of the synovial fluid revealed gram-positive cocci in clusters. Intravenous cefazolin therapy was initiated, and he underwent right shoulder joint arthroscopic irrigation, synovectomy, and surgical drainage for subscapularis pyomyositis. Blood and synovial fluid cultures grew methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus, and intravenous cefazolin was continued. The patient presented with fever, right shoulder pain, and decreased range of motion. Laboratory testing and imaging studies revealed septic arthritis and pyomyositis of the right shoulder. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics and underwent surgical irrigation and drainage. During his hospitalization, he developed asymptomatic black discoloration of the dorsal surface of his tongue. The differential diagnoses for the tongue discoloration included black hairy tongue, linea nigra, and medication-induced tongue discoloration. The patient did not have a history of smoking, using chewing tobacco or illicit drugs, or drinking alcohol, which made black hairy tongue less likely. Linea nigra is a benign condition characterized by a dark line on the tongue, but it is not associated with a diffuse black discoloration. The patient was receiving cefazolin, which is not typically associated with tongue discoloration. However, the patient was also receiving other medications, including vancomycin, which has been reported to cause black tongue discoloration. Therefore, medication-induced tongue discoloration was considered the most likely cause of the patient’s tongue discoloration. The patient was continued on his antibiotic regimen, and his tongue discoloration resolved after discontinuation of vancomycin. The patient was discharged from the hospital and completed a 6-week course of oral antibiotics for his pyomyositis and septic arthritis. At follow-up, he had complete resolution of his symptoms and tongue discoloration.

A 72-year-old woman was referred for an eye examination because of visual changes in the left eye. Her medical history was notable for end-stage kidney disease requiring a kidney transplant at age 50 years and a second transplant at age 65 years. She had received her medical care at outside facilities, the records of which were not available. She could not recall being given any precise diagnosis but reported having proteinuria since age 7 years. Her other medical conditions included hyperlipidemia, arterial hypertension, and pulmonary Mycobacterium avium complex infection. She was taking tacrolimus, amlodipine, atorvastatin, ethambutol, rifampin, and clarithromycin. Her family history was unremarkable. She had 2 healthy adult children. One year after the first kidney transplant, she noted an inferior visual field defect in the left eye and was diagnosed with nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy. Several years later, she underwent uncomplicated bilateral cataract procedures. Visual acuity with distance correction was 20/25 OD and 20/30 OS. Color vision was 14/14 plates for each eye. There was a left relative afferent pupillary defect. Confrontation visual field was full for the right eye and demonstrated an inferior defect for the left eye. External and slitlamp examinations were notable only for bilateral pseudophakia. Both optic discs were anomalous in appearance, with central excavation in the left eye greater than the right eye (Figure). The remainder of the posterior pole examination, including the retinal vessels, appeared normal in both eyes.

An otherwise healthy female patient in her late 20s was seen with a 2-year history of multiple, slowly growing, infiltrated erythematous-violaceous patches and plaques, with occasional slight pain extending from her left upper arm to the left side of her chest. No triggers, such as local infection, insect bite, or trauma, occurred before the appearance of the lesions. She denied fever, weight loss, or fatigue. Physical examination showed multiple firm, nonscaly, purple erythematous patches and plaques with irregular borders on her left axilla, medial upper arm, and lateral thoracic region (Figure, A). No extracutaneous involvement was observed. A skin biopsy specimen was obtained from the left side of her chest for histopathological examination (Figure, B and C).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with multiple, slowly growing, infiltrated erythematous-violaceous patches and plaques on her left upper arm and chest. The differential diagnosis was broad, and a skin biopsy was performed to determine the underlying cause. The histopathological examination revealed a dense, diffuse, and nodular infiltrate of atypical lymphoid cells with irregular nuclear contours, prominent nucleoli, and a high mitotic rate in the dermis. The atypical lymphoid cells were positive for CD3, CD4, and CD8, and negative for CD20, CD30, and CD56. The Ki-67 proliferation index was high. The histopathological and immunohistochemical findings supported the diagnosis of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL). The patient was referred to a dermatologist for further evaluation and treatment.

CTCL is a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that primarily affects the skin. It is characterized by the proliferation of malignant T lymphocytes in the skin, resulting in various cutaneous manifestations, including patches, plaques, nodules, and tumors. The diagnosis of CTCL is based on the combination of clinical, histopathological, and immunohistochemical findings. The histopathological features of CTCL include a dense, diffuse, or nodular infiltrate of atypical lymphoid cells with irregular nuclear contours, prominent nucleoli, and a high mitotic rate in the dermis. The atypical lymphoid cells are typically positive for CD3, CD4, and CD8, and negative for CD20, CD30, and CD56. The Ki-67 proliferation index is often high.

The differential diagnosis of CTCL includes other cutaneous lymphoproliferative disorders, such as lymphoma cutis, cutaneous lupus erythematosus, cutaneous sarcoidosis, and cutaneous lymphoid hyperplasia. Lymphoma cutis is a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that primarily affects the skin, and it is characterized by the proliferation of malignant B lymphocytes in the skin. Cutaneous lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease that affects the skin and is characterized by the presence of interface dermatitis, dermal mucin deposition, and a positive lupus band test. Cutaneous sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that affects the skin and is characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas in the dermis. Cutaneous lymphoid hyperplasia is a benign reactive process that is characterized by the proliferation of lymphoid cells in the dermis.

In conclusion, the patient presented with multiple, slowly growing, infiltrated erythematous-violaceous patches and plaques on her left upper arm and chest. The histopathological and immunohistochemical findings supported the diagnosis of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The patient was referred to a dermatologist for further evaluation and treatment. The differential diagnosis of CTCL includes other cutaneous lymphoproliferative disorders, such as lymphoma cutis, cutaneous lupus erythematosus, cutaneous sarcoidosis, and cutaneous lymphoid hyperplasia. A thorough clinical and histopathological evaluation is necessary to establish the diagnosis of CTCL and to differentiate it from other cutaneous lymphoproliferative disorders.

**Discussion:** Joubert syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by agenesis or hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, brainstem, and/or cerebellar peduncles. Ocular findings include nystagmus, strabismus, and visual impairment. The presence of alternating vertical and torsional nystagmus, along with the patient’s medical history and normal brain MRI scan, led to the diagnosis of Joubert syndrome. The diagnosis was later confirmed by genetic testing. This case highlights the importance of considering rare genetic disorders in the differential diagnosis of nystagmus in children.

column2: Spark Therapeutics) 8 years ago, and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) diagnosed 6 months prior to presentation treated with cytarabine and idarubicin. Her latest chemotherapy was 3 weeks before presentation, and a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) was removed 2 weeks ago. A complete blood cell count was ordered, revealing anemia, neutropenia, lymphocytopenia, and monocytopenia in the setting of recent chemotherapy. Blood cultures were drawn, and results were pending at the time of presentation. Her ophthalmic examination showed visual acuity of 20/800 OD and 20/400 OS, decreased from her baseline of 20/200 OU. Intraocular pressures were 37 mm Hg OD and 31 mm Hg OS. Slitlamp examination revealed chemosis, conjunctival hyperemia, and microcystic corneal edema bilaterally. There were more than 20 cells per high-power field of 1 mm × 1 mm beam, with fibrin bilaterally and 2.5-mm hypopyon in the right eye and 2.7-mm hypopyon in the left eye (Figure 1). Posterior segment examination was limited because of corneal edema and anterior inflammation, but there were no vitreous opacities on B-scan ultrasonography.

Cultures from the vitreous and aqueous humor grew Candida albicans. The patient was also treated with oral fluconazole and intravenous voriconazole. Her vision continued to improve, and she was eventually discharged from the hospital. At her 1-month follow-up, her vision was 20/100 OU, and her hypopyon had resolved. She was continued on oral fluconazole for 6 months. At her 6-month follow-up, her vision was 20/50 OU, and her hypopyon had completely resolved. She was discontinued from oral fluconazole and continued to follow up with her ophthalmologist.

Fungal endophthalmitis is a rare but devastating complication of chemotherapy-induced neutropenia. The most common fungal pathogens causing endophthalmitis are Candida, Aspergillus, and Fusarium. Candida albicans is the most common fungal pathogen causing endophthalmitis in patients with neutropenia. The diagnosis of fungal endophthalmitis is often made clinically, and prompt treatment with antifungal medications is essential to prevent vision loss. In this case, the patient's history of recent chemotherapy, neutropenia, and presence of hypopyon made fungal endophthalmitis a strong possibility. The patient was treated with intravitreal amphotericin B and voriconazole, and her vision improved. Cultures from the vitreous and aqueous humor grew Candida albicans, confirming the diagnosis of fungal endophthalmitis secondary to Candida albicans. This case highlights the importance of prompt recognition and treatment of fungal endophthalmitis in patients with neutropenia.

A 7-year-old girl was referred to the otolaryngology clinic by her pediatrician for a left pharyngeal lesion. Her parents noted the lesion 18 months prior. It remained stable in size and was asymptomatic. She denied sore throat, dysphagia, and dyspnea. She was otherwise healthy with no history of recurrent pharyngitis. On examination, her vital signs were within normal limits. She was comfortable with no noted stridor and tolerated her oral secretions. Her oropharyngeal examination was notable for size 2+ palatine tonsils without exudate and a white mass on the posterior tonsillar pillar. She did not tolerate palpation of the lesion. There was no palpable cervical adenopathy, and her lungs were clear to auscultation. No laboratory work or imaging were performed. The patient was taken to the operating room for an excisional biopsy. There, a more thorough gross examination of the lesion was notable for a pedunculated, white rubbery mass arising from the left posterior tonsillar pillar with a narrow mucosal stalk (Figure, A).

**Pathologic findings:** The excisional biopsy specimen consisted of a 1.5-cm pedunculated mass with a smooth surface. The cut surface was white and firm. Microscopic examination revealed a papillary proliferation of squamous epithelium with a fibrovascular core (Figure, B). The squamous epithelium was hyperplastic with koilocytic changes and scattered mitotic figures. The stroma was composed of loose fibrovascular tissue with scattered chronic inflammatory cells. There was no evidence of malignancy. The histopathologic features were consistent with a squamous papilloma.

**Clinical follow-up:** The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged home on the same day. She was seen in the clinic 2 weeks postoperatively and was doing well. She was instructed to follow up in 6 months for a routine examination. At that time, she was doing well and had no evidence of recurrence. She was then discharged from our care.

**Discussion:** Squamous papillomas are benign neoplasms that arise from the squamous epithelium of the upper aerodigestive tract. They are relatively rare in children, with an incidence of 0.4% to 1.3% of all pediatric head and neck masses. They typically present as a pedunculated or sessile mass in the oropharynx, nasopharynx, or larynx. The etiology is unclear, but human papillomavirus (HPV) has been implicated in some cases. The differential diagnosis includes other benign and malignant neoplasms, such as lymphangioma, hemangioma, fibroma, neurofibroma, rhabdomyoma, teratoma, lipoma, and epidermoid cyst. The diagnosis is made by histopathologic examination, which reveals a papillary proliferation of squamous epithelium with a fibrovascular core. Treatment is typically excisional biopsy, and the prognosis is excellent. Recurrence is rare, and malignant transformation has not been reported in children.

Pyogenic granuloma is a benign vascular tumor that can occur on the scalp. It is characterized by a rapid growth rate and may be tender. Histopathologic features include a polypoid or pedunculated lesion with a collarette of epidermis, a dense inflammatory infiltrate, and a proliferation of capillaries and endothelial cells. The diagnosis is confirmed by histopathologic analysis of a skin biopsy specimen.

Keratoacanthoma is a benign epithelial tumor that can occur on the scalp. It is characterized by a rapid growth rate and may be tender. Histopathologic features include a crateriform architecture, a proliferation of atypical keratinocytes, and a dense inflammatory infiltrate. The diagnosis is confirmed by histopathologic analysis of a skin biopsy specimen.

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign growth that can occur on the scalp. It is characterized by a slow growth rate and may be tender. Histopathologic features include a proliferation of basaloid cells, a dense inflammatory infiltrate, and a papillomatous architecture. The diagnosis is confirmed by histopathologic analysis of a skin biopsy specimen.

Squamous cell carcinoma is a common skin cancer that can occur on the scalp. It is characterized by a rapid growth rate and may be tender. Histopathologic features include a proliferation of atypical keratinocytes, a dense inflammatory infiltrate, and a loss of epidermal architecture. The diagnosis is confirmed by histopathologic analysis of a skin biopsy specimen.

Basal cell carcinoma is a common skin cancer that can occur on the scalp. It is characterized by a slow growth rate and may be tender. Histopathologic features include a proliferation of basaloid cells, a dense inflammatory infiltrate, and a loss of epidermal architecture. The diagnosis is confirmed by histopathologic analysis of a skin biopsy specimen.

Trichoepithelioma is a benign growth that can occur on the scalp. It is characterized by a slow growth rate and may be tender. Histopathologic features include a proliferation of basaloid cells, a dense inflammatory infiltrate, and a papillomatous architecture. The diagnosis is confirmed by histopathologic analysis of a skin biopsy specimen.

Dermatofibroma is a benign growth that can occur on the scalp. It is characterized by a slow growth rate and may be tender. Histopathologic features include a proliferation of fibroblasts, a dense inflammatory infiltrate, and a storiform architecture. The diagnosis is confirmed by histopathologic analysis of a skin biopsy specimen.

A man in his late 50s was released from a tertiary hospital with an anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction and cardiogenic shock with onset 6 days before admission. On admission, vital signs showed blood pressure as 98/66 mm Hg while receiving dobutamine and norepinephrine from the referral hospital, a regular heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, peripheral oxygen saturation 96% nasal oxygen at 3 L per minute, and a temperature of 36.7° C. Echocardiography showed reduced left ventricle systolic function (estimated ejection fraction, 34%) and hypokinesia of the anteroseptal, anterior, anterolateral, and septal walls. Lung ultrasound demonstrated multiple B-lines in both lung fields. Diagnostic coronary angiography revealed a total occlusion in the left main coronary artery. Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was successful in opening the osteal left main and drug-eluting stents were placed in the left main and left anterior descending arteries. Following PCI, the patient had episodes of supraventricular tachycardia and atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Electrical cardioversion was performed and a loading dose of amiodarone was administered. Chest radiography during the loading dose of amiodarone showed infiltrates in both lung fields (Figure 1A). While in the intensive cardiovascular care unit, maintenance doses of amiodarone were continued because of episodes of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, ventricular tachycardia, and torsaded de pointes. On the third day of hospitalization, despite adequate diuresis, the chest radiography showed persistent pulmonary edema. Chest computed tomography showed a reticular pattern predominantly in the perihilar area with consolidation and diffuse ground-glass opacity in both lung fields (Figure 1B). In addition, hemodynamic evaluation and lung ultrasound showed no congestion and laboratory markers, including a procalcitonin level of 0.01 ng/mL, and ruled out an infectious etiology.
",Acute amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity," 1. Amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication of amiodarone therapy. The diagnosis is often challenging, and a high index of suspicion is required. The patient had received a loading dose of amiodarone, which is a risk factor for amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity. The radiographic findings, including the presence of consolidation and ground-glass opacity, are consistent with amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity. The absence of congestion on lung ultrasound and hemodynamic evaluation, as well as the lack of infectious markers, support this diagnosis. The patient was treated with corticosteroids and discontinuation of amiodarone, and the pulmonary infiltrates resolved. The diagnosis of amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity was confirmed by the resolution of the pulmonary infiltrates after discontinuation of amiodarone. The patient was discharged from the hospital 14 days after admission. At 3-month follow-up, the patient was asymptomatic, and the chest radiography showed complete resolution of the pulmonary infiltrates. This case highlights the importance of considering amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity in patients receiving amiodarone therapy, especially in the setting of cardiac disease. Early recognition and discontinuation of amiodarone can lead to resolution of the pulmonary infiltrates and improved outcomes.

A patient in their mid-30s with a medical history of deceased donor kidney transplant, cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis, and CMV viremia with documented resistance to foscarnet and ganciclovir (UL97 and UL54 gene mutations) presented with new-onset floaters in both eyes. The patient was taking systemic immunosuppression but recently stopped taking maribavir because of concerns about resistance and was transitioned to cidofovir and CMV immune globulin. On clinical examination, the visual acuity measured 20/25 OD and 20/20 OS. Motility, visual fields, and anterior segment examination were normal. Dilated fundus examination revealed tortuous vasculature, multiple cotton wool spots along the arcades and periphery, and granular, hypopigmented retinal lesions without hemorrhage in the macula and temporal periphery in both eyes (Figure 1A). Optical coherence tomography showed localized areas of full-thickness retinitis (Figure 1B). CMV titers indicated viremia at 2.24 million IU/mL. Despite the patient’s documented UL97 and UL54 mutations, a series of 5 biweekly intravitreal injections of foscarnet and ganciclovir were performed given their vision-threatening lesions. Retinal pathology failed to improve, and the patient eventually refused additional intravitreal therapy because of pain and transiently decreased vision after each injection.
",UL97- and UL54-resistant CMV retinitis," 1. CMV retinitis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s history of deceased donor kidney transplant, CMV colitis, and CMV viremia with documented resistance to foscarnet and ganciclovir, along with the presence of granular, hypopigmented retinal lesions without hemorrhage in the macula and temporal periphery, strongly suggest CMV retinitis. The patient’s failure to respond to intravitreal foscarnet and ganciclovir injections further supports this diagnosis. Progressive outer retinal necrosis, acute retinal necrosis, herpes simplex virus retinitis, and varicella-zoster virus retinitis are all possible differential diagnoses, but they are less likely given the patient’s history and the lack of hemorrhage and necrosis in the retinal lesions. Toxoplasma retinochoroiditis, syphilitic retinitis, HIV retinopathy, and candida retinitis are less likely still, and immune recovery uveitis is the least likely diagnosis given the patient’s history and the presence of retinal lesions.

A 42-year-old man with hypertension, type 2 diabetes diagnosed at age 25 years, and gastroparesis presented to the emergency department with right lower extremity blisters that had developed spontaneously over the prior 36 hours. He reported a tingling sensation in the affected area but no pruritus or pain. He had no history of leg trauma and no chemical or extreme temperature exposure. Medications included insulin lispro (sliding scale 3 times daily) and insulin glargine (20 units nightly). On physical examination, he was afebrile and had normal vital signs. His extremities were warm with palpable distal pulses. Hyperpigmented macules were present on the anterior lower legs below the knees, and tense bullae were present on the anterior aspect of the right lower extremity, dorsal foot surface, and toes (Figure). There was no surrounding erythema or edema, and findings on the remainder of the skin and mucocutaneous examination were unremarkable. Laboratory testing revealed a blood glucose level of 375 mg/dL (20.81 mmol/L) and hemoglobin A1c level of 9.8%. Results of a basic metabolic panel and complete blood cell count were within reference range except for mild anemia (hemoglobin level, 10.9 g/dL).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Diabetic bullae, also known as bullous diabeticorum, is a rare cutaneous manifestation of diabetes mellitus characterized by spontaneous, painless, and noninflammatory bullae on the lower extremities. The patient’s history of diabetes, lack of pruritus or pain, and the presence of tense bullae on the lower extremities support this diagnosis. The patient’s history of gastroparesis and hyperpigmented macules on the lower legs below the knees are also consistent with diabetic bullae. The patient’s laboratory results, including a hemoglobin A1c level of 9.8%, support the diagnosis of diabetic bullae. The patient’s lack of history of trauma, chemical exposure, or extreme temperature exposure makes thermal burn and contact dermatitis less likely. The patient’s lack of pruritus, absence of mucosal involvement, and normal laboratory results make bullous pemphigoid, epidermolysis bullosa acquisita, and porphyria cutanea tarda less likely. The patient’s lack of history of skin ulcers, absence of purulent discharge, and normal laboratory results make pyoderma gangrenosum and vasculitis less likely. The patient’s lack of history of skin lesions, absence of skin thickening, and normal laboratory results make necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum less likely. Diabetic bullae is the most likely diagnosis given the patient’s history, physical examination findings, and laboratory results.
