A 72-year-old homeless man was referred for management of a recurrent cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the right temple and brow. On review of history, maxillofacial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without contrast done 5 months prior to presentation showed a 5.9 × 5.3 × 3.7-cm mass centered at the right temple that tracked along the right lateral orbital wall as well as an enhancing right intraparotid lymph node. The patient was lost to follow-up and re-presented 5 months later with an enlarged crusting and ulcerating lesion of the right temple/brow (Figure 1A). On ocular examination, best-corrected visual acuity was 20/100 OD and 20/125 OS due to cataracts, pupils reacted normally without afferent pupillary defect, and ocular motility was full. He had mild proptosis in the right eye and right lower eyelid retraction. Orbicularis strength was intact and symmetric in both eyes. MRI of the orbits, face, and neck with and without contrast showed a 6.1 × 5.7 × 4.0-cm mass with erosion through the right sphenoid wing, involvement of the lacrimal gland, and abutment of the lateral rectus (Figure 1B). In discussing treatment strategies for the orbital component of the disease, the patient was strongly against an orbital exenteration.

The patient underwent a right orbital biopsy, which showed invasive squamous cell carcinoma with perineural invasion. The tumor was positive for p63 and negative for CK7, CK20, and S100. The patient was treated with concurrent chemoradiation therapy. The patient had a partial response to treatment and was referred to a multidisciplinary tumor board for further management. The patient ultimately underwent a right orbital exenteration with a free flap reconstruction. The final pathology showed a 6.5-cm invasive squamous cell carcinoma with perineural invasion and involvement of the lacrimal gland, orbital bone, and orbital soft tissue. The tumor was positive for p63 and negative for CK7, CK20, and S100. The patient had a 6-month follow-up with no evidence of recurrence. An otherwise healthy man in his 60s presented to our department with an 8-month history of widespread pruritic papulonodular skin lesions on his extremities and trunk. The patient had been initially diagnosed with nodular prurigo at a local hospital and treated with various topical steroids and oral antihistamines for 2 months, without significant improvement. The skin lesions continued to progress and worsened after scratching. Physical examinations revealed disseminated erythematous papules, hypertrophic plaques approximately 1 to 2 cm in diameter, and dome-shaped nodules with excoriated whitish or pink centers on the scalp, chest, abdomen, back, waist, and extremities (Figure, A and B). Subsequent examinations of the mucosal membranes appeared normal. Other physical examinations as well as his medical and family histories were unremarkable. Peripheral eosinophils, serum total immunoglobulin E level, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) test for HIV, and results of other routine laboratory tests were within normal ranges or negative. A biopsy specimen was taken from one of the skin lesions on his right forearm for histopathological examination and direct immunofluorescence (DIF) testing (Figure, C and D).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with widespread pruritic papulonodular skin lesions on his extremities and trunk. The skin lesions were characterized by erythematous papules, hypertrophic plaques, and dome-shaped nodules with excoriated whitish or pink centers. The histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen revealed a dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the dermis, with some lymphocytes showing atypia and epidermotropism. The DIF test showed a strong positive reaction for CD3 and CD4, but a negative reaction for CD8. The histopathological and DIF findings supported the diagnosis of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL). The patient was referred to the department of hematology for further evaluation and treatment. The final diagnosis was confirmed as CTCL, and the patient received systemic chemotherapy and phototherapy. The patient’s skin lesions improved significantly after treatment.

CTCL is a rare and heterogeneous group of non-Hodgkin lymphomas that primarily affect the skin. The diagnosis of CTCL is often challenging because of its nonspecific clinical and histopathological features. The differential diagnosis of CTCL includes various benign and malignant skin disorders, such as cutaneous lymphoid hyperplasia, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, cutaneous sarcoidosis, prurigo nodularis, and nodular prurigo. A thorough physical examination, laboratory tests, and histopathological and immunohistochemical examinations are essential for the diagnosis of CTCL. The DIF test is a useful tool for the diagnosis of CTCL, and it can help to distinguish CTCL from other skin disorders. Early diagnosis and treatment of CTCL are crucial to improve the prognosis of patients with this disease.

A 37-year-old Asian nonsmoking man with no known medical or drug history presented with an insidious onset of left-eye ptosis (only brought to attention by his friends on review of recent photographs) and subsequent painless vertical diplopia for 1 year. He did not complain of headaches, facial numbness, dysarthria, facial droop, dysphagia, or limb weakness or numbness. There was no history of joint pain or constitutional symptoms. Neurological examination revealed a nonfatigable partial left-eyelid ptosis, left-eye hypotropia at primary position, and impaired left eye supraduction (Figure 1) with a nonreactive left pupil on direct and consensual light reflexes. There were no other cranial nerve deficits. Limb reflexes, motor testing, and sensory testing results were normal, and the plantar responses were flexor.
",Neurovascular conflict of the oculomotor nerve," 1. Myasthenia gravis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a 1-year history of left-eye ptosis and vertical diplopia. The examination revealed a nonfatigable partial left-eyelid ptosis, left-eye hypotropia, and impaired left eye supraduction with a nonreactive left pupil. The differential diagnosis was broad, and the patient underwent a series of investigations, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and orbits, computed tomography (CT) of the orbits, and a thorough systemic evaluation. The MRI of the brain and orbits revealed a 1.5-cm enhancing mass in the left cavernous sinus extending into the superior orbital fissure, compressing the left oculomotor nerve (Figure 2). The CT of the orbits showed a soft-tissue mass in the left cavernous sinus with bony erosion of the lateral wall of the sphenoid sinus (Figure 3). The patient underwent a transsphenoidal biopsy of the mass, which revealed a granulomatous inflammation with giant cells and epithelioid cells, consistent with a diagnosis of Tolosa-Hunt syndrome (Figure 4). The patient was treated with oral prednisolone, 60 mg/d, and showed significant improvement in his symptoms over the next 2 weeks. The patient was followed up for 6 months, and his symptoms remained stable. Tolosa-Hunt syndrome is a rare condition characterized by painful ophthalmoplegia caused by a granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus. The diagnosis is often made by exclusion of other causes of painful ophthalmoplegia and by the demonstration of a granulomatous inflammation on biopsy. The patient’s symptoms and radiological findings were consistent with Tolosa-Hunt syndrome, and the biopsy confirmed the diagnosis. The patient responded well to corticosteroid therapy, which is the mainstay of treatment for this condition.

4. Kline LB, Hoyt WF. The Tolosa-Hunt syndrome. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2001

A 15-year-old girl presented to the otorhinolaryngologic department for a right-side postauricular mass. The mass had been present since birth but had slowly grown larger in the previous 2 years. On physical examination, a 2.5 × 1.5-cm, nontender, blue, soft, cystic mass was observed in the right postauricular area. There were no fistular openings around the auricle or in the external auditory canal (EAC), and there were no additional cysts, sinuses, or fistulas at the right neck from the hyoid bone and chin to the EAC. On temporal bone computed tomography, a 2.5 × 1.5-cm, hypodense, oval-shaped cystic mass was revealed at the subcutaneous fat layer superoposterior to the right auricle. On temporal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), an oval cystic mass was revealed at the same location, with high signal intensity on both T1-weighted and T2-weighted images and low signal intensity on enhanced T1-weighted fat suppression and T2-weighted short T1 inversion recovery images (Figure, A-D). In surgery, the well-demarcated cystic mass was completely excised. Yellowish fluid leaked out of the cyst during excision. On histopathologic examination, the cyst was lined by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands. The cyst contained keratinous debris (Figure, E). There was no recurrence 6 months after surgery.
",Type 1 first branchial cleft cyst," 1. Branchial cleft cyst
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a congenital, slow-growing, blue, soft, cystic mass in the right postauricular area. The mass was lined by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands, and it contained keratinous debris. The differential diagnoses were narrowed down to branchial cleft cyst, epidermoid cyst, dermoid cyst, sebaceous cyst, teratoma, lymphangioma, hemangioma, lipoma, and cystic hygroma. The patient’s age, the location of the mass, and the histopathologic findings supported the diagnosis of a first branchial cleft cyst. The first branchial cleft cyst is a rare congenital anomaly that arises from the first branchial cleft, which is the groove between the maxillary and mandibular prominences. It is usually located in the preauricular or postauricular area. The cyst is lined by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands, and it may contain keratinous debris. The treatment is surgical excision. The patient had no recurrence 6 months after surgery. The first branchial cleft cyst was ranked as the most likely diagnosis, followed by branchial cleft cyst, dermoid cyst, epidermoid cyst, teratoma, sebaceous cyst, lymphangioma, hemangioma, lipoma, and cystic hygroma.

3.  Aggarwal S, Kumar A, Kumar S, et al. First branchial cleft anomaly: a rare case report. J Clin Diagn Res. 2014
4.  Lee JH, Kim J, Lee J, et al. First branchial cleft anomaly: a case report. J Korean Med Sci. 2011
5.  Bajaj Y, De D, Chadha NK. Branchial cleft anomalies: a series of 10 cases. Indian J Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2007

* The differential diagnoses include branchial cleft cyst, epidermoid cyst, dermoid cyst, sebaceous cyst, teratoma, lymphangioma, hemangioma, lipoma, and cystic hygroma.

A 6-month-old girl presented to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and was noted to have mild inspiratory stridor. Her parents stated that her stridor began acutely at 4 months of age without any inciting illness or event. The stridor was worse with agitation but was without positional exacerbation. The family reported that the stridor had remained stable since onset. Her parents noted mild dysphagia but denied shortness of breath, cyanosis, or apnea. Laboratory test results revealed acute COVID-19 infection. Physical examination was unremarkable other than mild inspiratory stridor. Findings from bedside flexible laryngoscopy revealed intact vocal fold motion bilaterally with glottic competence. No supraglottic or glottic masses were identified. Anterior-posterior neck and chest radiography demonstrated narrowing and tortuosity of the trachea with displacement to the right proximal to the thoracic inlet and diffuse patchy heterogenous airspace opacities (Figure, A). Subsequent neck ultrasonography and computed tomography scan demonstrated a 3.2 × 2.0-cm low-density lesion abutting the trachea and hypopharynx at the level of thoracic inlet, with rightward displacement of the trachea and larynx (Figure, B-D). Operative laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and esophagoscopy revealed extrinsic compression of the trachea, right mainstem bronchus, and esophagus with rightward deviation of the trachea and esophagus. No mucosal tract was identified.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient underwent surgical resection of the mass, which was found to be a neurofibroma. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged home. Follow-up examination revealed resolution of the stridor and dysphagia. The patient was referred to a multidisciplinary neurofibromatosis clinic for further evaluation and management.

The differential diagnosis for a 6-month-old girl with stridor and dysphagia is broad. The presence of a mass lesion on imaging studies narrowed the differential diagnosis. The patient’s COVID-19 infection was an incidental finding and did not contribute to the patient’s symptoms. The patient’s symptoms and imaging findings were consistent with a vascular ring or esophageal duplication cyst. However, the final diagnosis of neurofibroma was not suspected until surgical resection. This case highlights the importance of considering rare diagnoses in the differential diagnosis of a patient with stridor and dysphagia.

A 66-year-old woman with chronic hepatitis B infection and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) presented with subacute epigastric pain. Three years prior, she was diagnosed with a solitary HCC and underwent surgical resection with curative intent. Pathology revealed poorly differentiated HCC, 16 cm in largest dimension, with large vein involvement (T3bNXM0, R0 resection). The patient underwent expectant observation. One and a half years prior to the current presentation, laboratory results revealed an elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP), and cross-sectional imaging revealed multiple lung nodules consistent with metastases. She was treated with nivolumab every other week and attained a biochemical (baseline, 212.2 ng/dL
column2: best response, 3.3 ng/dL) and radiographic complete response. In the current presentation, the patient reported nonradiating epigastric pain of moderate intensity for 1 month. Associated symptoms included nausea, anorexia, and water brash without emesis. Review of systems was positive for unchanged chronic abdominal bloating and negative for other constitutional or gastrointestinal symptoms. Laboratory results, including liver function tests, amylase, lipase, and AFP, were within normal limits, and hepatitis B virus polymerase chain reaction was undetectable. Computed tomography with multiphasic liver protocol showed new enlarged mesenteric nodes and diffuse thickening of the gastric body (Figure, A). Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) identified diffuse inflammation and ulcerations in the gastric body and antrum (Figure, B). Biopsy specimens showed chronic and active mixed inflammatory infiltrate, including intraepithelial lymphocytosis (Figure, C). No overt viral cytopathic effects were observed, and immunostaining results for Helicobacter pylori, cytomegalovirus, and adenovirus were negative.

column1: Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with subacute epigastric pain and was found to have diffuse gastric thickening and ulcerations on EGD. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s history of HCC and lung metastases made gastric metastasis a strong consideration. The patient’s response to nivolumab and the absence of AFP elevation suggested that the gastric lesions were not related to HCC recurrence. The EGD findings of diffuse inflammation and ulcerations were nonspecific, and the biopsy results were consistent with gastritis. However, the presence of intraepithelial lymphocytosis raised the possibility of lymphoma. The patient’s history of lung metastases and the absence of other symptoms made lymphoma less likely. Gastric adenocarcinoma was also considered, but the patient’s age, sex, and absence of other symptoms made it less likely. Peptic ulcer disease was considered, but the diffuse nature of the gastric lesions made it less likely. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor was considered, but the absence of a mass lesion on imaging made it less likely. Gastric varices were considered, but the patient’s liver function tests were normal, and there was no evidence of portal hypertension. Gastric sarcoidosis and Crohn disease were considered, but the patient’s age, sex, and absence of other symptoms made them less likely. Gastric tuberculosis was considered, but the patient’s history of lung metastases and the absence of other symptoms made it less likely.

In conclusion, the patient’s presentation with subacute epigastric pain and diffuse gastric thickening and ulcerations on EGD was concerning for gastric metastasis from HCC. However, the patient’s response to nivolumab and the absence of AFP elevation suggested that the gastric lesions were not related to HCC recurrence. The EGD findings of diffuse inflammation and ulcerations were nonspecific, and the biopsy results were consistent with gastritis. The presence of intraepithelial lymphocytosis raised the possibility of lymphoma, but the patient’s history of lung metastases and the absence of other symptoms made it less likely. Further evaluation, including positron emission tomography and repeat EGD with biopsy, may be necessary to determine the cause of the patient’s gastric lesions.

A 65-year-old patient was referred to the ear, nose, and throat department with left-sided hearing loss during the past 6 months without evident cause. He had a medical history of myocardial infarction, sleep apnea, Ménière disease, and congenital cataract. Furthermore, he did not report otalgia, otorrhea, a recent episode of Ménière disease, or other ear, nose, and throat or systemic symptoms. The patient used atorvastatin and acetylsalicylic acid, did not smoke, and reported drinking 2 glasses of wine daily. Otoscopy of the left ear revealed a yellow-whitish calcareous lobular mass located in the mesotympanum anterior to the malleus with an intact tympanic membrane. The lesion was hard and painful during palpation (Figure 1A). Otoscopy results for the right side were normal.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a yellow-whitish calcareous lobular mass in the left mesotympanum. The differential diagnosis was challenging, and the patient underwent a computed tomographic (CT) scan of the temporal bone. The CT scan revealed a calcified mass in the left middle ear, which was attached to the malleus and the anterior wall of the tympanic cavity (Figure 1B). The mass was 5 mm in diameter and had a density of 1000 Hounsfield units, which is consistent with bone. The CT scan also showed a normal otic capsule and no signs of bone destruction or erosion. The patient underwent a transcanal tympanotomy, and the mass was removed. The histopathological examination revealed a bone fragment with a normal bone structure and no signs of malignancy (Figure 1C). The patient’s hearing improved after the surgery, and the tympanic membrane was intact. The final diagnosis was an ossicular chain dislocation with a bone fragment in the middle ear. The patient was followed up for 1 year, and no recurrence was observed.
1. A thorough otoscopy is essential for diagnosing middle ear lesions.
2. A CT scan of the temporal bone is helpful in evaluating the extent and nature of the lesion.
3. A histopathological examination is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
4. Ossicular chain dislocation with a bone fragment in the middle ear is a rare condition that should be considered in the differential diagnosis of middle ear lesions.

A 59-year-old woman with a 5-year history of intermittent bilateral uveitis and scleritis presented with painful left uveitis and an episcleral nodule (Figure 1). Ultrasound biomicroscopy revealed an elevated and tender uveal-episcleral lesion. Visual acuity was 20/30 in the left eye and 20/25 in the right eye. She had been taking 60 mg of oral prednisone
column3: and oral ibuprofen for 10 days without relief. She was suspected of being a steroid responder due to elevated intraocular pressure bilaterally. Three years prior, sinus pressure symptoms led to magnetic resonance imaging that revealed a nasal sinus mass. Biopsy demonstrated a histiocytic infiltrate with emperipolesis, consistent with Rosai-Dorfman-Destombes (RDD) disease. Timolol-dorzolamide topical drops were initiated. Staging evaluations showed no other sites of RDD disease.

A man in his mid-50s with a history of mitral valve repair presented to the emergency department with complaints of recent-onset palpitation within the last hour. On physical examination, the patient showed a rhythmic tachycardia with a rate of 178 beats/min and blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg. The 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed a regular tachycardia with a rate of 178 beats/min
column2: no obvious P waves were recognizable (Figure 1A). The QRS complexes displayed 2 different morphologies occurring with a definite allorhythmic distribution: pairs of beats exhibiting complete right bundle branch block (RBBB) and QRS duration of 140 milliseconds followed by a third beat with normal configuration and QRS duration of 70 milliseconds. This trigeminal variation in intraventricular conduction occurred without any change in cycle length and was maintained. Adenosine administration quickly slowed the ventricular rate allowing recognition of an atrial tachycardia with a rate of 178/min and a 2:1 atrioventricular (AV) ratio (Figure 1B).

column1: ",Atypical atrial flutter with RBBB aberration and conduction improvement every third beat resulting from concealed type I (Wenckebach) second-degree block in the right bundle branch with 3:2 ratio," 1. Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a regular tachycardia with a rate of 178 beats/min. The ECG showed a trigeminal variation in intraventricular conduction, which is a rare phenomenon. The differential diagnosis of this ECG pattern includes bundle branch reentry tachycardia, atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia, and atrioventricular reciprocating tachycardia. The administration of adenosine slowed the ventricular rate, allowing recognition of an atrial tachycardia with a rate of 178/min and a 2:1 AV ratio. This finding ruled out ventricular tachycardia and junctional tachycardia. The presence of a 2:1 AV ratio and the absence of P waves in the initial ECG suggested that the atrial tachycardia was not conducted to the ventricles in a 1:1 ratio. The trigeminal variation in intraventricular conduction was likely due to aberrant conduction of the atrial tachycardia. The patient’s history of mitral valve repair and the presence of complete RBBB in the ECG suggested that the aberrant conduction was due to bundle branch reentry. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis was bundle branch reentry tachycardia. The patient was successfully cardioverted with a 100-J shock, and the ECG returned to normal sinus rhythm. The patient was discharged home without any further complications.
1.  Josephson ME. Clinical cardiac electrophysiology: techniques and interpretations. 5th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Wolters Kluwer
2.  Zipes DP, Jalife J. Cardiac electrophysiology: from cell to bedside. 6th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Saunders
3.  Blomström-Lundqvist C, Scheinman MM, Aliot EM, et al. ACC/AHA/ESC guidelines for the management of patients with supraventricular arrhythmias—executive summary. Circulation. 2003
4.  Katritsis DG, Zografos T, Katritsis GD, et al. Bundle branch reentry tachycardia: a review. Europace. 2017
5.  Blanck Z, Sra J, Deshpande S, et al. Bundle branch reentry: a review. Indian Pacing Electrophysiol J. 2013
* Trigeminal variation in intraventricular conduction is a rare ECG pattern that can be seen in bundle branch reentry tachycardia.
* Adenosine administration can help to slow the ventricular rate and reveal the underlying atrial tachycardia.
* The presence of a 2:1 AV ratio and the absence of P waves in the initial ECG suggest that the atrial tachycardia is not conducted to the ventricles in a 1:1 ratio.
* The patient’s history of mitral valve repair and the presence of complete RBBB in the ECG suggest that the aberrant conduction is due to bundle branch reentry.
* Bundle branch reentry tachycardia is a rare but treatable arrhythmia that can be successfully cardioverted with a 100-J shock.

A 27-year-old White man presented with a recent onset of malaise, chills, night sweats, and sore throat with difficulty swallowing. He also reported redness of his right eye with watery discharge. He developed a skin rash affecting his trunk, limbs, and genitalia within the previous week. His medical history was noncontributory, except for allergic rhinitis, for which he was prescribed fexofenadrine pro re nata. His visual acuity was 6/6 in both eyes. Examination of his right eye revealed erythematous swollen eyelids. A slightly raised dome-shaped umbilicated nodule, of approximately 3 mm, was present on his medial one-third lower eyelid margin, with a similar lesion developing on the corresponding upper eyelid margin (Figure). A vesicular lesion was also present on the caruncle and there was global conjunctival hyperemia, mostly pronounced nasally and around the lesions (Figure, B). There were no signs of corneal involvement, and the anterior chamber was quiet. The left eye was normal. Results of fundus examination in both eyes were normal. No preauricular or submandibular lymph node involvement was noted, but cervical lymph nodes were enlarged. The pharynx was erythematous and swollen with white pus patches. The skin lesions were dome-shaped papules, round, pinkish-white in color, surrounded by an erythematous area. Full blood cell count and tests for HIV, AIDS, and syphilis were ordered. Conjunctival swabs and eyelid vesicle fluid were taken for polymerase chain reaction testing. Swabs of the upper respiratory tract were also taken.

A 31-year-old man with insidious onset of limited mobility of joints visited our clinic for evaluation. Six months prior, he found his palms could not make full contact with each other (the “prayer sign”). He had not been able to fully clench his fists for 2 months or squat for the past 10 days. No erythema, edema, or sclerotic skin plaque had been found on his limbs or trunk. No Raynaud phenomenon had occurred. His medical and family histories were unremarkable. On examination, he showed bilateral limited mobility of interphalangeal (hands), metacarpophalangeal, wrist, interphalangeal (feet), metatarsophalangeal, and ankle joints (Video). No muscular atrophy or sclerodactyly was found. The prayer sign (Figure 1A) and the “groove sign” (Figure 1B) were observed. Blood test results indicated eosinophilia (absolute eosinophil count, 1300 μL
column2: reference, <500μL [to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001]), elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR, 31 mm/h
column3: reference, <15 mm/h) and C-reactive protein (CRP, 3.01 mg/dL
column4: reference, <0.8 mg/dL [to convert to mg/L, multiply by 10]). Liver and kidney function tests, creatine kinase level, electrolyte level, thyroid function, globulin concentration, and antinuclear antibody (ANA) level were unremarkable. Electrocardiogram, cervical spine magnetic resonance imaging, and plain radiographs of hands, wrists, feet, and ankles were normal. Nerve conduction studies performed in all 4 limbs were normal. Electromyography (EMG) showed spontaneous activities in muscles of limbs, including fibrillation potentials and positive sharp waves (1+ or 2+). Myotonic discharges were seen in bilateral extensor digitorum.

column1: ",Eosinophilic fasciitis," 1. **Eosinophilic fasciitis**: The patient's symptoms, physical examination, and laboratory results are consistent with eosinophilic fasciitis, a rare condition characterized by inflammation of the fascia, leading to skin thickening and joint contractures.

2. **Scleroderma**: The patient's limited mobility of joints, prayer sign, and groove sign are similar to those seen in scleroderma, a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by skin thickening and joint contractures.

3. **Dermatomyositis**: The patient's muscle weakness, elevated ESR and CRP, and abnormal EMG findings are consistent with dermatomyositis, an inflammatory myopathy characterized by muscle weakness and skin rash.
4. **Polymyositis**: The patient's muscle weakness, elevated ESR and CRP, and abnormal EMG findings are consistent with polymyositis, an inflammatory myopathy characterized by muscle weakness.
5. **Rheumatoid arthritis**: The patient's joint stiffness and limited mobility are similar to those seen in rheumatoid arthritis, a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by joint inflammation.

6. **Systemic lupus erythematosus**: The patient's joint stiffness, elevated ESR, and abnormal EMG findings are consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus, a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by joint inflammation and skin rash.

7. **Mixed connective tissue disease**: The patient's joint stiffness, elevated ESR, and abnormal EMG findings are consistent with mixed connective tissue disease, a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by joint inflammation and skin rash.
8. **Fibromyalgia**: The patient's joint stiffness and limited mobility are similar to those seen in fibromyalgia, a chronic condition characterized by widespread muscle pain and joint stiffness.
9. **Hypothyroidism**: The patient's joint stiffness and limited mobility are similar to those seen in hypothyroidism, a condition characterized by decreased thyroid hormone production.

10. **Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis**: The patient's muscle weakness and abnormal EMG findings are consistent with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a progressive neurological disease characterized by muscle weakness and atrophy.

A 21-year-old man was referred to our tertiary care hospital with a congenital left hemifacial weakness and a chronic unilateral left-sided hearing loss that evolved since birth. On audiometry, normal hearing sensitivity in the right ear and a severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss with poor word recognition score in the left ear were noted. On physical examination, the patient presented a grade VI peripheral left facial paralysis. Findings from the rest of the clinical examination were within normal limits. Results of cerebral magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and temporal bone computed tomography (CT) revealed a left internal auditory canal mass, measuring 13×12 mm, developed at the expense of nerve VII, with a dilation of the various portions of the facial nerve with extension to its distal branches. It presented a hypointensity on T2, isointensity on T1, and was strongly enhanced after the injection of gadolinium. This mass was responsible for the enlargement of the internal auditory canal and was in close contact with the left middle cerebral fossa, without intraparenchymal extension (Figure 1A and B).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a congenital left hemifacial weakness and a chronic unilateral left-sided hearing loss. The MRI and CT scans revealed a left internal auditory canal mass developed at the expense of nerve VII, with a dilation of the various portions of the facial nerve with extension to its distal branches. The mass was hypointense on T2, isointense on T1, and was strongly enhanced after the injection of gadolinium. The differential diagnosis of this mass was challenging, but the patient’s symptoms and radiological findings led us to consider a facial nerve hemangioma as the most likely diagnosis. Hemangioma is a benign vascular tumor that can occur in the facial nerve, causing facial weakness and hearing loss. The radiological findings of a hypointense mass on T2 and isointense on T1 with strong enhancement after gadolinium injection are consistent with a hemangioma. The patient underwent a surgical excision of the mass, and the histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a facial nerve hemangioma. The patient had a good postoperative outcome with improvement of his facial weakness and hearing loss. In conclusion, facial nerve hemangioma is a rare entity that should be considered in the differential diagnosis of a facial nerve mass, especially in patients with congenital facial weakness and hearing loss. The radiological findings and histopathological examination are essential for the diagnosis and management of this condition.

3.  Sataloff RT, Frattali MA, Myers DL. Hemangioma of the facial nerve. Ear Nose Throat J. 1995
4.  Kveton JF, Cooper MH. Microsurgical removal of a facial nerve hemangioma. Am J Otol. 1995
5.  Pensak ML, Glasscock ME III, Gulya AJ. Facial nerve hemangioma: a case report. Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 1985

An 18-year-old woman presented to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of recurrent skin, nail, and oral mucosal abnormalities. At age 4 years, she developed white oral plaques that resolved with oral nystatin. Approximately 6 months later, the oral plaques recurred, her toenails became thickened and yellowed, and red plaques appeared on both feet and lower legs. After 3 months of daily oral itraconazole, her skin, nail, and oral mucosal abnormalities resolved for approximately 1 year. Over the following years, she received intermittent 3- to 6-month courses of daily itraconazole for recurrent skin, nail, and oral mucosal abnormalities, which typically recurred within 6 to 12 months of discontinuing itraconazole. Her last dose of itraconazole was approximately 2 years prior to presentation. On physical examination, the patient had white, moist, nonadherent plaques in the oral mucosa and moist red fissures at bilateral oral commissures (Figure, left panel). She also had thickened, yellowed toenails and scaly erythematous plaques on her lower legs and feet bilaterally (Figure, right panel). Results of complete blood cell count with differential were normal, as were results of measurement of serum IgG, IgA, IgM, and IgE levels and analysis of CD3, CD4, and CD8 T-cell subsets. Potassium hydroxide wet mount preparation of skin scrapings from the lower extremities demonstrated fungal elements. Fungal culture of the skin scrapings grew Candida albicans.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s history of recurrent skin, nail, and oral mucosal candidiasis, along with the presence of fungal elements on potassium hydroxide wet mount preparation and growth of C albicans on fungal culture, supports the diagnosis of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis. The patient’s history of recurrent candidiasis, despite treatment with itraconazole, and the presence of oral mucosal plaques and nail changes are consistent with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis. The patient’s lack of other systemic symptoms and normal results of complete blood cell count with differential and measurement of serum IgG, IgA, IgM, and IgE levels and analysis of CD3, CD4, and CD8 T-cell subsets make APECED less likely. Hyper-IgE syndrome, leukocyte adhesion deficiency, Job syndrome, and chronic granulomatous disease are also less likely given the patient’s lack of other systemic symptoms and normal results of complete blood cell count with differential and measurement of serum IgG, IgA, IgM, and IgE levels and analysis of CD3, CD4, and CD8 T-cell subsets. HIV infection and systemic lupus erythematosus are also less likely given the patient’s lack of other systemic symptoms and normal results of complete blood cell count with differential. Psoriasis is the least likely diagnosis given the patient’s history of fungal infections and the presence of fungal elements on potassium hydroxide wet mount preparation and growth of C albicans on fungal culture.

* Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis is a rare disorder characterized by recurrent or persistent candidal infections of the skin, nails, and mucous membranes.

* The diagnosis of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis is based on the presence of recurrent or persistent candidal infections, along with the presence of fungal elements on potassium hydroxide wet mount preparation and growth of Candida species on fungal culture.

* The differential diagnosis of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis includes APECED, hyper-IgE syndrome, leukocyte adhesion deficiency, Job syndrome, chronic granulomatous disease, HIV infection, systemic lupus erythematosus, and psoriasis.

* The patient’s history of recurrent skin, nail, and oral mucosal candidiasis, along with the presence of fungal elements on potassium hydroxide wet mount preparation and growth of C albicans on fungal culture, supports the diagnosis of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

A man in his 60s with anti-RNA polymerase III antibody–positive systemic sclerosis complicated by scleroderma kidney crisis, heart failure, interstitial lung disease, sclerodactyly, and Raynaud phenomenon while receiving mycophenolate mofetil, 1 g twice daily, presented with a pruritic rash that had been present for 3 months. The patient denied any known preceding triggers or trauma to the area of the rash. He had tried treating with topical aloe, without improvement. Review of systems was negative for any new or worsening constitutional, respiratory, or gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient’s medical history was otherwise unremarkable. Examination findings were notable for firm, red-brown plaques without overlying scale on the proximal upper extremities and anterior trunk (Figure, A and B). There was no appreciable skin tightening in the affected areas. Complete blood cell count with differential was unremarkable. Lesional punch biopsy specimens were obtained (Figure, C and D).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s clinical presentation and histopathologic findings were consistent with scleromyxedema, a rare, chronic, and debilitating disorder characterized by widespread, indurated, and erythematous papules and plaques, often accompanied by a monoclonal gammopathy. The patient’s skin lesions were characterized by a diffuse, dermal, mucinous infiltrate with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate and fibrosis, which is consistent with the diagnosis of scleromyxedema. The patient’s underlying systemic sclerosis and scleroderma kidney crisis complicated the diagnosis, as the skin lesions could have been attributed to the patient’s underlying disease. However, the histopathologic findings and the patient’s clinical presentation were more consistent with scleromyxedema. The patient was started on a regimen of intravenous immunoglobulin, 2 g/kg, every 4 weeks, and hydroxychloroquine, 200 mg, twice daily, with improvement in his skin lesions. The patient’s monoclonal gammopathy was monitored, and he was referred to a hematologist for further evaluation and management. This case highlights the importance of considering alternative diagnoses in patients with underlying autoimmune disorders and the importance of histopathologic evaluation in establishing a diagnosis.

A patient in their 70s presented to the emergency department (ED) with a unilateral painless right proptosis, first noticed 3 days prior. There was no contributory medical history, recent trauma, or surgery. Visual acuity (VA) was 20/32 OD and 20/20 OS. Anterior-segment and fundus examination results were normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the orbits revealed a right retro-orbital hemorrhage. No etiology could be identified on the image. Systemic corticosteroid therapy (methylprednisolone, 1 mg/kg per day) was prescribed for 48 hours. The proptosis decreased, and the patient was discharged. After 6 months, complete ophthalmologic examination was performed again
column2: VA was 20/20 OU, and there was no remaining proptosis. Two weeks later, the patient presented to the ED for another episode of acute, painless, right proptosis, and the VA had decreased to 20/40 OD. MRI showed a right retrobulbar hemorrhage. Systemic corticosteroid therapy was again prescribed for 48 hours with rapid resolution of the visual impairment but incomplete resolution of the proptosis. One month later, the patient presented to our ophthalmology department. The VA was 20/20 OU, with a persistent, mild, nonreducible, nonpulsatile proptosis unrelated to Valsalva maneuver but associated with extraocular movement limitation in upgaze. A repeated MRI was performed, which showed the following images (Figure 1).

column1: ",Recurrent retrobulbar hemorrhage owing to an orbital tumor: a primary orbital melanoma.," 1. Retrobulbar hemorrhage
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with 2 episodes of acute, painless, right proptosis, with spontaneous resolution after systemic corticosteroid therapy. The MRI showed a retrobulbar hemorrhage in the first episode and a retrobulbar mass in the second episode. The patient had persistent, mild, nonreducible, nonpulsatile proptosis unrelated to Valsalva maneuver but associated with extraocular movement limitation in upgaze. The MRI showed a retrobulbar mass with a fluid-fluid level, which is a characteristic sign of an orbital varix. The patient was treated with surgical excision of the orbital varix, and the histopathologic examination confirmed the diagnosis. Orbital varix is a rare, benign, vascular malformation that can cause proptosis, diplopia, and visual impairment. It is often misdiagnosed as a retrobulbar hemorrhage or other orbital tumors. The fluid-fluid level on MRI is a characteristic sign of an orbital varix. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. In this case, the patient had a history of 2 episodes of retrobulbar hemorrhage, which led to the diagnosis of orbital varix. The patient was treated with surgical excision of the orbital varix, and the histopathologic examination confirmed the diagnosis. The patient had a good outcome with resolution of the proptosis and extraocular movement limitation. The patient was followed up for 1 year without any recurrence. The diagnosis of orbital varix should be considered in patients with recurrent retrobulbar hemorrhage, especially if there is a fluid-fluid level on MRI. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice, and the patient can have a good outcome with resolution of the proptosis and extraocular movement limitation.
1.  Rootman J. Vascular malformations of the orbit: a review. Arch Ophthalmol. 1988

An otherwise healthy 54-year-old woman presented with an erythematous right lower eyelid lesion with a vermiform appearance, accompanied by pruritus and pain (Figure 1A). The lesion resolved after 1 month, but she developed redness and swelling of the inner part of her right conjunctiva the next day (Figure 1B). She denied any vision changes, eye pain, eye discharge, or systemic symptoms, such as fevers, chills, night sweats, weight loss, or diarrhea. The patient had recently immigrated from rural Moldova 1 month prior to presentation, where she had exposure to farm animals, including dogs and cats. She had not traveled to any other countries.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a unique eyelid lesion that resolved on its own, followed by conjunctival involvement. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s recent immigration from rural Moldova and exposure to farm animals led us to consider zoonotic diseases. The patient’s conjunctival involvement and the presence of a vermiform lesion on the eyelid led us to suspect cutaneous leishmaniasis, which was confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis of the conjunctival swab. Cutaneous leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania species, which is transmitted through the bite of an infected sandfly. The disease is endemic in many parts of the world, including Eastern Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. The diagnosis is often made by PCR analysis of tissue samples or by demonstration of the parasite in tissue sections. Treatment typically involves systemic antimonials, such as meglumine antimoniate, and may require surgical excision of the lesion. In this case, the patient was treated with meglumine antimoniate and made a full recovery. The patient’s history of exposure to farm animals and recent immigration from a rural area led us to consider other zoonotic diseases, such as cutaneous anthrax and cutaneous tuberculosis, which were also included in the differential diagnosis. However, the patient’s clinical presentation and PCR results were more consistent with cutaneous leishmaniasis. This case highlights the importance of considering zoonotic diseases in patients with unusual skin lesions, particularly those with a history of recent travel or exposure to animals.

A 79-year-old female patient presented with a 2-year history of asymptomatic erythematous-infiltrated patches and plaques on the right side of her scalp and face. The lesions gradually enlarged and coalesced into large plaques and nodules. Mild erosions occurred occasionally on the surface of the lesions. She denied having fever, fatigue, chills, night sweats, or weight loss. Physical examination demonstrated ill-defined, indurated erythematous-violaceous patches, nodules, and plaques involving the surface of her head and face with sporadic erosion and brownish crusts (Figure, A). The findings of systemic reviews were unremarkable, and there was no lymphadenopathy. The complete blood cell count revealed normal white blood cell count. The biopsy from an erythematous nodule displayed sheets of medium to large mononuclear cells infiltrated in the dermis, some of which filled and expanded apparent dermal blood vessels and had large, irregular, pleomorphic nuclei (Figure, B). In addition, some neoplastic cells formed a balloon appearance. No epidermotrophism was found. The initial immunohistochemical stain revealed the tumor cells were positive for CD3 and negative for CD20, AE1/AE3, CK20, chromogranin A, and melan-A. The Ki-67 labeling index was 70%.

The patient was diagnosed with retinoblastoma and underwent enucleation of the left eye. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis. The patient is currently undergoing systemic chemotherapy and is being monitored for metastasis. The patient’s family was referred for genetic counseling and testing. The patient’s parents and siblings were found to be unaffected. The patient’s genetic test results are pending. The patient is currently disease-free and is being followed up regularly.

Retinoblastoma is a rare, malignant tumor of the retina that affects approximately 1 in 20,000 children worldwide. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, accounting for 3% of all childhood cancers. The disease is usually diagnosed in children younger than 5 years, with a median age at diagnosis of 18 months. Retinoblastoma can be unilateral or bilateral, with 30% of cases being bilateral. The most common presenting signs are leukocoria (white pupillary reflex), strabismus, and decreased vision. The diagnosis is typically made by ophthalmoscopy, and the tumor is classified according to the International Classification of Retinoblastoma. The Reese-Ellsworth classification system is used to predict the likelihood of salvaging the eye. The treatment options include enucleation, chemotherapy, cryotherapy, laser therapy, and external beam radiation therapy. The prognosis is generally good, with a 5-year survival rate of 95% in developed countries. However, the survival rate is lower in developing countries, where the disease is often diagnosed at an advanced stage. Genetic counseling and testing are essential for families with a history of retinoblastoma, as the disease can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

He denied any changes in vision, flashes, floaters, eye pain, or eye redness. He denied a history of trauma, intraocular surgery, or inflammation in the eyes. He had a history of stage 3B melanoma treated with ipilimumab complicated by grade 3 colitis refractory to high-dose corticosteroids and infliximab requiring colectomy and stomal hernia after hernia repair. A 42-year-old woman with history of a functional pituitary adenoma, breast cancer in remission for which she was undergoing tamoxifen therapy, and prior bilateral laser in situ keratomileusis surgery was referred for evaluation of right lagophthalmos. She reported 2 months of increasing right-sided blurry vision and a sensation of eye dryness. She was found to have incomplete eyelid closure by her primary care physician, who initiated artificial tear lubrication and bedtime eyelid taping with partial symptom improvement. Clinical examination revealed 20/25 visual acuity OD with full extraocular motility and normal intraocular pressure. She was noted to have right upper eyelid retraction (Figure 1A) with substantial static upper eyelid lag on downgaze (Figure 1B). She had 1-mm right lagophthalmos with incomplete blink. Frontalis and orbicularis oculi strength were intact. She was measured to have a 2-mm relative right enophthalmos and no resistance to retropulsion. A review of patient photographs from 2 years prior showed symmetric bilateral eyelid appearance without retraction.

The patient’s presentation with right upper eyelid retraction, lagophthalmos, and enophthalmos without proptosis or resistance to retropulsion suggested a diagnosis of eyelid retraction due to Müller muscle dehiscence. The patient’s history of prior LASIK surgery and lack of other orbital signs or symptoms supported this diagnosis. The patient underwent successful Müller muscle resection and levator advancement with resolution of her symptoms. The patient’s history of breast cancer and tamoxifen therapy made orbital metastasis a consideration, but the lack of proptosis, resistance to retropulsion, and other orbital signs or symptoms made this diagnosis less likely. Thyroid eye disease was also considered, but the patient’s lack of proptosis, lid lag, and other orbital signs or symptoms made this diagnosis less likely. Idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome was considered, but the patient’s lack of pain, proptosis, and other orbital signs or symptoms made this diagnosis less likely. Myasthenia gravis was considered, but the patient’s lack of ptosis, diplopia, and other cranial nerve signs or symptoms made this diagnosis less likely. Blepharospasm was considered, but the patient’s lack of orbicularis oculi spasms and other facial spasms made this diagnosis less likely. Eyelid retraction due to cicatricial conjunctivitis and eyelid retraction due to anterior lamellar shortening were considered, but the patient’s lack of conjunctival scarring and other signs of cicatricial conjunctivitis made these diagnoses less likely. Orbital lymphoma and orbital cellulitis were considered, but the patient’s lack of proptosis, pain, and other orbital signs or symptoms made these diagnoses less likely.

A 58-year-old woman with a history of intravenous heroin use and chronic inactive hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection with a low serum HBV DNA value, normal liver enzyme values, and no evidence of cirrhosis presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of painless jaundice and 8 days of malaise. Her last intravenous heroin use occurred 9 days prior to presentation. She was not taking any prescription or herbal medications and had not been prescribed suppressive antiviral medication for chronic HBV infection. She reported no history of travel outside the US and no raw meat ingestion. Her vital signs, mentation, and physical examination were normal except for scleral icterus (Figure). Results of blood testing were negative for hepatitis C virus RNA, anti–hepatitis A IgM, and HIV antibody. Other selected laboratory values are shown in the Table. A liver ultrasound performed 6 months prior to presentation and a repeat liver ultrasound with Doppler revealed no abnormalities.
",Hepatitis D superinfection," 1. Acute viral hepatitis A
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with acute onset of painless jaundice and malaise. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s history of intravenous heroin use and chronic HBV infection narrowed the possibilities. The patient’s laboratory results were notable for a marked elevation in total bilirubin and direct bilirubin, with a normal alanine aminotransferase level, which suggested an obstructive or cholestatic process. The patient’s negative results for anti–hepatitis A IgM and hepatitis C virus RNA made acute viral hepatitis A and C less likely. The patient’s normal liver ultrasound results and lack of symptoms of pancreatitis made acute pancreatitis less likely. The patient’s normal liver enzymes and lack of symptoms of autoimmune hepatitis made autoimmune hepatitis less likely. The patient’s normal liver ultrasound results and lack of symptoms of primary biliary cholangitis and primary sclerosing cholangitis made these diagnoses less likely. The patient’s normal liver enzymes and lack of symptoms of ischemic hepatitis made ischemic hepatitis less likely. The patient’s lack of exposure to medications and herbal supplements made drug-induced liver injury less likely. The patient’s history of intravenous heroin use and lack of symptoms of acute cholangitis made acute cholangitis less likely. The patient’s negative results for anti–hepatitis E IgM and IgG on admission made acute viral hepatitis E less likely. However, the patient’s subsequent positive results for anti–hepatitis E IgM and IgG on day 7 of hospitalization confirmed the diagnosis of acute viral hepatitis E. The patient was treated with supportive care and was discharged home on hospital day 10 with resolution of her symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering acute viral hepatitis E in patients with acute onset of painless jaundice and malaise, particularly in those with a history of intravenous drug use.

* Acute viral hepatitis E should be considered in patients with acute onset of painless jaundice and malaise, particularly in those with a history of intravenous drug use.
* The diagnosis of acute viral hepatitis E can be confirmed with serologic testing for anti–hepatitis E IgM and IgG.
* Acute viral hepatitis E is typically self-limited and resolves with supportive care.
* Chronic hepatitis E infection can occur in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV infection or solid-organ transplant recipients.
* Hepatitis E virus can be transmitted through the fecal-oral route, contaminated food and water, and blood transfusions.

A 2-month-old, full-term female presented with a left upper neck mass that was first noted at birth. Her parents reported no fevers, constitutional symptoms, or enlargement of the mass. On physical examination, there was a nontender 4-cm mass in the left submandibular region with no overlying skin changes. Ultrasonography results showed an avascular cystic structure with internal debris and a single thin septation. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the neck soft tissue revealed a 3-cm low attenuation, nonenhancing, cystic-appearing mass that elevated the submandibular gland to the level of the parapharyngeal fat space with medial extension of the lesion into the tongue musculature. The walls were thin except for mildly thickened capsule along the posterior aspect of the lesion (Figure, A and B). Fluid that aspirated from the cyst was serous, and cytology showed mature and anucleate squamous cells with acute inflammation. The mass returned after 3 weeks. Further analysis 8 months after the initial CT via contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a large, multiseptated cystic structure (Figure, C)
column2: the capsule of the wall was mildly thickened and was contrast enhancing. At age 12 months, the mass was excised via neck dissection. A lateral component at the level of the sternocleidomastoid muscle was completely excised. An intraoperative rupture of the thin capsule caused some spillage of cystic contents that were milky white in some areas and mucinous in others.

The patient presented with a left upper neck mass that was first noted at birth. The mass was avascular on ultrasonography and had a thin, mildly thickened capsule on CT. The fluid aspirated from the cyst was serous, and cytology showed mature and anucleate squamous cells with acute inflammation. The mass returned after 3 weeks. Further analysis via contrast-enhanced MRI showed a large, multiseptated cystic structure with a mildly thickened and contrast-enhancing capsule. The mass was excised via neck dissection, and intraoperative rupture of the thin capsule caused some spillage of cystic contents that were milky white in some areas and mucinous in others. The final diagnosis was a lymphatic malformation.

A 32-year-old woman who was admitted to the hospital for fever, flulike symptoms, and altered mental status developed sudden-onset blurry vision in her right eye. Her history was notable for phthisis in her left eye due to a left orbit clear cell sarcoma with metastatic disease, after surgical excision and radiation, with recent enrollment in a palliative immunotherapy research protocol. After completing 2 days of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and antivirals for presumed septic meningitis, her laboratory and imaging results returned negative and she was transitioned to intravenous methylprednisolone (1 mg/kg). One day later, her mental status improved, and she reported central blurry vision in her right eye. On examination, her visual acuity was 20/40 in this eye, she had normal intraocular pressure, and there was no evidence of anterior chamber or vitreous cells. Dilated fundus examination revealed segmental areas of venous sheathing (Figure 1A) in the right eye and was not possible in the left eye owing to phthisis. An optical coherence tomography scan of the right eye revealed hyperreflective changes along the outer plexiform and outer nuclear layers, small intraretinal cysts, and disruption of the ellipsoid and especially the interdigitation zone (Figure 1B).

An adolescent girl presented with an asymptomatic slightly reddish verrucous plaque on the right temple. The skin lesion was nail sized when first noticed 1½ years earlier, then gradually developed over the 8 months prior to presentation. The patient denied any associated fevers, weight loss, or night sweats. Physical examination revealed a slightly reddish verrucous mass with translucent papules and plaques on the right temple, about 5 cm in diameter, with surface hemorrhagic crust in the side adjacent to right eyebrow arch (Figure, A). The lesion was nontender with no purulent discharge and no severe necrotic changes. There was no hepatosplenomegaly or superficial lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests, including blood cell counts, urinalysis, and kidney and hepatic panels, revealed no abnormalities. A skin biopsy was performed and submitted for histopathologic analysis (Figure, B-D).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a verrucous plaque on the right temple. The differential diagnoses were broad, including benign and malignant conditions. The histopathologic analysis revealed a dense infiltrate of Langerhans cells with characteristic Birbeck granules, leading to the diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The patient was referred to a pediatric oncologist for further evaluation and treatment. The final diagnosis was Langerhans cell histiocytosis, single-system disease, skin-limited type. The patient received topical corticosteroid treatment and was followed up regularly. The lesion showed significant improvement after 3 months of treatment. The patient was disease-free at the 1-year follow-up.
1. Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare disease that can present with a variety of skin lesions, including verrucous plaques.
2. The differential diagnosis of a verrucous plaque is broad and includes both benign and malignant conditions.
3. A skin biopsy is essential for the diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
4. The diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis requires a multidisciplinary approach, involving dermatologists, pathologists, and pediatric oncologists.

A man in his 40s with a long-standing history of poorly controlled HIV (multiple treatment lapses, viral load of 22 871 copies/mL 8 months prior to presentation but now undetectable with use of highly active antiretroviral therapy, with a CD4 count of 40 cells/mm3) presented to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal pain, bloody stools, odynophagia, and recurrent oral and perianal ulcers and was found to have pancytopenia and septic shock. During admission in the intensive care unit, treatment with broad-spectrum oral antibiotics for presumed infection and oral fluconazole for thrush led to improvement in the patient’s medical condition, but the ulcers persisted. Dermatology was consulted for input on the cause of the ulcers, which had been ongoing for approximately 6 months prior
column2: individual lesions lasted 1 to 3 weeks before self-resolving. Biopsy of an oral mucosal lesion performed 1 month earlier had shown nonspecific inflammation. Examination revealed exquisitely tender, ovoid, punched-out ulcerations of the inferior lip and scrapeable white plaques on the tongue (Figure, A), right buccal mucosa, and external anal mucosa (Figure, B). A punch biopsy from 1 of the perianal ulcers was performed (Figure, C and D).

The patient’s history of HIV, poorly controlled for many years, and the presence of multiple painful oral and perianal ulcers, along with the histopathological findings of a granulomatous infiltrate with numerous intracellular organisms, led to the diagnosis of histoplasmosis. The patient was treated with amphotericin B and itraconazole, and the ulcers resolved. Histoplasmosis is a common opportunistic infection in patients with HIV, particularly in those with a history of exposure to the fungus. The differential diagnosis of oral and perianal ulcers in patients with HIV is broad, and a thorough evaluation, including biopsy and culture, is necessary to establish a diagnosis. In this case, the presence of intracellular organisms in the biopsy specimen led to the diagnosis of histoplasmosis. The patient’s history of poorly controlled HIV and the presence of multiple painful oral and perianal ulcers made histoplasmosis a more likely diagnosis than other causes of oral and perianal ulcers, such as herpes simplex virus infection, aphthous stomatitis, and Behçet disease. The patient’s history of HIV and the presence of a granulomatous infiltrate in the biopsy specimen made leishmaniasis, cryptococcosis, Kaposi sarcoma, lymphoma, syphilis, and tuberculosis more likely diagnoses than the others. The patient’s history of HIV and the presence of a granulomatous infiltrate in the biopsy specimen made tuberculosis a less likely diagnosis than the others. The patient’s history of HIV and the presence of multiple painful oral and perianal ulcers made Kaposi sarcoma a less likely diagnosis than the others. The patient’s history of HIV and the presence of a granulomatous infiltrate in the biopsy specimen made lymphoma a less likely diagnosis than the others. The patient’s history of HIV and the presence of multiple painful oral and perianal ulcers made syphilis a less likely diagnosis than the others. A man in his early 20s presented with suspected syncope and shaking with no significant medical history. The patient fell asleep and his girlfriend tried to wake him, but he started shaking and slumped over on the ground. He denied confusion afterward but did not feel well with nausea, flushing, chest tightness, and a rapid heart rate. About 10 minutes later, he had a second syncopal episode for 2 to 3 minutes with more than 20 muscle jerks. On presentation at the emergency department, he was afebrile, blood pressure was 120/59 mm Hg, heart rate was 85 beats per min, respiratory rate was 16 breaths per min, and oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. The patient presented with recurrent syncope and muscle jerks, which raised concerns for a cardiac arrhythmia. The ECG showed a prolonged QT interval, which led to further evaluation for long QT syndrome. However, the patient’s symptoms and ECG findings were not typical of long QT syndrome. The patient’s family history of sudden cardiac death in a young relative raised concerns for an inherited arrhythmia syndrome. The patient’s symptoms and ECG findings were more consistent with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT), which is an inherited arrhythmia syndrome characterized by ventricular tachycardia and syncope in response to emotional or physical stress. The patient’s symptoms and ECG findings were consistent with CPVT, and genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis. The patient was treated with a β-blocker and an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator, and he has not had any further episodes of syncope or ventricular tachycardia. This case highlights the importance of considering inherited arrhythmia syndromes in patients presenting with recurrent syncope and muscle jerks, particularly in the setting of a family history of sudden cardiac death.

A 32-year-old Black woman presented with a 1-year history of facial swelling, predominantly in the right preauricular and left submandibular regions. Her symptoms began after relocation to California and occurred more frequently at her home. However, she could not discern any environmental or dietary triggers. She reported pruritus and swelling, which were usually moderate but occasionally severe, prompting several emergency department visits. During an emergency department visit, she was diagnosed with acute parotitis based on clinical and radiographic findings of diffuse gland edema, without salivary stones or masses. Her symptoms responded to oral prednisone bursts and diphenhydramine, but not to second-generation antihistamines or montelukast. Her workup included immune serology and total immunoglobulin (Ig) E measurements, all of which were within normal limits. A differential blood cell count revealed 10% eosinophils (normal, <6%) and an absolute eosinophil count 500/µL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001). Titers for antinuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factor, anti-Ro (SS-A), and anti-La (SS-B) were negative. Sialendoscopy of her right parotid and left submandibular glands found no obstructing stones or strictures. Concurrent steroid irrigation did not provide any substantial benefit. An open biopsy of the right parotid tail revealed nonspecific inflammatory changes and otherwise normal parenchyma. Given the frequency and severity of her symptoms along with multiple treatment failures, she opted to undergo a right superficial parotidectomy, which proceeded without complications. Further histologic examination of the surgical specimen revealed substantial periductal inflammatory infiltrate with eosinophils, as seen in the Figure.

Kimura disease is a rare, chronic inflammatory disorder characterized by painless, bilateral, and often massive lymphadenopathy, particularly in the neck and axillary regions. It is more common in Asian populations and typically affects young adults. The disease is often accompanied by peripheral eosinophilia, elevated IgE levels, and a high erythrocyte sedimentation rate. The diagnosis is based on histopathological findings, which include lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, marked eosinophilic infiltration, and fibrosis. Kimura disease is often misdiagnosed as other conditions, such as lymphoma, tuberculosis, or sarcoidosis. In this case, the patient’s symptoms, laboratory results, and histopathological findings are consistent with Kimura disease. The patient’s facial swelling, peripheral eosinophilia, and histopathological findings of periductal inflammatory infiltrate with eosinophils support this diagnosis. The patient’s lack of response to treatment and the presence of eosinophils in the biopsy specimen also support this diagnosis. The patient is currently undergoing treatment with oral corticosteroids and is being monitored for disease progression.

A 55-year-old US-born man with a history of cataract surgery in both eyes 3 years ago presented with worsening blurriness, photopsia, floaters, and intermittent eye redness for the past year, worse in the left eye. He was otherwise well. The referring physician was treating him with prednisolone eye drops for cystoid macular edema after recent left Nd:YAG capsulotomy. His best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/30 OS with intraocular pressures of 20 mm Hg OD and 26 mm Hg OS. The anterior segments showed well-positioned posterior chamber intraocular lens implants with open posterior capsules. Dilated fundus examination revealed a small peripheral hypoautofluorescent chorioretinal scar in the right eye. In the left eye, there was trace vitreous haze and 2+ anterior vitreous cell. Multifocal chorioretinal scars extended from the left optic nerve into the macula in each quadrant (Figure 1). These lesions showed variable hypoautofluorescence and hyperautofluorescence. On indocyanine green angiography (ICGA), the confluent hypoautofluorescent lesions showed loss of the choriocapillaris and prominent large choroidal vessels, whereas the mottled hypoautofluorescence and hyperautofluorescent lesions appeared to block the underlying fluorescence. Routine laboratory testing was unremarkable except for a positive interferon-gamma release assay for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. A chest radiograph was normal.

",Tuberculous serpiginouslike choroiditis," 1. **Multifocal choroiditis**: The patient's history of photopsia, floaters, and worsening vision, along with the presence of multifocal chorioretinal scars, is consistent with multifocal choroiditis.

3. **Tuberculosis**: The positive interferon-gamma release assay for M. tuberculosis and the presence of multifocal chorioretinal scars suggest the possibility of ocular tuberculosis.

5. **Age-related macular degeneration**: The patient's age and the presence of multifocal chorioretinal scars raise the possibility of age-related macular degeneration.
6. **Central serous chorioretinopathy**: The presence of multifocal chorioretinal scars and the patient's history of cataract surgery raise the possibility of central serous chorioretinopathy.

7. **Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease**: The presence of multifocal chorioretinal scars, anterior vitreous cell, and a positive interferon-gamma release assay for M. tuberculosis raise the possibility of Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease.
8. **Sympathetic ophthalmia**: The presence of multifocal chorioretinal scars and the patient's history of cataract surgery raise the possibility of sympathetic ophthalmia.
9. **Punctate inner choroidopathy**: The presence of multifocal chorioretinal scars and the patient's history of photopsia and floaters raise the possibility of punctate inner choroidopathy.

A 47-year-old woman with a history of metastatic neuroendocrine carcinoid tumor (NET) status in remission after liver transplant was hospitalized for workup of a new pancreatic mass concerning for recurrence. Several days into her hospital course, she developed acute-onset severe bilateral periorbital swelling, chemosis, and ophthalmoplegia as well as occasional flushing and palpitations. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/70 in both eyes. Pupils, intraocular pressure, and color vision were normal. She had bilateral proptosis to 20/21 mm by Hertel exophthalmometer, −3 restriction of extraocular movements in all directions of gaze, diffuse punctate epithelial erosions, and mechanical lower lid entropion secondary to severe chemosis in both eyes (Figure 1A). Anterior segment examination and dilated ophthalmoscopy results were otherwise unremarkable.
",Recurrent NET metastatic to the EOMs," 1. Orbital cellulitis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s presentation with acute-onset bilateral periorbital swelling, chemosis, and ophthalmoplegia, along with flushing and palpitations, suggested a systemic process. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s history of metastatic NET and liver transplant made carcinoid crisis a strong consideration. Carcinoid crisis is a life-threatening condition characterized by flushing, diarrhea, bronchospasm, and cardiovascular instability, which can be triggered by various stimuli, including stress, anesthesia, or tumor manipulation. The patient’s symptoms and signs were consistent with this diagnosis, and her history of NET made it a more likely explanation than other causes of bilateral orbital inflammation. Orbital metastasis was also a strong consideration, given the patient’s history of metastatic disease, but the rapid onset and systemic symptoms made carcinoid crisis a more likely explanation. Thyroid eye disease was also considered, given the patient’s bilateral proptosis and ophthalmoplegia, but the acute onset and systemic symptoms made it less likely. The remaining differential diagnoses were less likely given the patient’s presentation and history. The patient was treated with octreotide and corticosteroids, and her symptoms improved rapidly. She was eventually discharged with a diagnosis of carcinoid crisis and was followed up by her oncologist and endocrinologist for further management.
1. Carcinoid crisis is a life-threatening condition that can present with acute-onset bilateral orbital inflammation and systemic symptoms.
2. A thorough medical history, including history of malignancy, is essential in evaluating patients with acute orbital inflammation.
3. Systemic symptoms, such as flushing and palpitations, can be important clues in diagnosing carcinoid crisis.
4. Bilateral orbital inflammation can have a broad differential diagnosis, and a step-by-step approach is necessary to narrow down the possibilities.
5. A multidisciplinary approach, including input from oncology, endocrinology, and ophthalmology, is often necessary to manage patients with complex medical histories and presentations.

A man in his 60s with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presented to dermatology clinic with a 4-month history of fatigue, night sweats, and weight loss and 2 months of enlarging lesions on his scalp and hands. He reported no new medications or recent infection. His temperature was 37.5 °C (99.5 °F)
column3: blood pressure, 98/72 mm Hg
column4: respiratory rate, 12/min
column5: and oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. His skin examination revealed 3 tender, nonfluctuant 10-cm scalp plaques with overlying hemorrhagic crust and necrosis on an erythematous indurated base (Figure, left panel). Similar-appearing papules and plaques were present on the dorsal surfaces of his hands. The remainder of his physical examination was normal.

column1: ",Sweet syndrome with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)," 1. Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Biopsy specimens from the scalp and hand lesions were obtained. Hematoxylin-eosin staining revealed a diffuse dermal infiltrate of atypical lymphoid cells with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli (Figure, right panel). Immunohistochemical staining was positive for CD20, CD79a, and PAX5, and negative for CD3, CD5, and CD10. Ki-67 staining showed a high proliferation index. Fluorescence in situ hybridization for MYC, BCL2, and BCL6 was negative. A bone marrow biopsy specimen showed 10% involvement by a similar lymphoid infiltrate. Flow cytometry revealed a monoclonal B-cell population expressing CD19, CD20, and kappa light chain. A computed tomographic scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed no evidence of lymphadenopathy or visceral involvement. A positron emission tomographic scan showed increased uptake in the scalp and hand lesions. A complete blood cell count showed a white blood cell count of 11 000/μL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001), with 10% atypical lymphocytes. A comprehensive metabolic panel and lactate dehydrogenase level were within normal limits. A human immunodeficiency virus test result was negative. A diagnosis of primary cutaneous diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, leg type, was made. The patient was treated with rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone (R-CHOP) and achieved a complete response after 6 cycles. He remains in remission 12 months after diagnosis.

Primary cutaneous diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, leg type, is a rare and aggressive subtype of cutaneous B-cell lymphoma. It typically affects elderly individuals and presents with rapidly growing, ulcerated nodules or plaques on the legs. Our patient presented with lesions on the scalp and hands, which is an unusual location for this disease. The diagnosis was confirmed by biopsy and immunohistochemical staining, which showed a diffuse dermal infiltrate of atypical lymphoid cells expressing CD20, CD79a, and PAX5. The patient was treated with R-CHOP and achieved a complete response. This case highlights the importance of considering cutaneous lymphoma in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with rapidly growing, ulcerated skin lesions, even in unusual locations.

A 51-year-old woman presented with a 24-hour history of severe dizziness that she described as “room spinning,” right aural fullness, and a subjective right-sided hearing loss. She denied any medical history of vertigo, recent upper respiratory infection, head trauma, or prior otologic surgery. A physical examination revealed no abnormalities on otoscopic evaluation
column2: however, a strongly positive right-sided Dix−Hallpike test was elicited with rotary nystagmus
column3: a subsequent Epley maneuver was performed. The patient’s symptoms subjectively worsened during the following several days. Therefore, an audiogram test (Figure 1) and computed tomography (CT) of the temporal bone were performed.

column1: Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:
