column2: however, the audiogram test results and CT scan of the temporal bone revealed a dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal, which is diagnostic of superior canal dehiscence syndrome. This diagnosis was confirmed by a subsequent surgical exploration. The patient underwent a middle fossa craniotomy and canal plugging, which resulted in resolution of her symptoms. The patient provided written informed consent for publication of this case report.

column1: Superior canal dehiscence syndrome is a rare condition characterized by a dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal, which can cause vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. The diagnosis is often delayed because of the nonspecific nature of the symptoms and the lack of awareness of this condition among clinicians. The Dix−Hallpike test is often positive in patients with superior canal dehiscence syndrome, which can lead to an incorrect diagnosis of BPPV. The diagnosis is confirmed by a high-resolution CT scan of the temporal bone, which demonstrates a dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal. The treatment of superior canal dehiscence syndrome typically involves a middle fossa craniotomy and canal plugging, which can result in resolution of symptoms.

A 6-year-old boy with severe autism spectrum disorder (ASD) was brought to the hospital by his mother for whitening in the right eye. The patient was nonverbal at baseline and exhibited restrictive and repetitive behaviors. His diet consisted exclusively of cookies, apples, potato chips, and Gatorade. His mother noticed him frequently rubbing his eyes for several weeks, which she initially attributed to new-onset allergies. She did not describe any reduction in visual function or ability to perform low-luminance tasks. The patient was admitted and ophthalmology was consulted. He required an examination under sedation. His visual acuity could not be determined. There was no relative afferent pupillary defect in either eye. The eyelids were mildly erythematous with bilateral eyelash hypertrichosis. The conjunctiva and cornea appeared dry and leathery bilaterally. The right cornea was diffusely hazy with a 3-mm paracentral epithelial defect with 60% stromal thinning and a 1-mm infiltrate. There was a small crescentic fibrin deposit nasally in the right anterior chamber. The left cornea was diffusely hazy with a 1-mm epithelial defect without stromal thinning (Figure). Dilated examination showed bilateral grade 3 optic nerve head edema and otherwise normal retinal findings. Fortified vancomycin eye drops, 25 mg/mL, and tobramycin eye drops, 15 mg/mL, were initiated. Results of magnetic resonance imaging of the brain were normal.
",Xerophthalmia and keratomalacia from vitamin A deficiency," 1. Vitamin A deficiency
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s presentation with bilateral corneal haze, epithelial defects, and optic nerve head edema in the setting of severe autism and a highly restricted diet led us to suspect a nutritional deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency was the leading differential diagnosis given the patient’s diet and the presence of bilateral corneal haze and epithelial defects. The patient’s eyelash hypertrichosis and dry, leathery conjunctiva and cornea were also consistent with vitamin A deficiency. The patient’s optic nerve head edema was likely secondary to the corneal disease. The patient was treated with oral vitamin A and topical fortified vancomycin and tobramycin. His corneal haze and epithelial defects resolved, and his optic nerve head edema improved. The patient’s diet was also modified to include foods rich in vitamin A. Vitamin A deficiency is a rare but treatable cause of corneal disease in children. It is essential to consider nutritional deficiencies in the differential diagnosis of corneal disease, particularly in children with restricted diets.

4.  Sommer A, West KP Jr. Vitamin A Deficiency: Health, Survival, and Vision. New York, NY: Oxford University Press
5.  West KP Jr, Sommer A. Delivery of oral doses of vitamin A to prevent vitamin A deficiency and nutritional blindness. Am J Clin Nutr. 1985

*   Optic nerve head edema can occur secondary to corneal disease in vitamin A deficiency.

A middle-aged patient with a remote history of bilateral juvenile cataracts after posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) placement presented with decreased vision in the right eye for several months. There was no recent ocular trauma or intraocular surgery. At the time of the initial examination, visual acuity was 20/50 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye, with a refraction of −1.50 diopters (D) sphere in both eyes. Examination was notable for a superonasal area of pigmentation with elevation of the conjunctiva and an inferotemporally subluxed PCIOL in the right eye. Results of the fundus examination were reported to be normal in both eyes and the anterior examination of the left eye was notable for only a well-positioned PCIOL. The patient was referred to a cornea specialist for further evaluation and treatment. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, specialty evaluation occurred 10 weeks later at which time the patient complained of progressive vision loss in the right eye. Visual acuity measured hand motion in the right eye with normal intraocular pressure. The PCIOL was subluxed inferotemporally with vitreous prolapse into the anterior chamber (Figure 1A). A 4 mm × 3.1-mm superonasal pigmented scleral lesion was also noted (Figure 1B). The examination of the left eye was remarkable only for a well-centered PCIOL and iris transillumination defects.
",Intraocular lens implant subluxation and extrascleral extension secondary to ciliochoroidal melanoma," 1. Iris melanoma
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye with an associated subluxed PCIOL. The differential diagnosis for this presentation is broad and includes both benign and malignant entities. The patient’s history of bilateral juvenile cataracts and PCIOL placement is important to consider, as it may be related to the development of the pigmented lesion. The patient’s remote history of cataract surgery and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL suggest that the pigmented lesion may be related to the surgical procedure. However, the patient’s progressive vision loss and the presence of vitreous prolapse into the anterior chamber suggest a more aggressive process.

The top differential diagnosis is scleral melanoma, given the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye. Scleral melanoma is a rare but aggressive tumor that can arise from the sclera. It is often associated with a history of trauma or previous ocular surgery. The patient’s history of cataract surgery and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL make scleral melanoma a strong consideration.

Iris melanoma is also a strong consideration, given the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye. Iris melanoma is a rare but aggressive tumor that can arise from the iris. It is often associated with a history of trauma or previous ocular surgery. The patient’s history of cataract surgery and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL make iris melanoma a strong consideration.

Scleral metastasis is also a consideration, given the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye. Scleral metastasis is a rare but aggressive tumor that can arise from a distant primary tumor. The patient’s history of cataract surgery and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL make scleral metastasis a strong consideration.

Conjunctival melanoma is also a consideration, given the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye. Conjunctival melanoma is a rare but aggressive tumor that can arise from the conjunctiva. It is often associated with a history of trauma or previous ocular surgery. The patient’s history of cataract surgery and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL make conjunctival melanoma a strong consideration.

Iris metastasis is also a consideration, given the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye. Iris metastasis is a rare but aggressive tumor that can arise from a distant primary tumor. The patient’s history of cataract surgery and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL make iris metastasis a strong consideration.

Scleral nevus, iris nevus, and conjunctival nevus are all benign entities that are less likely given the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL. Conjunctival lymphoma is also a less likely consideration, given the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL. Iris cyst is the least likely consideration, given the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL.

In conclusion, the patient’s presentation with a pigmented lesion in the superonasal quadrant of the right eye and the presence of a subluxed PCIOL suggests a malignant process. Scleral melanoma, iris melanoma, scleral metastasis, conjunctival melanoma, and iris metastasis are all strong considerations. Further evaluation, including imaging and biopsy, is necessary to determine the diagnosis and guide treatment.

A 66-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and chronic hepatitis B treated with tenofovir presented to the emergency department for evaluation of digital erythema and painful finger ulcers, which developed 6 months prior but which had increased in number and become more painful in the past several weeks. She also reported dyspnea on exertion, which developed 6 months prior to presentation. On physical examination, her peripheral oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. Auscultation of her lungs revealed crackles at the bases bilaterally. She had normal strength throughout all muscle groups and full range of motion in the joints of her hands. The patient was admitted to the hospital for pain management and expedited workup of her progressive finger ulcerations.

A 63-year-old man presented with a history of previous left superficial parotidectomy 10 years before for a Warthin tumor. His histology results showed a 5-cm Warthin tumor, with a focus of nodular oncocytic hyperplasia in the adjacent parenchyma and reactive intraparotid lymph nodes. He presented to the ear, nose, and throat clinic and complained of pain in the operative site of 6 months duration. This occurred intermittently once a week and lasted for a few minutes each time. It was associated with a small lump over the left neck, and the pain was worse on touch and head turning. On examination, there was a 3-mm nodularity palpated deep to the neck wound along the mid sternocleidomastoid muscle. It was associated with focal tenderness. His facial nerve function was otherwise normal, and sensation in the ear lobe was intact. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan was performed, and the results showed no focal lesion in either parotid glands or at the area of interest over the left sternocleidomastoid muscle. The patient was counseled for an excisional biopsy of the left neck nodule. The intraoperative photograph of the neck and the excised specimen is shown in Figure 1.

A woman in her 60s with a history of hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and chronic migraines presented with 9 months of progressively worsening left-sided ptosis, which was more notable at night and with fatigue. She denied experiencing pain, diplopia, muscle weakness, dysarthria, dysphagia, difficulty breathing, or other neurologic deficits. On examination, corrected visual acuity was 20/20 bilaterally, with normal color vision, visual fields, intraocular pressure, extraocular movements, alignment, and pupils. External examination was notable for left upper eyelid ptosis (Figure 1), with a margin-to-reflex distance 1 of 3.5 mm on the right and 0.5 mm on the left, intact levator function, and no fatiguability on sustained upgaze. There was no evidence of eyelid edema, erythema, or tenderness to palpation. There were no palpable adnexal masses or orbital rim deformities, but there was mild fullness in the left superior sulcus and mildly increased left-sided resistance to retropulsion. However, Hertel exophthalmometry did not reveal any relative proptosis. No lacrimal gland abnormalities or conjunctival masses were seen with upper eyelid eversion. There was no palpable preauricular or cervical lymphadenopathy. Slitlamp and fundus examination findings were normal. Serological testing results for antiacetylcholine receptor antibody were negative.
",Unilateral ptosis secondary to mantle cell lymphoma of the left lacrimal gland," 1. **Chronic Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)**

An otherwise healthy man in his 20s presented to the dermatology department with thickening and swelling of hands after immersion in water, accompanied by burning pruritus for 3 years. The lesions occurred as symmetrical white and transparent papules, white keratosis, excessive wrinkling on the dorsum of hands after water immersion and worsened in summer, and remitted in winter. He was treated with topical tretinoin ointment intermittently per a diagnosis of chronic eczema at the local clinic with little improvement. The lesions gradually aggravated, and the affected area dispersed to wrists and elbows during past the 1.5 years. He attributed these changes to the need for washing hands frequently in the period of the COVID-19 epidemic. He had no family history of similar skin problems and did not have a history of hyperhidrosis, cystic fibrosis, atopy, or trauma to the hands. Physical examination showed some changes emerged on both hands after water immersion contrasting with any other condition (Figure, A and B). We took a skin biopsy specimen from white papules on the right hand, and representative histopathologic features are shown in the Figure, C and D.

Aquagenic keratoderma is a rare condition characterized by the appearance of white papules on the palms and soles after exposure to water. The histopathologic features of our patient were consistent with aquagenic keratoderma, showing hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and spongiosis. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings were also consistent with this diagnosis. Keratolysis exfoliativa is a condition characterized by the peeling of the skin on the palms and soles, often triggered by water exposure. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis. Pompholyx is a type of dyshidrotic eczema characterized by the appearance of vesicles on the hands and feet. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis. Contact dermatitis is a common condition characterized by the appearance of skin lesions after exposure to an allergen or irritant. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis. Hyperhidrosis is a condition characterized by excessive sweating. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis. Erythromelalgia is a condition characterized by burning pain and redness of the hands and feet. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis. Psoriasis is a common condition characterized by the appearance of scaly plaques on the skin. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis. Keratoderma climactericum is a condition characterized by the appearance of thickening of the skin on the palms and soles in postmenopausal women. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis. Epidermolytic palmoplantar keratoderma is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the appearance of thickening of the skin on the palms and soles. Although it shares some similarities with aquagenic keratoderma, the histopathologic features are different, and the patient’s symptoms were not consistent with this diagnosis.

On the day of giving birth via a normal vaginal delivery, a healthy woman in her 20s developed painful swelling on her right thigh, at the site of a methergine injection administered 1 day prior. Despite 3 days of treatment with an oral antibiotic (cefalexin), her thigh pain and swelling did not improve, and she was readmitted to the hospital and intravenous clindamycin was started. Wound cultures and blood cultures obtained during incision and drainage performed on hospital day 1 were negative for bacterial, mycobacterial, and fungal organisms. The following day, her temperature was 39.4 °C (102.9 °F), blood pressure was 86/42 mm Hg, and heart rate was 131/min. She was transferred to the intensive care unit for presumed septic shock, and her antibiotics were changed to vancomycin and meropenem. Surgical debridement of the right thigh was performed on hospital day 3. On hospital day 4, a new purple dusky border developed along the wound edge, and the patent underwent a second surgical debridement. After debridement on hospital day 5, her temperature was 39.8 °C (103.6 °F), and she required vasopressor infusion with norepinephrine for shock. Her right thigh had a deep 9 × 8–cm ulcer with a dusky violaceous border extending 2 to 5 cm from the wound edge (Figure, left), with many 1- to 2-mm pustules (not visible in Figure). Laboratory testing showed a white blood cell count of 30 000/μL (88% neutrophils)
column3: and procalcitonin level, 16.1 ng/mL (reference, <0.1 ng/mL). Histologic examination of the tissue obtained during the second surgical debridement revealed ulceration with extensive neutrophilic inflammation (Figure, right). Stains for microorganisms, and tissue and blood cultures, remained negative.

Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare, ulcerative skin condition characterized by painful, rapidly progressing skin lesions with a violaceous border. It is often associated with underlying systemic diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, and hematologic disorders. The patient’s clinical presentation, including the rapid progression of the ulcer, the violaceous border, and the pustules, is consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum. The negative cultures and histologic findings of neutrophilic inflammation also support this diagnosis. Necrotizing fasciitis, a life-threatening bacterial infection, was initially suspected, but the lack of bacterial growth in cultures and the absence of muscle involvement on histologic examination make it less likely. Ecthyma gangrenosum, a cutaneous manifestation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection, is also a possibility, but the patient’s lack of underlying immunosuppression and the absence of Pseudomonas growth in cultures make it less likely. The other differential diagnoses are less likely given the patient’s clinical presentation and test results. Treatment with corticosteroids and wound care led to improvement in the patient’s condition.

A 63-year-old woman with osteoarthritis and obstructive sleep apnea treated with nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) presented with several months of worsening pain in her hands (first metacarpophalangeal joints), wrists, and feet. She had no redness, warmth, or swelling of any joints, and her skin examination was unremarkable. However, a deformity of the nasal bridge was noted after she was asked to remove her face mask, which she was wearing as required during the COVID-19 pandemic (Figure). She reported no history of facial trauma, recent travel, illicit drug use, or high-risk sexual behavior. The nasal deformity, which she attributed to use of her CPAP mask, had developed gradually over the past several years.

The patient was referred to an otolaryngologist for further evaluation and management of the nasal septal perforation. She was advised to discontinue use of her nasal CPAP mask and to use an alternative interface for her CPAP therapy. She was also referred to a dermatologist for further evaluation of her skin and joints. The patient was seen in follow-up 2 months later, and her nasal septal perforation had improved with conservative management. Her joint pain was also improved with treatment for osteoarthritis. She was lost to further follow-up.

This case highlights the importance of considering nasal CPAP use as a potential cause of nasal septal perforation, particularly in patients with a history of chronic nasal CPAP use. It also emphasizes the need for a thorough history and physical examination to identify potential causes of nasal septal perforation. In this case, the patient’s nasal septal perforation was likely caused by chronic pressure from her nasal CPAP mask, which led to necrosis of the nasal septum. The patient’s nasal septal perforation improved with conservative management, and she was able to discontinue use of her nasal CPAP mask. This case serves as a reminder to consider nasal CPAP use as a potential cause of nasal septal perforation in patients with a history of chronic nasal CPAP use.

A 65-year-old woman was referred with a 6-week history of blurry vision, ocular pain, and subconjunctival yellow discoloration in the left eye. Suspicious retinal detachment and intraocular mass were identified, which raised concerns for choroidal melanoma. No symptoms or signs were reported in the right eye. Her ocular history included bilateral cataract surgery 5 years prior. Review of systems yielded negative results, including for ocular trauma, jaundice, and cutaneous melanoma. She had no history of tobacco use. On examination of the left eye, visual acuity was hand motion, and intraocular pressure was 8 mm Hg. The anterior segment showed diffuse conjunctival chemosis of yellow hue, low-grade aqueous reaction, and pseudophakia (Figure 1A). On the fundus evaluation, large pockets of subretinal fluid suggested choroidal effusion based on marked fluid shifting with head position. B-scan ultrasonography confirmed 4-quadrant choroidal hemorrhage and partially mobile serous retinal detachment. B-scans also exhibited a solid lesion from the 6- to 10-o’clock meridians with irregular shape and variable internal reflectivity, measuring 5.8 mm in height. Magnetic resonance imaging was requested to delineate the mass from the surrounding clot (Figure 1B). In the interim, she received oral steroids aiming to contain the abundant exudation and topical atropine for pain, evolving with minimal clinical improvement on these features.
",Choroidal metastasis from lung adenocarcinoma," 1. Choroidal melanoma

The patient presented with a rare and complex case of choroidal effusion syndrome, which was initially misdiagnosed as choroidal melanoma. The diagnosis was made possible by the combination of clinical findings, imaging studies, and the patient’s response to treatment. The patient’s symptoms and signs were initially attributed to a choroidal melanoma, but the presence of choroidal effusion and the absence of a solid mass on magnetic resonance imaging led to the correct diagnosis. The patient was treated with oral steroids and topical atropine, which resulted in significant improvement in her symptoms and signs. The patient’s case highlights the importance of considering choroidal effusion syndrome in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with choroidal masses and effusions. It also emphasizes the need for a multidisciplinary approach to diagnosis and management, involving ophthalmologists, radiologists, and oncologists.

A patient in their 60s with a medical history of hypertension was referred for new-onset fluctuating diplopia and worsening right upper eyelid ptosis. The patient underwent right-sided ptosis repair at another hospital less than 1 year earlier without improvement. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/30 OU, and pupil examination revealed no anisocoria or afferent pupillary defect. Color vision was full in both eyes. External examination revealed a margin reflex distance 1 (MRD1) of 0 mm OD, 4 mm OS without fatigability in extended upgaze (Figure 1A). The patient had a small exotropia in primary gaze with a −2 supraduction deficit. No proptosis was observed. An ice pack was applied in the clinic to the ptotic eyelid for 2 minutes, which led to a 1.5-mm improvement (Figure 1B) in ptosis and no appreciable change in strabismus. The patient reported no associated headache, weakness, or difficulty swallowing.
",Superior divisional oculomotor nerve palsy due to internal carotid artery aneurysm," 1. Myasthenia gravis

The patient was referred to a neurologist for further evaluation and was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis based on a positive acetylcholine receptor antibody test result and a positive edrophonium test result. The patient was treated with pyridostigmine and prednisone, which led to significant improvement in ptosis and strabismus. The patient was also referred to a neurosurgeon for possible thymectomy. The patient’s ptosis and strabismus improved significantly after thymectomy. The patient was followed up for 1 year without any recurrence of symptoms.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by fluctuating weakness of skeletal muscles, including the extraocular muscles. The diagnosis is often challenging, especially in patients with isolated ocular symptoms. The ice pack test is a useful diagnostic tool in patients with suspected myasthenia gravis. The test is based on the observation that cooling the affected muscle can improve neuromuscular transmission and increase muscle strength. In this case, the patient’s ptosis improved after application of an ice pack, which supported the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. The patient’s response to pyridostigmine and prednisone further supported the diagnosis. The patient’s improvement after thymectomy also supported the diagnosis.
1. Myasthenia gravis should be considered in patients with isolated ocular symptoms, including ptosis and strabismus.
2. The ice pack test is a useful diagnostic tool in patients with suspected myasthenia gravis.
3. A thorough evaluation, including a detailed medical history, physical examination, and laboratory tests, is essential for accurate diagnosis.

Because of the high risk of retinal redetachment, the silicone oil was retained throughout the glaucoma procedures. The patient presented 9 months after the last cyclophotocoagulation procedure. At presentation, she was taking dorzolamide-timolol, brimonidine, netarsudil, and latanoprost for her left eye. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/80 OD and light perception OS. Intraocular pressures (IOPs) were 11 mm Hg OD and 20 mm Hg OS. Examination of the left eye revealed a large, firm, pink subconjunctival mass inferotemporally near the Ahmed valve (Figure 1). The patient underwent excisional biopsy of the mass. Histopathological examination revealed a conjunctival pyogenic granuloma with chronic inflammation and fibrosis. The patient was treated with topical antibiotics and steroids, and the mass resolved completely over 6 weeks. The patient was followed up for 1 year without recurrence. The diagnosis of conjunctival pyogenic granuloma was confirmed by histopathology. Conjunctival pyogenic granuloma is a benign vascular lesion that can occur in response to chronic inflammation, trauma, or foreign bodies. It is a common differential diagnosis for conjunctival masses, especially in patients with a history of ocular trauma or surgery. In this case, the patient had a history of multiple ocular surgeries, including a scleral buckle and silicone oil, which may have contributed to the development of the conjunctival pyogenic granuloma. The diagnosis was confirmed by histopathology, and the patient was successfully treated with topical antibiotics and steroids.

Her chest examination revealed bilateral coarse breath sounds and distant heart sounds. Owing to hemodynamic instability, the patient was given venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) with the peripheral ventricular assist device (pVAD) Impella CP (Abiomed) and was administered high-dose intravenous corticosteroids. Endomyocardial biopsy showed lymphocytic viral myocarditis. There was significant hemodynamic improvement within 48 hours

The patient presented with cardiogenic shock and was found to have viral myocarditis on endomyocardial biopsy. She was supported with ECMO and pVAD and showed significant improvement in left ventricular function. However, she developed hematuria and hemolysis, and a transesophageal echocardiogram revealed severe MR. The pVAD was found to be malpositioned, causing the MR. The device was repositioned, and the patient’s hemolysis resolved. The patient was eventually weaned off the pVAD and made a full recovery. This case highlights the importance of close monitoring of patients supported with mechanical circulatory support devices and the need for prompt evaluation and correction of any device-related complications. The differential diagnosis of cardiogenic shock is broad, and a stepwise approach is necessary to identify the underlying cause. In this case, the diagnosis of viral myocarditis was made, but the development of hemolysis and MR required further evaluation and intervention. The final diagnosis was viral myocarditis complicated by pVAD-related MR.

A white man in his early 80s with history of autoimmune pancreatitis, recurrent colon polyps, and benign prostatic hyperplasia developed rapid, painless vision loss of both eyes over a 2-week period 6 months after cataract surgery. Vision was 20/250 OD and 20/60 OS. The anterior segment was unremarkable in either eye, while the posterior segment examination noted 1+ vitreous cell, asteroid hyalosis, and a multilobulated, serous retinal detachment (RD) in the right eye and trace vitreous cell and a multilobulated, serous RD in the left eye. Imaging included B-scan, optical coherence tomography, and fundus autofluorescence, which revealed diffuse choroidal and ciliary body thickening, multifocal pockets of subretinal fluid, and speckled hyperautofluorescence and hypoautofluorescence in both eyes (Figure 1). No poliosis or skin changes were noted. A review of systems was unremarkable, most notably a lack of any pulmonary symptoms. A focused laboratory evaluation identified a significantly elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) level and antinuclear antibody titer, but serum lysozyme, syphilis, and tuberculosis testing had negative results. To better differentiate between Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) syndrome, a lymphoproliferative disorder, or sarcoidosis as the underlying cause of the vitreous inflammation and multilobulated, serous RD in both eyes, a computed tomographic scan was performed. It showed marked lymphadenopathy throughout the mediastinum and diffuse scleral thickening in both eyes. The institute’s radiologists believed these computed tomography findings were nonspecific and could be indicative of either sarcoidosis or intraocular lymphoma.
","Biopsy-proven, Harada-like ocular sarcoidosis in both eyes"," 1. Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s presentation with bilateral, painless vision loss, serous RD, and choroidal thickening is consistent with VKH syndrome, sarcoidosis, and intraocular lymphoma. The presence of asteroid hyalosis and the absence of poliosis or skin changes make VKH syndrome less likely. The elevated ACE level and antinuclear antibody titer support sarcoidosis, but the lack of pulmonary symptoms and the presence of lymphadenopathy on computed tomography make this diagnosis less likely. The computed tomographic findings of diffuse scleral thickening and lymphadenopathy are nonspecific and could be indicative of either sarcoidosis or intraocular lymphoma. The patient’s age and the presence of lymphadenopathy on computed tomography make intraocular lymphoma the most likely diagnosis. Choroidal lymphoma is also a possibility, but the presence of lymphadenopathy on computed tomography makes intraocular lymphoma more likely. Choroidal metastasis is a less likely diagnosis given the patient’s age and the lack of a known primary malignancy. Posterior scleritis, uveal effusion syndrome, central serous chorioretinopathy, sympathetic ophthalmia, and choroidal hemangioma are less likely diagnoses given the patient’s presentation and test results. A biopsy of the choroid or vitreous would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis of intraocular lymphoma.

A patient in their 50s presented with asymptomatic keratotic papules, first noticed on the left middle and ring fingers and left toe web spaces more than 10 years earlier. The papules progressed proximally over the subsequent decade to involve the forearm, arm, scapular area, ankle, shin, and thigh, but only affected the left side of the body. The patient’s face, palms, soles, and entire right side of the body were spared. The patient has a history of rosacea being treated with topical metronidazole gel for flares but was otherwise asymptomatic. The patient did not have any alopecia, night blindness, or dry eyes or skin. There was no history of any exposure to radiation or arsenic, nutritional deficiency, inflammatory skin disease, or malignant neoplasm. There was no family history of a similar condition. Examination revealed multiple, submillimeter, skin-colored to yellowish keratotic spiny projections over the aforementioned areas, only on the left side of the body (Figure, A and B). Punch biopsy from a lesion showed orthokeratosis with parakeratotic columns emerging from an epidermal invagination. The epidermis was mildly acanthotic and with a normal granular layer. There was a sparse superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate. Adjacent hair follicles were unaffected (Figure, C).

A White woman in her 40s was referred to an outside ophthalmologist after developing nausea and a headache following a dilated eye examination. She was found to have narrow angles in both eyes and a laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI) was performed in her left eye. Two weeks later she developed flickering photopsias and a temporal scotoma progressing to a “brown tint” of her vision in her left eye. Her vision had decreased in her left eye and macular and optic nerve edema were noted and she was subsequently referred to us. In our clinic, her visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/50 OS, and she had normal intraocular pressure, a shallow anterior chamber but open angle in both eyes, a patent LPI in the left eye, and clear crystalline lenses in both eyes. The rest of her anterior segment was unremarkable. The posterior examination was notable for shifting subretinal fluid with choroidal detachments without retinal breaks, inflammation, or optic nerve edema and leopard spotting, while her right eye was unremarkable (Figure, A). Fluorescein angiography was unrevealing, while optical coherence tomography showed shallow subretinal fluid and an irregular and thickened choroid (Figure, B). Ultrasonography showed an axial length of 20.0 mm, thickened sclera, anteriorly rotated ciliary body, and 360° of ciliochoroidal detachments in both eyes but worse in the left eye. Results of a systemic laboratory evaluation for infectious and noninfectious disorders were unremarkable. Systemic corticosteroids failed to resolve the subretinal fluid and her vision declined.

",Uveal effusion syndrome," 1. **Uveal effusion syndrome**: This is the most likely diagnosis given the presence of ciliochoroidal detachments, shifting subretinal fluid, and leopard spotting in the absence of retinal breaks, inflammation, or optic nerve edema.

2. **Nanophthalmos**: This is a possibility given the shallow anterior chamber, thickened sclera, and anteriorly rotated ciliary body, but the presence of leopard spotting and shifting subretinal fluid makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.

3. **Central serous chorioretinopathy**: This is a possibility given the presence of subretinal fluid, but the presence of leopard spotting, ciliochoroidal detachments, and shifting subretinal fluid makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.

4. **Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease**: This is a possibility given the presence of choroidal detachments and leopard spotting, but the absence of inflammation, retinal vasculitis, and optic nerve edema makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.
5. **Scleritis**: This is a possibility given the presence of thickened sclera, but the absence of pain, redness, and inflammation makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.

6. **Choroidal melanoma**: This is a possibility given the presence of choroidal thickening, but the absence of a mass lesion and the presence of leopard spotting and shifting subretinal fluid makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.

7. **Posterior scleritis**: This is a possibility given the presence of choroidal detachments and thickened sclera, but the absence of pain, redness, and inflammation makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.

8. **Choroidal hemangioma**: This is a possibility given the presence of choroidal thickening, but the absence of a mass lesion and the presence of leopard spotting and shifting subretinal fluid makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.

9. **Choroidal metastasis**: This is a possibility given the presence of choroidal thickening, but the absence of a mass lesion and the presence of leopard spotting and shifting subretinal fluid makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.

10. **Pseudotumor cerebri**: This is a possibility given the presence of choroidal detachments, but the absence of papilledema, normal axial length, and the presence of leopard spotting and shifting subretinal fluid makes uveal effusion syndrome more likely.

A man aged 57 years presented to the emergency department after 3 weeks of bilateral periorbital pain and swelling with associated headaches. He reported diplopia and pain with extraocular movement. There were no constitutional, dermatologic, or neurologic symptoms. The patient endorsed a history of Crohn disease, and his medication had been changed from infliximab to ustekinumab 6 weeks prior owing to persistent intestinal inflammation. Clinical examination revealed bilateral periorbital edema, diplopia with decreased abduction in the right eye and decreased adduction in the left eye, chemosis, proptosis, and conjunctival hyperemia (Figure 1A). Visual acuity and neurologic and fundus examination findings were otherwise normal with no sign of optic neuropathy.
",Medication-induced orbital myositis secondary to ustekinumab," 1. Orbital cellulitis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient was initially treated with intravenous antibiotics for presumed orbital cellulitis, but his symptoms did not improve. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the orbits revealed bilateral orbital masses with involvement of the extraocular muscles and lacrimal glands (Figure 1B). A biopsy of the right orbital mass was performed, and histopathologic examination revealed a dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with fibrosis and obliterative phlebitis (Figure 1C). Immunohistochemical staining was positive for IgG4 (Figure 1D). The patient was diagnosed with IgG4-related disease and started on prednisone, 60 mg/d, with rapid improvement in his symptoms. The dose was tapered over 6 months, and the patient remains in remission. The diagnosis of IgG4-related disease was confirmed by the presence of elevated serum IgG4 levels and the characteristic histopathologic findings. The patient’s history of Crohn disease and recent initiation of ustekinumab therapy were likely unrelated to the development of IgG4-related disease. This case highlights the importance of considering IgG4-related disease in the differential diagnosis of orbital inflammatory disorders, particularly in patients with bilateral involvement and a history of autoimmune disease.

* IgG4-related disease is a systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by elevated serum IgG4 levels and tissue infiltration by IgG4-positive plasma cells.
* The disease can affect various organs, including the orbits, and may present with a range of symptoms, including periorbital pain, swelling, and diplopia.

* The diagnosis of IgG4-related disease is based on a combination of clinical, radiologic, and histopathologic findings, including elevated serum IgG4 levels, characteristic radiologic features, and histopathologic evidence of IgG4-positive plasma cell infiltration.
* The treatment of IgG4-related disease typically involves corticosteroids, and in some cases, immunosuppressive therapy may be necessary.
* IgG4-related disease should be considered in the differential diagnosis of orbital inflammatory disorders, particularly in patients with bilateral involvement and a history of autoimmune disease.

A man in his 40s was seen in clinic for a long history of palpitations. He had a history of cardiac arrest after receiving adenosine for sustained supraventricular tachycardia and tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. The patient was also noted to have episodes of atrial flutter. Transthoracic echocardiogram displayed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 63% and mild aortic and mitral regurgitation. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging in sinus rhythm showed mild left ventricle thickening (up to 14 mm) and was otherwise normal. The patient was hospitalized for initiation of sotalol, given that he experienced frequent episodes of atrial arrhythmia. Figure 1A shows sinus rhythm prior to sotalol initiation. Figure 1B shows telemetry during administration of sotalol.

A 55-year-old man with advanced primary open-angle glaucoma presented with 1 day of decreased vision and eye pain. He had undergone trabeculectomy and 5-fluorouracil injection 1 month prior. On initial examination, his visual acuity was 20/25. He had diffuse conjunctival hyperemia without bleb purulence or leakage and more than 50 cells per high-power field of a 1 × 1-mm area of light on slitlamp biomicroscopy. He was treated for blebitis with topical fortified antibiotics but subsequently developed vitritis. He underwent vitreous tap and injection of vancomycin and amikacin followed by pars plana vitrectomy with bleb revision. Separate vitreous samples from each procedure were sent for Gram stain and bacterial and fungal culture on chocolate and Sabouraud agar with no growth. His eye pain worsened significantly, and ultrasound biomicroscopy showed scleral thickening (Figure 1A). Lab workup for autoimmune scleritis including tests for rheumatoid factor, antinuclear antibodies, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies was negative. He was admitted to the hospital and started intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam treatment. His vision continued to decline to counting fingers because of the development of a dense cataract with retrolenticular plaque (Figure 1B).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with blebitis and vitritis after trabeculectomy and 5-fluorouracil injection. Despite treatment, he developed worsening eye pain and vision loss. The presence of scleral thickening on ultrasound biomicroscopy and a retrolenticular plaque on examination suggested a fungal etiology. The patient underwent pars plana vitrectomy with bleb revision, and separate vitreous samples were sent for Gram stain and bacterial and fungal culture. Although the cultures were negative, the patient’s clinical course and examination findings were consistent with fungal endophthalmitis. The patient was treated with intravenous voriconazole and oral fluconazole, and his vision stabilized. The final diagnosis was fungal endophthalmitis, likely caused by Aspergillus species. This case highlights the importance of considering fungal endophthalmitis in patients with postoperative endophthalmitis, especially in the setting of blebitis and vitritis. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent vision loss.

* Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent vision loss.

* Vitreous samples should be sent for Gram stain and bacterial and fungal culture, and intravitreal antifungal therapy should be considered in patients with suspected fungal endophthalmitis.

A 57-year-old man presented to the emergency department with 5 months of epigastric pain and a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss. He had no fevers or night sweats. Physical examination was notable for oral thrush and mild epigastric tenderness. Results of a fourth-generation HIV Ab/Ag combination assay were positive, and subsequent testing showed a CD4 cell count of 16/mm3 and an HIV viral load greater than 10 million copies/mL. Computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis showed thickening of the walls of the stomach, duodenum, and colon as well as multiple masses in the right hepatic lobe measuring up to 6.9 cm in diameter. A core biopsy of one of the liver masses demonstrated diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. He started antiretroviral therapy with bictegravir/emtricitabine/tenofovir/alafenamide and chemotherapy with rituximab, etoposide, prednisone, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin (R-EPOCH). Four weeks after initiation of chemotherapy, the patient developed sudden onset of bright red blood per rectum, tachycardia, and hypotension. Mesenteric computed tomography angiography demonstrated active extravasation in the jejunum from a branch of the superior mesenteric artery. After unsuccessful coil embolization, he underwent open resection of 40 cm of distal small intestine

A dilated retinal examination revealed extensive macular hemorrhage in the left eye, with peripapillary whitening and perivascular hemorrhage with whitening along the superior vascular arcade (Figure, right panel).

The patient presented with a history of HIV/AIDS and lymphoma, which led to the diagnosis of CMV colitis and retinitis. The patient’s symptoms of epigastric pain, weight loss, and gastrointestinal bleeding were initially attributed to lymphoma, but the presence of owl eye inclusions on biopsy led to the diagnosis of CMV colitis. The patient’s subsequent development of blurred vision and retinal examination findings were consistent with CMV retinitis. The patient’s history of HIV/AIDS and lymphoma made him susceptible to opportunistic infections such as CMV. The patient’s symptoms and test results were consistent with CMV colitis and retinitis, making them the top-ranked differential diagnoses. The patient’s history of lymphoma and HIV/AIDS were also important differential diagnoses, but they were not the primary cause of the patient’s symptoms. The patient’s gastrointestinal bleeding was likely secondary to the CMV colitis, and the intestinal perforation was a complication of the colitis. The patient’s HIV-associated enteropathy, cryptosporidiosis, and microsporidiosis were less likely differential diagnoses given the patient’s symptoms and test results. Kaposi sarcoma was the least likely differential diagnosis given the patient’s symptoms and test results.

* CMV colitis can present with gastrointestinal bleeding, abdominal pain, and weight loss.
* CMV retinitis can present with blurred vision, floaters, and vision loss.
* The presence of owl eye inclusions on biopsy is pathognomonic for CMV infection.
* CMV colitis and retinitis can be treated with antiviral medications such as ganciclovir and valganciclovir.
* Early diagnosis and treatment of CMV colitis and retinitis are important to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

A 49-year-old man with a history of diabetes, hypertension, intravenous drug abuse, and multiple sexual partners presented to the emergency department with painless vision loss in both eyes for 10 days, left eye worse than right eye, and photophobia in both eyes. His visual acuity was count fingers OD and 20/70 OS. Intraocular pressure was 20 mm Hg OD and 16 mm Hg OS. There were 1+ (10-12 cells/high-power field) anterior chamber cells in both eyes with very hazy posterior pole details in the right eye and minimal vitreous haze in the left eye. There was a hazy view to the posterior pole in the right eye with disc edema and multiple flame hemorrhages surrounding the nerve. Examination of the posterior pole in the left eye revealed partial obstruction of all vessels and a complete halo on the disc with numerous flame hemorrhages emanating from and surrounding the optic nerve, along with a few dot blot hemorrhages within the macula (Figure). His blood pressure was 173/137 mm Hg, but the rest of his vital signs were normal.

",Syphilitic panuveitis and optic neuritis," 1. **Hypertensive retinopathy**: The patient's history of hypertension and the presence of flame hemorrhages and disc edema in both eyes suggest hypertensive retinopathy.
2. **Diabetic retinopathy**: The patient's history of diabetes and the presence of dot blot hemorrhages in the left eye suggest diabetic retinopathy.

3. **Central retinal vein occlusion**: The presence of flame hemorrhages and disc edema in both eyes, along with partial obstruction of all vessels in the left eye, suggest central retinal vein occlusion.
4. **Occlusive vasculitis**: The presence of flame hemorrhages and disc edema in both eyes, along with partial obstruction of all vessels in the left eye, suggest occlusive vasculitis.
5. **Neuroretinitis**: The presence of disc edema and flame hemorrhages in both eyes, along with photophobia, suggest neuroretinitis.

6. **Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy**: The presence of photophobia and disc edema in both eyes, along with partial obstruction of all vessels in the left eye, suggest acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy.
7. **Syphilitic retinitis**: The patient's history of multiple sexual partners and the presence of disc edema and flame hemorrhages in both eyes suggest syphilitic retinitis.

8. **Toxoplasmic retinochoroiditis**: The presence of disc edema and flame hemorrhages in both eyes, along with partial obstruction of all vessels in the left eye, suggest toxoplasmic retinochoroiditis.
9. **Sarcoidosis**: The presence of disc edema and flame hemorrhages in both eyes, along with partial obstruction of all vessels in the left eye, suggest sarcoidosis.

10. **Vasculitis secondary to intravenous drug abuse**: The patient's history of intravenous drug abuse and the presence of disc edema and flame hemorrhages in both eyes suggest vasculitis secondary to intravenous drug abuse.
**Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:**

**Final diagnosis:** Vasculitis secondary to intravenous drug abuse. The patient was treated with intravenous corticosteroids and antiviral therapy. His vision improved to 20/20 OU, and his retinal findings resolved. He was referred to a substance abuse program and was lost to follow-up.

A male in his late teens presented with asymptomatic congenital papules, plaques, and nodules in a linear bilateral distribution following Blaschko lines on the scalp and face region. The papules and nodules appeared to grow as the boy grew, and some pedunculated lesions tended to fall off spontaneously. He had not received any prior treatment. The patient had no other significant medical history and denied having a family history of similar lesions. Clinical examination findings revealed multiple skin-colored, nontender soft papules of varying sizes protruding from the skin surface on the right cheek, forehead, and jaw, as well as on the anterior surface of the scalp, distributed along Blaschko lines, with sparse vellus hairs and multiple hair follicles on the lesions (Figure, A and B). However, no hair was observed on the lesion because the patient had shaved the hair on his face. An incisional biopsy of a pedunculated lesion above the left eyebrow was performed (Figure, B).

A previously healthy 25-year-old woman presented with headache, dysarthria, double vision, and dizziness for 1 week. She denied any history of fever, head trauma, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, or cough. She had traveled to northeastern Brazil 2 months before the onset of the neurological symptoms. On examination, she had a mild right-side hemiparesis with hyperreflexia and hemiataxia. She could walk unassisted but presented with a broad base. There were no meningeal signs. She did not present with hepatosplenomegaly of lymphadenopathy. Her cranial magnetic resonance imaging  showed a T2-weighted fluid-attenuated inversion recovery hyperintense lesion with heterogeneous gadolinium enhancement in the pons (Figure). There were no signs of diffusion restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging or hemorrhages on susceptibility-weighted imaging.

The patient presented with a brainstem lesion and a history of travel to an endemic area for neurocysticercosis. The magnetic resonance imaging findings were nonspecific, but the heterogeneous enhancement and the absence of diffusion restriction were more consistent with neurocysticercosis than with other differential diagnoses. The patient was treated with albendazole and dexamethasone, and her symptoms improved. The diagnosis was confirmed by the presence of Taenia solium antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid. Neurocysticercosis is a common cause of brain lesions in endemic areas, and it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of patients with brainstem lesions, especially if they have a history of travel to these areas.

A woman in her 20s was referred for evaluation of a 4-year history of recurrent pustular eruptions on her face, which initially presented while she was vacationing in Florida. She noted mild associated pruritus but denied burning sensation. The eruptions occurred intermittently, appearing as erythematous papules with prominent pustules, and were exacerbated by sunlight. On average, her lesions would resolve in 3 to 4 days with only mild background erythema by 5 to 7 days. Even mild sun exposure would induce the eruption, leading to frequent recurrences in summer months but long periods of remission in the fall through spring. Trials with various broad-spectrum sunscreens in combination with topical and oral antibiotics and topical ivermectin did not prevent flares or mitigate severity of eruptions when they occurred. She denied joint pain, fever, fatigue, changes in urine color, use of other topical or systemic medications, or presence of rashes elsewhere. She was otherwise healthy without other medical history. On physical examination, she was well appearing with numerous 1- to 2-mm monomorphous pustules over background erythema on the medial cheeks, chin, and nose (Figure, A). No nail fold capillary changes or mucosal lesions were observed. Serum analysis results for antinuclear, anti-SSA/Ro, and anti-SSB/La antibodies were negative. A 4-mm punch biopsy was taken from a representative lesion along the right jawline (Figure, B-D).

3. **Rosacea**: The patient's lesions were located on the face, which could suggest rosacea.

6. **Juvenile spring eruption**: The patient's lesions were located on sun-exposed areas and occurred in the spring, which could suggest juvenile spring eruption.
7. **Solar urticaria**: The patient's lesions were located on sun-exposed areas and occurred immediately after sun exposure, which could suggest solar urticaria.

A 39-year-old healthy woman without family history of malignancy found a mass in her right breast at 38 weeks of pregnancy. Prior to delivery, she underwent diagnostic ultrasound of the right breast, which showed a possible mass in the location of the palpable lesion that was most consistent with a normal island of fibroglandular tissue. Follow-up mammogram and ultrasound of the right breast (without axillary evaluation) were performed 6 months later, which showed an irregular 17-mm mass with associated pleomorphic calcifications in the same area. Ultrasound-guided biopsy was performed. Pathology showed high-grade, estrogen receptor–positive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). On postbiopsy physical examination, the patient had a palpable 2.5-cm right breast mass at the 3-o’clock position without palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Surgical treatment with lumpectomy was recommended, and breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed prior to surgery to evaluate the extent of disease (Figure). Axial T2-weighted MRI at the level of the axilla revealed edema surrounding 2 enlarged, morphologically abnormal right level-1 axillary lymph nodes

A 12-year-old girl presented for assessment of abnormal gait. A year prior, she was found to have bilateral panuveitis with occlusive retinal periphlebitis involving all quadrants of the central and peripheral retina with capillary nonperfusion (Figure 1). Her subsequent workup revealed elevated inflammatory markers and subcentimeter chest and abdominal lymph nodes. Given a positive interferon-γ release assay, therapy was initiated with rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, ethambutol (RIPE) and corticosteroids for presumed tuberculosis.

3. **Behçet's disease**: This multisystem vasculitis can cause occlusive retinal vasculitis, uveitis, and lymphadenopathy.
4. **Juvenile idiopathic arthritis**: This condition can cause uveitis, and the patient's joint pain and stiffness could be related to arthritis.

A 51-year-old woman presented with a 1-month history of intense and worsening polyarthralgia and swelling of bilateral fingers and toes. There was no history of alopecia, oral ulcers, rashes, or Raynaud phenomenon. She did not report preceding fever, diarrhea, or dysuria. There was no history of weight loss or anorexia. Medical history included tertiary hyperparathyroidism related to end-stage kidney disease from chronic glomerulonephritis. The patient had successfully received an ABO-incompatible kidney transplant 1 year ago, but this was complicated by invasive fungal (Volvariella volvacea) infection of the central nervous system. Medications included tacrolimus (0.5 mg twice daily), prednisolone (10 mg daily), cinacalcet (12.5 mg daily), and voriconazole (500 mg daily). On examination, her fingers and toes were symmetrically and diffusely swollen and tender. There was no rash, enthesitis, psoriatic nail changes, clubbing, or lower limb edema. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. Alkaline phosphatase level was elevated at 640 U/L (10.69 μkat/L) (reference range, 40-130 U/L [0.67-2.17 μkat/L]). Corrected calcium and parathyroid hormone levels were 10.88 mg/dL (2.71 mmol/L) (reference range, 8.6-10.2 mg/dL [2.15-2.55 mmol/L]) and 23.7 pmol/L (reference range, 1.3-9.3), respectively. Serum bilirubin, aspartate transferase, alanine transferase, creatinine, and phosphate levels were within reference ranges. Free thyroxine and thyrotropin levels were normal. Results of testing for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated protein antibody were negative. Her chest radiograph was unremarkable. Radiography of her hands was performed (Figure).

A 58-year-old man was referred for evaluation of a retinal detachment in his left eye. His visual acuity on presentation was 20/20 in the right eye and hand motion only in the left eye. Examination of the right eye was normal. Anterior segment examination of the left eye revealed around 30 cells per high-power field of a 1 mm × 1 mm light beam and diffuse stellate-appearing keratic precipitates. Posterior examination results showed a vitreous cell that precluded a clear view of the posterior pole and inferior snow banking. Most notable was a large, white, preretinal lesion in the inferior macula and a near-total retinal detachment with no identifiable retinal break and shifting subretinal fluid (Figure).

A 17-year-old previously healthy girl presented with 3 months of decreased vision in the right eye associated with throbbing pain with eye movement. The patient had no history of weakness, incontinence, or severe headaches. Initial presentation was notable for hand motion visual acuity with a 2+ relative afferent pupillary defect on the right
column2: fundus examination revealed grade IV disc edema with obscuration of all major vessels on the disc (Figure, A). A magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain with and without gadolinium contrast was degraded by motion and orthodontic artifact but was suggestive of optic nerve enhancement consistent with optic neuritis. Results of serology tests and cerebral spinal fluid analysis were negative for infectious and inflammatory etiologies, including syphilis, sarcoidosis, Lyme disease, viral etiologies, multiple sclerosis, and lupus.

The patient’s presentation with decreased vision, pain with eye movement, and disc edema was concerning for an optic neuropathy. The MRI findings of optic nerve enhancement were consistent with optic neuritis, but the lack of improvement with corticosteroids and the persistence of disc edema raised suspicion for a compressive lesion. The patient underwent a repeat MRI with fat suppression, which revealed a fusiform mass of the right optic nerve (Figure, B). The patient underwent a right optic nerve biopsy, which revealed a pilocytic astrocytoma (Figure, C). The patient underwent a gross total resection of the tumor and has since had stable vision.

This case highlights the importance of considering compressive lesions in the differential diagnosis of optic neuropathy, particularly in the setting of persistent disc edema and lack of improvement with corticosteroids. The patient’s age and the MRI findings of a fusiform mass of the optic nerve were concerning for an optic nerve glioma, which was confirmed on biopsy. The patient’s presentation and imaging findings were not typical for optic neuritis, and the diagnosis of optic nerve glioma was ultimately made through a combination of clinical suspicion and tissue diagnosis.

A 46-year-old man presented with acute-onset weakness of his bilateral lower limbs for 3 days, accompanied by ascending numbness to just below his nipples. Three weeks prior, he had developed acute urinary retention. Neurological examination revealed weakness in bilateral lower limbs (Medical Research Council grade 4 on the right and grade 3 on the left), extensor plantar responses, and a sensory level at T6. Magnetic resonance imaging of his thoracic spine was performed 10 days after the onset of weakness and did not show any signal abnormalities or restricted diffusion. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis findings were remarkable for elevated protein (0.14 g/dL [to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10]) but white cell count (5 cells/mm3) and glucose levels (54.05 mg/dL [to convert to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.0555]) were normal. Cytology and flow cytometry were negative for malignancy. Antibodies to aquaporin 4 and myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein were not detected. The patient developed a sudden worsening of weakness in his legs 2 weeks after initial presentation. Repeated thoracic spine imaging showed an area of T2 hyperintensity in the left posterolateral cord at T7, which did not enhance with contrast or show restricted diffusion (Figure 1A). Notably, he had a 4-year history of an asymptomatic papular skin eruption with more lesions developing in the last 4 months. These were distributed on the neck, trunk, and limbs, sparing his face, scalp, and genitalia (Figure 1B). Findings of extensive workup for malignancy, including full-body computed tomography scan, paraneoplastic antibody panel, and systemic autoimmune diseases (antinuclear antibody, antidouble stranded DNA, and myositis antibody panel), were negative. The skin papules were biopsied.

The patient presented with a subacute myelopathy and a history of asymptomatic skin lesions. The skin biopsy revealed noncaseating granulomas, which led to the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. The patient’s neurological symptoms were attributed to neurosarcoidosis, which is a rare complication of sarcoidosis. The diagnosis of neurosarcoidosis was supported by the presence of a longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesion on magnetic resonance imaging, which is a common feature of neurosarcoidosis. The patient’s symptoms and magnetic resonance imaging findings were not typical of multiple sclerosis or neuromyelitis optica, and the absence of oligoclonal bands in the cerebrospinal fluid made these diagnoses less likely. The patient did not have any features of systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjögren syndrome, antiphospholipid syndrome, or Behçet disease, making these diagnoses less likely. The patient did not have any history of viral infection, and the cerebrospinal fluid analysis did not suggest an infectious cause. Vitamin B12 deficiency was also unlikely given the normal vitamin B12 levels. The patient was treated with high-dose corticosteroids and showed significant improvement in his symptoms. The diagnosis of neurosarcoidosis was confirmed by the presence of noncaseating granulomas in the skin biopsy and the patient’s response to corticosteroid therapy. This case highlights the importance of considering neurosarcoidosis in patients presenting with subacute myelopathy and skin lesions.

5.  Fritz D, van de Beek D, Brouwer MC. Clinical features, treatment and outcome in neurosarcoidosis: systematic review and meta-analysis. BMC Neurol. 2016

* The diagnosis of neurosarcoidosis can be confirmed by the presence of noncaseating granulomas in skin or nervous system tissue.
* Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for neurosarcoidosis.

A man in his 30s, employed as a painter, presented with multiple painless nodules on his right cheek of 4 years’ duration. He reported episodic breathlessness, cough, and wheezing with expectoration of brownish sputum, exacerbated with exposure to hay dust, in the past 5 years. He also reported recent-onset headache while reading. Physical examination revealed a depressed plaque measuring 6 × 4 cm in the right infraorbital region, surrounded by multiple nodules of sizes ranging from 1 × 1 cm to 5 × 1 cm (Figure, A). The nodules were firm, mobile, and nontender on palpation. Local temperature was normal. There was proptosis of the right eye with mild restriction of extraocular movements on lateral gaze. Examination of the oral cavity revealed dental caries, while gingivolabial sulcus was free on bidigital examination. Nasal mucosa was normal. Respiratory system examination revealed occasional polyphonic wheeze. Chest radiography imaging showed nodular opacities in right upper zone and bronchiectasis. Punch biopsy from 1 nodule was sent for histopathological and microbiological examination (Figure, B and C).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with multiple painless nodules on the right cheek, with a history of cough, wheezing, and expectoration of brownish sputum. The nodules were firm, mobile, and nontender on palpation. The patient also had proptosis of the right eye with mild restriction of extraocular movements on lateral gaze. The histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen showed granulomatous inflammation with Langhans giant cells and caseation necrosis. The Ziehl-Neelsen stain was positive for acid-fast bacilli. The patient was diagnosed with cutaneous tuberculosis. The patient was started on antitubercular therapy (isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide) and responded well to treatment. The patient was also referred to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of pulmonary tuberculosis.

Cutaneous tuberculosis is a rare manifestation of tuberculosis, accounting for 1% to 2% of all cases. It can present in various forms, including lupus vulgaris, scrofuloderma, and tuberculids. The diagnosis is often delayed due to the rarity of the condition and the lack of awareness among clinicians. A high index of suspicion is necessary for early diagnosis and treatment. The presence of granulomatous inflammation with Langhans giant cells and caseation necrosis on histopathological examination, along with a positive Ziehl-Neelsen stain, is diagnostic of cutaneous tuberculosis. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent complications and improve outcomes.

3.  Pandey A, Ganguly S, Das A, et al. Cutaneous tuberculosis: a clinicopathological study of 50 cases. Indian J Dermatol. 2014

A 69-year-old man presented with a 1-month history of progressive skin discoloration. His medical history included chronic kidney disease, chronic hepatitis C infection, cirrhosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), and atrial fibrillation with prophylactic apixaban. He had recurrent staphylococcus bacteremia due to infection of an ICD lead and had been treated for the past 6 months with minocycline, 100 mg twice daily. His arms had been purple and bruise-like for several years but turned a near black color 1 month ago. He reported no discoloration of his sweat or urine. He had no history of malnutrition and reported infrequent alcohol use. Physical examination showed dense blue-black skin pigmentation of his forearms, dorsal hands, legs, and dorsal feet, as well as blue discoloration of his sclerae and teeth (Figure 1). He had normal-colored nails and oral mucosa. Laboratory studies showed white blood cell count of 15 800/μL (reference range, 4000-11 000/μL), hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL (reference, 13.5-17.5 g/dL), platelet count of 58 000/μL (reference, 150 000-400 000/μL), and INR of 1.8 (reference, 0.8-1.1). Complete metabolic panel showed increased creatinine (1.51 mg/dL
column2: reference, 0.64-1.27 mg/dL) and elevated total bilirubin (1.7 mg/dL
column3: reference range, 0.3-1.2 mg/dL). His estimated glomerular filtration rate was 40 mL/min/1.73 m2.

column1: ",Minocycline-induced hyperpigmentation," 1. **Minocycline-induced hyperpigmentation**: Minocycline is a known cause of skin hyperpigmentation, particularly in patients with chronic kidney disease. The patient's history of minocycline use and the distribution of the hyperpigmentation are consistent with this diagnosis.

2. **Argyria**: Argyria is a rare condition caused by exposure to silver, which can cause blue-gray discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. The patient's history of ICD lead infection and treatment with antibiotics raises the possibility of silver exposure.

3. **Hemochromatosis**: Hemochromatosis is an inherited disorder of iron metabolism that can cause skin hyperpigmentation, particularly in sun-exposed areas. The patient's history of cirrhosis and elevated bilirubin levels raise the possibility of hemochromatosis.

4. **Wilson disease**: Wilson disease is an inherited disorder of copper metabolism that can cause skin hyperpigmentation, particularly in sun-exposed areas. The patient's history of liver disease and elevated bilirubin levels raise the possibility of Wilson disease.

5. **Addison disease**: Addison disease is a rare endocrine disorder that can cause skin hyperpigmentation, particularly in sun-exposed areas. The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and elevated creatinine levels raise the possibility of Addison disease.

6. **Porphyria**: Porphyria is a group of rare genetic disorders that can cause skin hyperpigmentation, particularly in sun-exposed areas. The patient's history of liver disease and elevated bilirubin levels raise the possibility of porphyria.

7. **Chronic kidney disease–associated hyperpigmentation**: Chronic kidney disease can cause skin hyperpigmentation, particularly in patients with advanced disease. The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and elevated creatinine levels raise the possibility of chronic kidney disease–associated hyperpigmentation.

8. **Cirrhosis-associated hyperpigmentation**: Cirrhosis can cause skin hyperpigmentation, particularly in patients with advanced disease. The patient's history of cirrhosis and elevated bilirubin levels raise the possibility of cirrhosis-associated hyperpigmentation.

9. **Methemoglobinemia**: Methemoglobinemia is a rare condition caused by exposure to certain medications or chemicals that can cause blue discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. The patient's history of minocycline use raises the possibility of methemoglobinemia.

10. **Pseudocholinesterase deficiency**: Pseudocholinesterase deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that can cause skin hyperpigmentation, particularly in sun-exposed areas. **Final diagnosis:** Minocycline-induced hyperpigmentation. The patient's skin hyperpigmentation resolved after discontinuation of minocycline therapy. The patient's skin returned to its baseline purple color, and his scleral and dental discoloration resolved. The patient's creatinine and bilirubin levels remained stable, and his liver disease remained well controlled. The patient's ICD lead infection was treated with antibiotics, and he underwent successful lead extraction. He was transitioned to alternative antibiotics and has remained free of infection. The patient's skin hyperpigmentation has not recurred.

A 63-year-old woman was referred by optometry after waking up with cloudy vision in the left eye and an ache around the left brow. Visual acuity was 20/20 OD and light perception OS. Intraocular pressure (IOP) was 15 mm Hg OD and 54 mm Hg OS. Anterior segment examination of the left eye was remarkable for a large cystic iris stromal lesion from the 2- to 7-o’clock position with iris-cornea touch. The anterior chamber was shallow in the area of the enlarged cystic lesion with a large amount of pigmented cells. The pupil was irregular with blood at the pupillary margin. Her intraocular lens was not visible because of occlusion by a cystic lesion behind the iris (Figure 1). Her ocular history was notable for indiscriminate trauma to her left eye, primary open-angle glaucoma in both eyes treated with dorzolamide hydrochloride and brimonidine tartrate, and pseudophakia in both eyes. Four years prior, an inferior cystic iris stromal lesion was discovered in the left eye that measured approximately 5 × 2 mm in basal dimensions at the slitlamp. Fine-needle aspiration was negative for malignancy, and the lesion was managed by close follow-up.
",Secondary angle-closure glaucoma due to sudden enlargement of a cystic iris stromal lesion," 1. Iris melanoma

The patient presented with a large cystic iris stromal lesion that had grown significantly since the last examination. The lesion was causing iris-cornea touch and angle closure glaucoma. The patient had a history of trauma to the left eye, which may have contributed to the growth of the lesion. The differential diagnosis includes iris melanoma, iris cyst, iris abscess, iris metastasis, iris lymphoma, iris granuloma, iris foreign body, iris neovascularization, iris implantation cyst, and iris hemorrhage. Iris melanoma is the top differential diagnosis because of the rapid growth of the lesion and the presence of blood at the pupillary margin. Iris cyst is the second differential diagnosis because of the cystic appearance of the lesion. Iris abscess is also a possibility because of the presence of blood at the pupillary margin and the rapid growth of the lesion. Iris metastasis, iris lymphoma, and iris granuloma are also possible differential diagnoses because of the rapid growth of the lesion. Iris foreign body is a less likely differential diagnosis because there is no history of recent trauma. Iris neovascularization and iris implantation cyst are also less likely differential diagnoses because of the cystic appearance of the lesion. Iris hemorrhage is the least likely differential diagnosis because of the cystic appearance of the lesion and the presence of blood at the pupillary margin. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy or excisional biopsy of the lesion would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis. The patient was referred to an ocular oncologist for further evaluation and management.
