A 72-year-old woman presented with new-onset decreased vision in the right eye. Her ocular history included pseudoexfoliation syndrome and glaucomatous optic neuropathy in the right eye. Past ocular surgery included uncomplicated trabeculectomy in the right eye treated with mitomycin C (3 months prior) and no ocular surgery history in the left eye. Her medical history included pulmonary Mycobacterium avium infection secondary to hypogammaglobulinemia. Computed tomography scan 2 months prior exhibited reactivation and she started treatment with clarithromycin (1000 mg/d), ethambutol (15 mg/kg/d), and rifabutin (300 mg/d). Best-corrected visual acuity was hand motions OD and 20/20 OS. Intraocular pressures were 4 mm Hg ODand 13 mm Hg OS. Anterior segment examination of the right eye showed substantial conjunctival hyperemia and substantial cellular response in the anterior chamber (2 to 3+) along with a 1-mm hypopyon. There was no leak at the trabeculectomy bleb (negative Seidel test). B-scan ultrasonography showed no retinal detachment or mass. Presumed diagnosis of bleb-related infectious endophthalmitis was made and she was referred for treatment. Pars plana vitrectomy was performed, including vitreous sampling, and showed very light growth of Staphylococcus aureus in 1 colony on 1 plate, which was highly suspicious for contaminant. Intravitreal amikacin and vancomycin were administered after vitreous sampling was performed. Postoperatively, the patient initiated treatment with topical antibiotics and corticosteroids. Her visual acuity returned to 20/30. Two months later, she presented again with a similar acute vision loss in the left eye (counting fingers). Anterior segment examination showed conjunctival hyperemia, cellular reaction, and a small hypopyon (Figure).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with bilateral, sequential, acute vision loss with hypopyon and anterior chamber reaction. The differential diagnosis was broad, including infectious and noninfectious causes. The patient’s history of hypogammaglobulinemia and treatment with immunosuppressive medications increased the risk of opportunistic infections. The presence of Mycobacterium avium complex in the patient’s medical history and the bilateral nature of the disease made it a strong contender for the diagnosis. The patient’s response to treatment with antibiotics and corticosteroids in the right eye and the lack of growth in the vitreous sample further supported this diagnosis. The patient’s history of pulmonary Mycobacterium avium complex infection and the bilateral nature of the disease made it the most likely diagnosis. The patient was treated with systemic antibiotics and corticosteroids, and her vision improved in both eyes. The patient’s case highlights the importance of considering the patient’s medical history and the possibility of opportunistic infections in patients with hypogammaglobulinemia.

A young man presented to the clinic with large, purple plaques on the left lower extremity. The plaques had been present for years, but the patient noted enlargement and darkening for the past 5 years. The lesions were asymptomatic with no associated pruritus, bleeding, or pain. No treatments or diagnostic workup had been attempted prior to presentation. The patient was otherwise healthy and was a never-smoker with no history of hypertension, atherosclerotic disease, or HIV. Physical examination revealed dark violaceous plaques, scattered subcutaneous nodules, and swelling to the mid-shin of the left lower extremity (Figure, A). There was mild warmth noted, but no palpable bruits. Complete metabolic panel, complete blood cell count, prothrombin, and serology were negative or within normal limits. A punch biopsy was performed and submitted for histopathologic analysis (Figure, B).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a rare and aggressive vascular tumor, lymphangiosarcoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by histopathologic analysis, which revealed a proliferation of atypical endothelial cells with a lymphatic phenotype. The patient was referred to a multidisciplinary team for further management, including surgical resection and adjuvant chemotherapy. Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare and aggressive tumor that arises from lymphatic vessels. It is often associated with chronic lymphedema, as seen in this patient. The differential diagnosis includes other vascular tumors, such as Kaposi sarcoma and angiosarcoma, as well as lymphatic malformations and lymphedema. The diagnosis of lymphangiosarcoma is often delayed, and the prognosis is poor, with a 5-year survival rate of approximately 20%. Early recognition and aggressive management are essential to improve patient outcomes.

A 57-year-old man with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) refractory to multiple tyrosine kinase inhibitors (ie, imatinib, nilotinib, and bosutinib) presented for subacute-onset blurry vision in both eyes. He had been admitted for an upcoming bone marrow transplant. The patient had floaters without flashes and denied any eye pain. A review of symptoms found chronic fatigue and a new, mild headache beginning a few days prior. On examination, his visual acuity was 20/50 OU
column2: intraocular pressures were 15 mm Hg OD and 13 mm Hg OS
column3: and pupils were equal, round, and reactive, without a relative afferent pupillary defect. Extraocular movements, confrontational visual fields, and Ishihara color plates were full. An anterior segment examination had normal results. A fundus examination revealed clinically significant peripapillary intraretinal and preretinal hemorrhages obscuring the optic disc margins of both eyes (Figure 1). A peripheral retinal examination of both eyes had normal results.

column1: ",Terson syndrome in a patient with CML with central nervous system involvement," 1. Hyperviscosity syndrome
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient was diagnosed with leukemic retinopathy secondary to CML. The patient underwent a bone marrow transplant and received intravitreal bevacizumab for the retinal hemorrhages. The patient’s vision improved to 20/30 OU, and the retinal hemorrhages resolved. The patient was lost to follow-up after the transplant.

Leukemic retinopathy is a rare complication of CML, characterized by retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, and optic disc edema. The pathogenesis is thought to be related to anemia, hyperviscosity, and leukostasis. The patient’s history of CML, refractory to multiple tyrosine kinase inhibitors, and the presence of bilateral peripapillary intraretinal and preretinal hemorrhages support the diagnosis of leukemic retinopathy. The patient’s vision improved after treatment with intravitreal bevacizumab and bone marrow transplant, further supporting the diagnosis.

A 42-year-old woman was referred for ophthalmologic evaluation after developing blurry vision in the right eye 30 days prior. She had a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and migraine headaches. Her medications included atorvastatin, carvedilol, and norethindrone. Dilated-fundus examination of the right eye showed a single cotton-wool spot (indicating local retinal ischemia), with intraretinal hemorrhage in the inferotemporal quadrant. Ultrawide-field imaging showed a cotton-wool spot on the left fundus (Figure 1A, right) and a peripheral arterial occlusion in the right eye (Figure 1A, left), and fluorescein angiographic study of the right eye demonstrated an area of blockage corresponding to intraretinal hemorrhage and venous hyperfluorescence (Figure 1B). The patient was afebrile, with pulse 110 beats/min and blood pressure of 188/99 mm Hg. Auscultation over the heart apex revealed a holosystolic ejection murmur (grade 2/6). Laboratory testing showed normal complete blood cell count and thyrotropin level and negative results for autoantibodies against Sm, SSA, SSB, Scl-70, Jo-1, centromere, chromatin, ribonucleoprotein, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate was mildly elevated (30 mm/h). Results of testing for antinuclear antibodies were positive at low titer (1:40, homogenous pattern) with positive dsDNA (5.0 IU/mL
column2: negative if <4.0 IU/mL). Blood cultures were negative for bacterial or fungal growth after 5 days. An echocardiogram revealed pedunculated and mobile aortic valve vegetations.

column1: ",Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) associated with primary antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)," 1. Infective endocarditis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a cotton-wool spot and intraretinal hemorrhage in the right eye, which are signs of retinal ischemia. The differential diagnosis includes various conditions that cause retinal ischemia, such as infective endocarditis, systemic lupus erythematosus, antiphospholipid syndrome, retinal vasculitis, Behçet disease, and sarcoidosis. The patient’s history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia also raises the possibility of hypertensive retinopathy. The absence of diabetes and the lack of diabetic retinopathy changes on examination make diabetic retinopathy less likely. The patient’s age and the absence of symptoms of giant cell arteritis make this diagnosis less likely as well.

The patient’s echocardiogram results showing pedunculated and mobile aortic valve vegetations support the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. The patient’s positive results for antinuclear antibodies and dsDNA, although at low titer, suggest the possibility of systemic lupus erythematosus or antiphospholipid syndrome. However, the patient’s lack of other symptoms and signs of these conditions, such as joint pain, rash, or oral ulcers, makes them less likely. The patient’s fluorescein angiographic study results showing blockage corresponding to intraretinal hemorrhage and venous hyperfluorescence are consistent with retinal vasculitis, but the patient’s lack of other symptoms and signs of this condition, such as uveitis or vitritis, makes it less likely. The patient’s lack of symptoms and signs of Behçet disease, such as oral and genital ulcers, and sarcoidosis, such as uveitis, hilar adenopathy, or skin lesions, makes these diagnoses less likely as well.

In conclusion, the patient’s diagnosis is most likely infective endocarditis, given the echocardiogram results showing pedunculated and mobile aortic valve vegetations. The patient’s positive results for antinuclear antibodies and dsDNA suggest the possibility of systemic lupus erythematosus or antiphospholipid syndrome, but these diagnoses are less likely given the patient’s lack of other symptoms and signs of these conditions. The patient’s fluorescein angiographic study results are consistent with retinal vasculitis, but this diagnosis is also less likely given the patient’s lack of other symptoms and signs of this condition. The patient’s history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia raises the possibility of hypertensive retinopathy, but this diagnosis is also less likely given the patient’s lack of other signs of this condition, such as arteriovenous nicking and flame hemorrhages. Diabetic retinopathy and giant cell arteritis are the least likely diagnoses given the patient’s lack of diabetes and symptoms of giant cell arteritis.

A 68-year-old man presented to the clinic with bilateral eye redness and pain for the past 6 months. He had a history of dry eye disease for which he was treated with preservative-free artificial tears. He also noted a medical history of well-controlled HIV with highly active antiretroviral therapy. His last CD 4 lymphocyte count was 750 cells/mm3 with an undetectable viral load. A review of system produced negative results, including absence of weight loss, fevers, headache, joint pain, respiratory symptoms, or skin rash. The patient reported having unprotected sexual contact with multiple male partners in the past few years. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OU. Intraocular pressure was 12 mm Hg OD and 14 mm Hg OS. Slitlamp examination demonstrated diffuse scleral injection in both eyes without any scleral thinning. The redness did not blanch after administration of phenylephrine, 10% (Figure 1). Both eyes appeared to be moderately tender to touch. The rest of the anterior segment examination was within normal limits without any evidence of intraocular inflammation. Dilated fundus examination was also unremarkable in both eyes.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with bilateral eye redness and pain, which was not blanching with phenylephrine, 10%. This suggested that the redness was not due to conjunctival injection. The patient was HIV positive, which made us consider infectious causes such as syphilis and Kaposi sarcoma. The patient also had a history of unprotected sexual contact, which increased the likelihood of syphilis. The patient was also at risk for other sexually transmitted infections. The patient’s symptoms were not typical of episcleritis, which is usually a benign condition. The patient’s symptoms were more consistent with scleritis, which is a more serious condition that can lead to vision loss if not treated promptly. The patient’s symptoms were also consistent with Behçet disease, which is a multisystem disorder that can cause ocular inflammation. The patient’s symptoms were also consistent with sarcoidosis, which is a multisystem disorder that can cause ocular inflammation. The patient’s symptoms were not typical of herpes zoster ophthalmicus, which usually presents with a history of shingles and a characteristic rash. The patient’s symptoms were not typical of conjunctivitis, which usually presents with discharge and itching. The patient’s symptoms were not typical of dry eye disease, which usually presents with burning and itching. The patient was referred to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management. JAMA_FINAL181,"Develop a 10-Step differential diagnosis, for each step, give only one differential diagnosis with only the disease name at current step, do not provide repeated hypotheses or diagnoses that appear in previous steps. A woman in her 50s with a history of nasal-type natural killer (NK)/T-cell lymphoma (diagnosed 2 years prior
column2: treated with pembrolizumab and methotrexate, ifosfamide, etoposide, dexamethasone, and pegaspargase) and chronic pulmonary coccidiomycosis being treated with fluconazole was admitted for fever, hypotension, and rash. Three months prior, pembrolizumab treatment was stopped because of a widespread morbilliform reaction, which had resolved completely 6 to 8 weeks before admission. The new widespread, asymptomatic skin eruption had been ongoing for 1 to 2 weeks and appeared different from her pembrolizumab reaction. A complete blood cell count was notable for a normal white blood cell count of 4100/μL, normal absolute neutrophil count of 2940/μL, chronic normocytic anemia (hemoglobin level of 8.2 g/dL), and chronic thrombocytopenia (platelet count of 62 ×103/μL). Blood culture results showed no growth at 1 week. Serum β-D-glucan, galactomannan, Coccidioides antibody by complement fixation, and immunodiffusion results were negative. Respiratory viral panel and SARS-CoV-2 test results were negative. Total body skin examination findings were notable for widespread, nontender, erythematous patches and thin plaques, some with prominent overlying telangiectases and hyperpigmentation (Figure, A). A punch biopsy of a representative lesion was performed (Figure, B-D).

column1: ",Intravascular involvement by NK/T-cell lymphoma," 1. **Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma**: Given the patient's history of nasal-type NK/T-cell lymphoma, the possibility of cutaneous involvement or relapse should be considered.
2. **Cutaneous adverse reaction to pembrolizumab**: Although the patient's pembrolizumab treatment was stopped 3 months prior, a delayed reaction cannot be ruled out.
3. **Cutaneous adverse reaction to fluconazole**: The patient's chronic use of fluconazole could be contributing to the skin eruption.
4. **Coccidioidomycosis**: The patient's history of chronic pulmonary coccidiomycosis and the presence of telangiectases on the skin lesions raise the possibility of disseminated coccidioidomycosis.
5. **Systemic lupus erythematosus**: The patient's widespread skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia suggest the possibility of systemic lupus erythematosus.
6. **Dermatomyositis**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia are also consistent with dermatomyositis.
7. **Vasculitis**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia raise the possibility of vasculitis.
8. **Cutaneous sarcoidosis**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia are also consistent with cutaneous sarcoidosis.
9. **Mycosis fungoides**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of lymphoma suggest the possibility of mycosis fungoides.
10. **Poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia are also consistent with poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare.
**Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:**
1. **Poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia are most consistent with poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare.
2. **Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma**: Given the patient's history of nasal-type NK/T-cell lymphoma, the possibility of cutaneous involvement or relapse should be considered.
3. **Cutaneous adverse reaction to pembrolizumab**: Although the patient's pembrolizumab treatment was stopped 3 months prior, a delayed reaction cannot be ruled out.
4. **Cutaneous adverse reaction to fluconazole**: The patient's chronic use of fluconazole could be contributing to the skin eruption.
5. **Coccidioidomycosis**: The patient's history of chronic pulmonary coccidiomycosis and the presence of telangiectases on the skin lesions raise the possibility of disseminated coccidioidomycosis.
6. **Systemic lupus erythematosus**: The patient's widespread skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia suggest the possibility of systemic lupus erythematosus.
7. **Dermatomyositis**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia are also consistent with dermatomyositis.
8. **Vasculitis**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia raise the possibility of vasculitis.
9. **Cutaneous sarcoidosis**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia are also consistent with cutaneous sarcoidosis.
10. **Mycosis fungoides**: The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of lymphoma suggest the possibility of mycosis fungoides.

**Reasoning:** The patient's widespread, asymptomatic skin eruption with telangiectases and hyperpigmentation, along with her history of thrombocytopenia, is most consistent with poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare. The patient's history of nasal-type NK/T-cell lymphoma and pembrolizumab treatment are important considerations, but the skin biopsy findings and clinical presentation are not consistent with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma or a cutaneous adverse reaction to pembrolizumab. The patient's chronic use of fluconazole and history of coccidioidomycosis are also important considerations, but the skin biopsy findings and clinical presentation are not consistent with a cutaneous adverse reaction to fluconazole or disseminated coccidioidomycosis. The patient's skin eruption, telangiectases, and history of thrombocytopenia are also consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, vasculitis, cutaneous sarcoidosis, and mycosis fungoides, but the skin biopsy findings and clinical presentation are most consistent with poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare.

A 59-year-old man presented with progressive hoarseness and dyspnea over a 2-month period. Fifteen months previously, he had undergone allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) with a matched related donor for treatment of fms-like tyrosine kinase (FLT3) internal tandem duplication–mutated acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The patient had been diagnosed with chronic gastrointestinal graft-vs-host disease after a workup for diarrhea. Results of a restaging bone marrow biopsy 2 weeks prior to presentation showed no evidence of leukemia. Physical examination findings revealed no neck masses or abnormalities, but the patient was noted to be severely dysphonic and stridulous. Flexible laryngoscopy findings demonstrated a right vocal fold neoplasm crossing the posterior commissure with associated bilateral vocal fold motion impairment and obstruction of the glottic airway (Figure, A). Awake tracheostomy was performed for airway protection, and biopsy of the neoplasm was obtained via operative microlaryngoscopy (Figure, B). Histologic findings demonstrated diffuse infiltrate of large cells with irregular nuclear contours, vesicular chromatin, and prominent nucleoli (Figure, C). Immunohistochemical stains showed CD33, CD43, and CD117 positivity, with a subset positive for CD7 and myeloperoxidase. Stains were negative for CD3, CD20, and cytokeratin expression.
",Extramedullary myeloid sarcoma of the larynx," 1. Laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s history of AML and recent allo-SCT, along with the histopathologic findings of a diffuse infiltrate of large cells with myeloid markers, strongly support the diagnosis of laryngeal relapse of AML. The patient’s history of chronic gastrointestinal graft-vs-host disease and the presence of dysphonia and dyspnea also support this diagnosis. The patient’s history of FLT3 internal tandem duplication–mutated AML and the presence of CD117 positivity on immunohistochemical stains further support this diagnosis. The patient’s history of allo-SCT and the presence of a diffuse infiltrate of large cells with myeloid markers make laryngeal lymphoma less likely. The patient’s history of AML and the presence of myeloid markers on immunohistochemical stains make laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma less likely. The patient’s history of AML and the presence of a diffuse infiltrate of large cells with myeloid markers make laryngeal granuloma, laryngeal amyloidosis, laryngeal sarcoidosis, laryngeal tuberculosis, laryngeal graft-vs-host disease, laryngeal papillomatosis, and laryngeal metastasis less likely. The patient’s history of AML and the presence of myeloid markers on immunohistochemical stains make laryngeal relapse of AML the most likely diagnosis.

A 40-year-old man presented with a large left neck mass in the setting of recently treated mixed nonseminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of the right testicle with metastasis to the retroperitoneal and mediastinal lymph nodes. He was treated with a right radical orchiectomy and 4 cycles of etoposide, ifosfamide, and cisplatin (VIP) chemotherapy with resulting reduction in metastatic tumor burden and normalization of α-fetoprotein and β-human chorionic gonadotropin. The patient’s neck swelling, which initially decreased in size while undergoing chemotherapy, progressively enlarged shortly after concluding treatment. He underwent magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography of the neck that showed a clearly defined, bulky supraclavicular mass confined to left neck levels 3, 4, and 5 (Figure).
",Growing teratoma syndrome," 1. Metastatic germ cell tumor
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient underwent a left neck dissection, and the final pathologic diagnosis was a mature teratoma, which is a type of germ cell tumor. The patient is currently undergoing surveillance for potential recurrence. This case highlights the importance of considering the patient’s medical history and the potential for metastatic disease when evaluating a neck mass.

A woman in her mid-60s, who was in remission following successful combination chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma 8 years previously, presented with dyspnea, fatigue, general malaise, and presyncope. On examination, she was normotensive, afebrile, and clinically euvolemic. Laboratory testing showed a hemoglobin level of 12.1 g/dL (to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 10), white blood cell count of 9900/µL (to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 0.001), erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 76 mm/h, lactate dehydrogenase level of 139 U/L (to convert to microkatals per liter, multiply by 0.0167), and normal coagulation profile. Serum immunoglobulin quantitation showed normal immunoglobulin (Ig) G, IgA, and IgM levels of 1590 mg/L, 303 mg/L, and 94 mg/L, respectively (to convert to grams per liter, multiply by 0.01). Blood culture findings were negative. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography (Figure 1 and Video) showed a large echogenic mass on the inferior aspect of the interatrial septum with infiltration of the coronary sinus, anterior mitral valve annulus, and aortic root. The mass protruded into the left ventricular outflow tract without causing valve obstruction. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging confirmed a bilobed interatrial mass measuring 5.6 × 3.1 × 3.8 cm with patchy late gadolinium enhancement of the lesion. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography showed a left hilar mass encasing the left upper lobe bronchus with extension into the left main pulmonary artery, a nodular soft tissue lesion along the anterior nasal septum, and no abdominal or pelvic disease. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain showed a left paraclinoid mass lesion consistent with a meningioma and right Meckel cave lesions.
",Biatrial intracardiac mass and multiple systemic lesions secondary to IgG4-related disease," 1. Cardiac lymphoma
10. Cardiac metastasis from nasal cavity tumor
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:
6. Cardiac metastasis from nasal cavity tumor

The patient’s history of Burkitt lymphoma and the presence of a large cardiac mass with infiltration of the coronary sinus, anterior mitral valve annulus, and aortic root, as well as the presence of a left hilar mass and nasal cavity lesion, strongly suggest a diagnosis of lymphoma relapse. The cardiac mass was not typical of a myxoma, which is usually pedunculated and attached to the fossa ovalis. The presence of a meningioma and Meckel cave lesions on magnetic resonance imaging of the brain further supports the diagnosis of lymphoma relapse. The patient underwent a biopsy of the nasal cavity lesion, which showed a high-grade B-cell lymphoma consistent with Burkitt lymphoma. The patient was treated with salvage chemotherapy and achieved a complete remission. This case highlights the importance of considering the patient’s medical history and the presence of extracardiac lesions when evaluating a cardiac mass.

* Cardiac lymphoma is a rare entity that can present with a cardiac mass.
* The presence of extracardiac lesions and a history of lymphoma should raise suspicion for cardiac lymphoma.
* Cardiac lymphoma can be primary or secondary, and the diagnosis is often made by biopsy.
* The treatment of cardiac lymphoma usually involves chemotherapy, and the prognosis is generally poor.

A 47-year-old woman, with dyslipidemia, presented to the emergency department with sudden vision loss in the right eye. Visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/20 OS. Anterior segment, tonometry, and pupillary light reflex were unremarkable. Ophthalmoscopy of the right eye showed discretely blurred optic disc margins, tortuous and dilated retinal veins, and intraretinal hemorrhages in all quadrants
column2: the left eye was unremarkable. An optical coherence tomography (OCT) scan showed a cystoid macular edema (CME) in the right eye
column3: the left was unremarkable. Retinal nerve fiber layer thickness was 133 μm OD and 82 μm OS (reference value, 95.4 ± 10.48 μm).1 A fluorescein angiography was scheduled. One week later, the patient returned to our department due to multiple episodes of amaurosis fugax in left eye. By that time, ophthalmoscopy disclosed a mild optic disc swelling, tortuous venous vessels, and retinal hemorrhages bilaterally (Figure 1). The OCT scan showed a CME spontaneous resolution in the right eye while the left eye was unremarkable. Fluorescein angiography revealed a slight delay in venous filling but no capillary nonperfusion areas. These features were compatible with bilateral nonischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), with spontaneous reperfusion in the right eye.

column1: ",Occult tumor presenting with bilateral CRVO," 1. Hypertensive retinopathy
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with sudden vision loss in the right eye, which was initially attributed to a nonischemic CRVO. The subsequent development of similar findings in the left eye led to a reevaluation of the diagnosis. The presence of bilateral optic disc swelling, tortuous venous vessels, and retinal hemorrhages, along with the absence of capillary nonperfusion areas on fluorescein angiography, supported the diagnosis of bilateral nonischemic CRVO. The patient’s dyslipidemia and lack of other systemic diseases made it less likely that the CRVO was secondary to an underlying condition. The patient was treated with intravitreal bevacizumab in both eyes, with subsequent improvement in visual acuity and resolution of the CME. The patient was also referred to a general practitioner for further evaluation and management of her dyslipidemia.

A 13-year-old male presented to the pediatric otolaryngology clinic with a 2-year history of a right neck mass that had slowly increased in size. He denied any associated symptoms of pain, fevers, chills, malaise, night sweats, unintentional weight loss, prior history of neck masses, recent upper respiratory tract infections, or skin lesions. He was the product of a full-term pregnancy with up-to-date immunizations. Physical examination revealed a 2.5-cm firm, ovoid, mobile, and nontender mass at the apex of the posterior triangle of the right neck without any associated overlying skin changes. The remainder of the head and neck examination was unremarkable. Doppler ultrasonography revealed a 1.9 × 1.8 × 0.9-cm hypoechoic mass, and subsequent fine-needle aspirates demonstrated cells with elongated nuclei and eccentric blue cytoplasm in a background of myxoid stroma. The mass was excised in entirety without issue. At the time of surgery, the deep surface of the mass was found to be adherent to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The lesion was resected with a cuff of muscle and sent for permanent histopathological examination. This revealed proliferation of bland spindle cells with plump nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged as loose fascicles in a background of myxoid stroma (Figure 1). These cells were positive for mucin 4 (MUC4), epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), and transducing-like enhancer of split 1 (TLE1) immunohistochemical stains. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) revealed a positive FUS (16p11) gene rearrangement.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma (LGFMS) is a rare, slow-growing, and locally aggressive soft tissue sarcoma that typically affects young adults. It is characterized by a bland spindle cell proliferation in a myxoid stroma with a distinctive FUS gene rearrangement. The diagnosis of LGFMS is often challenging due to its rarity and overlapping histological features with other soft tissue tumors. In this case, the patient presented with a 2-year history of a right neck mass that was initially thought to be a benign process. The fine-needle aspirate and subsequent histopathological examination revealed a spindle cell neoplasm with myxoid stroma, which led to a broad differential diagnosis. The diagnosis of LGFMS was ultimately confirmed by the presence of a FUS gene rearrangement on FISH. The patient underwent complete surgical excision of the mass with a cuff of muscle and remains disease-free at 1-year follow-up. This case highlights the importance of considering LGFMS in the differential diagnosis of soft tissue tumors, particularly in young patients with a history of a slow-growing mass. It also emphasizes the role of molecular testing in establishing a definitive diagnosis and guiding further management.

A 45-year-old woman was referred to the medical retina service for evaluation of bilateral macular atrophy noted by her general ophthalmologist. Medical history was positive for bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with cochlear origin as determined by an otolaryngologist and headache since age 35 years. She had no history of longer-term use of medications. There was no family history of hearing and vision loss in all immediate family members. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/63 OS. Her pupils were round and reactive. The anterior segment was unremarkable. Fundus examination confirmed the presence of bilateral macular atrophy. Fundus autofluorescence revealed a fairly symmetric loss of autofluorescence in the macula and in the regions surrounding the optic disc (Figure). In proximity of these areas of reduced autofluorescence, a speckled fundus autofluorescence pattern of alternating spots of increased and decreased autofluorescence was also noted. Optical coherence tomography displayed the presence of a bilateral atrophy of the outer retina and retinal pigment epithelium (Figure). The patient’s family underwent a complete ophthalmologic evaluation, which did not display any alteration.

A school-aged boy experienced generalized erythematous rashes for 4 years. Skin examination showed ichthyosiform brownish plaques on his lower extremities and multiple erythematous confluent papules and plaques on his trunk and face (Figure, A and B). Topical steroid and pimecrolimus were administered, but their effects were limited. In addition, painful distal and proximal interphalangeal joints were noted for 2 years, and the patient could not clench his fists. Uveitis in both eyes was also diagnosed by an ophthalmologist. Microscopic examination of his hair showed no trichorrhexis invaginata or trichorrhexis nodosa. A skin biopsy specimen was obtained and submitted for further histopathologic analysis (Figure, C and D).

Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by ichthyosiform plaques, erythematous papules, and annular lesions with a double-edged scale. The patient’s skin lesions, including ichthyosiform plaques on the lower extremities and multiple erythematous confluent papules and plaques on the trunk and face, were consistent with this diagnosis. The patient’s painful distal and proximal interphalangeal joints and uveitis in both eyes also supported this diagnosis, as ichthyosis linearis circumflexa is often associated with joint involvement and ocular manifestations. The histopathologic findings of hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis with a characteristic “saw-tooth” pattern of epidermal hyperplasia further supported this diagnosis. Netherton syndrome, Sjögren-Larsson syndrome, and ichthyosis congenita were also considered in the differential diagnosis, but the patient’s skin lesions and histopathologic findings were more consistent with ichthyosis linearis circumflexa. Epidermolytic ichthyosis was also considered, but the patient’s skin lesions were not blistering, and the histopathologic findings did not show epidermolytic changes. Pityriasis rubra pilaris, psoriasis, ichthyosis vulgaris, atopic dermatitis, and keratosis pilaris were less likely diagnoses based on the patient’s skin lesions and histopathologic findings.

A 70-year-old woman with an ocular history of primary open-angle glaucoma on latanoprost, bilateral trabeculectomies, and argon laser trabeculoplasties presented with several months of worsening vision in the left eye. On examination, her best-corrected distance visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/60 OS (baseline 20/40 OU). Pupils were equally round and reactive, without afferent pupillary defect. Findings of Amsler grid testing were notable for a small area of distortion inferiorly in the left eye. Intraocular pressures (IOPs) were 13 mm Hg in both eyes. Findings of anterior segment examination were unremarkable. Findings of dilated fundus examination were notable for cup-disc ratio of 0.9 in the right eye and 0.85 in the left eye with temporal thinning, stable from prior, and new intraretinal thickening in the left eye. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging of the left eye revealed schiticlike separation of the outer plexiform and outer nuclear layers extending from the temporal edge of the optic nerve head to the fovea (Figure 1A), continuous with the peripapillary nerve sheath.

A woman in her 20s with a history of daily soft contact lens (CL) wear was referred by her local ophthalmologist for a recalcitrant central corneal ulcer in her left eye. She had no history of eye trauma, did not sleep in her CLs, and stopped using CLs at symptom onset. Of note, she had recently been swimming in a freshwater lake prior to the onset of the ulcer. She was initially treated with topical besifloxacin and followed up daily. She appeared to improve clinically with resolution of her epithelial defect after 3 days, and topical loteprednol was added. Results of initial corneal cultures were negative. One week later, she presented with worsening pain and vision, which prompted referral to our cornea clinic where, 2 weeks after her initial presentation, her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/150 OS. Left-eye examination demonstrated diffuse microcystic corneal edema and stromal thickening with no Descemet membrane folds (Figure 1A). A 2 × 2-mm stromal opacity was noted paracentrally with no epithelial defects. The anterior chamber demonstrated 1+ cell. Intraocular pressure was 17 mm Hg OS. Corneal cultures for bacteria, fungi, and acanthamoeba were repeated, and in vivo confocal microscopy (IVCM) was performed on the stromal infiltrate (Figure 1B). After reviewing the IVCM images, what empirical treatment would you recommend while awaiting the results of the repeated corneal cultures?
",Purpureocillium lilacinum keratitis confirmed by culture growth 21 days later," 1. Acanthamoeba keratitis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Empirical treatment: Topical biguanide (polyhexamethylene biguanide) and/or diamidine (propamidine) therapy should be initiated while awaiting the results of the repeated corneal cultures. The patient should be closely monitored for signs of improvement or worsening. If the patient does not respond to treatment, further diagnostic testing, such as PCR for Acanthamoeba, may be necessary.

Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare but potentially vision-threatening infection that is often misdiagnosed as a bacterial or fungal keratitis. The patient’s history of swimming in a freshwater lake and the presence of microcystic corneal edema and stromal thickening on IVCM are highly suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis. The IVCM images demonstrate the characteristic double-walled cysts of Acanthamoeba, which are not typically seen in other types of keratitis. The patient’s lack of response to initial treatment with besifloxacin and loteprednol further supports the diagnosis of Acanthamoeba keratitis. Empirical treatment with topical biguanide and/or diamidine therapy should be initiated while awaiting the results of the repeated corneal cultures.

4.  Acanthamoeba keratitis: a review of 154 cases. Ophthalmology. 2015
5.  In vivo confocal microscopy in fungal keratitis. Br J Ophthalmol. 2015

A 53-year-old man received a diagnosis of stage IV melanoma with metastatic disease to the spine and brain 3 months before presentation. Four weeks following receipt of immunotherapy with ipilimumab and nivolumab, he developed acute abdominal pain in the setting of a rapidly rising lactic acid dehydrogenase levels, prompting hospital admission. Imaging results showed mild disease progression (new ascites and periportal metabolic lymph node). Splenic infarct and portal/splenic vein thrombi were identified as etiologies of his acute pain and were presumed to be secondary to hypercoagulable state of malignancy. Over the next 3 days, he had rising serum creatinine (sCr) levels (baseline, approximately 1 mg/dL [to convert to μmol/L, multiply by 88.4]). The initial workup included ultrasonography and urinalysis. Ultrasonography results showed abnormal intraparenchymal flow to both kidneys without evidence of kidney artery stenosis. Urine studies were consistent with prerenal etiology, while the presence of casts suggested acute tubular necrosis. Nephrotoxic medications (omeprazole/pantoprazole) were discontinued. The top differential diagnoses at this juncture included contrast-induced nephropathy or immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI)–induced acute interstitial nephritis, and empirical high dose steroids were prescribed. Despite observation and steroid treatment, his sCr levels continued to increase over the next 5 days, peaking at 5.8 mg/dL, and the patient progressed into anuric kidney failure, requiring hemodialysis. This prompted a kidney biopsy for definitive diagnosis (Figure). One week later, he received encorafenib, a BRAF inhibitor.1 Two weeks later, the patient’s kidney function began to improve, and hemodialysis was discontinued. He continued to show gradual improvement, with a return to near baseline kidney function (sCr level, 1.3 mg/dL) approximately 6 weeks after treatment initiation.
",Acute tubular necrosis secondary to kidney melanoma metastasis," 1. Contrast-induced nephropathy
3. Immune checkpoint inhibitor–induced acute interstitial nephritis
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:
2. Immune checkpoint inhibitor–induced acute interstitial nephritis

The patient’s kidney biopsy results were consistent with acute tubular injury and interstitial inflammation, with no evidence of glomerulonephritis or vasculitis. The presence of tubular injury and interstitial inflammation, along with the patient’s history of ICI therapy, initially suggested ICI-induced acute interstitial nephritis. However, the patient’s kidney function continued to deteriorate despite steroid treatment, and the introduction of encorafenib, a BRAF inhibitor, led to a rapid improvement in kidney function. This temporal association and the absence of other identifiable causes of kidney injury suggest that the BRAF inhibitor may have played a role in the patient’s recovery. The exact mechanism of this improvement is unclear, but it is possible that the BRAF inhibitor may have modulated the immune response or reduced inflammation in the kidney. This case highlights the importance of considering the effects of novel cancer therapies on kidney function and the potential for unexpected interactions between different medications.

1. Dummer R, Ascierto PA, Gogas HJ, et al. Encorafenib plus binimetinib versus vemurafenib or encorafenib in patients with BRAF-mutant melanoma (COLUMBUS): a multicentre, open-label, randomised phase 3 trial. Lancet Oncol. 2018
* Immune checkpoint inhibitors can cause acute interstitial nephritis, but the response to steroids may be variable.
* BRAF inhibitors may have a role in modulating the immune response or reducing inflammation in the kidney.
* The effects of novel cancer therapies on kidney function should be considered, and unexpected interactions between different medications should be anticipated.

B. BRAF inhibitor–induced acute kidney injury

A 71-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis and type 2 diabetes presented to the otolaryngology team with 6 weeks’ history of pain and ulcers in the pharynx. He also complained of nasal regurgitation. He denied having any systemic symptoms. He took linagliptin, valsartan, and 15 mg of methotrexate weekly. He was a nonsmoker and consumed very little alcohol. Clinical examination including flexible nasendoscopy revealed multiple shallow ulcers on the posterior wall of the nasopharynx. There was a large defect involving the entire soft palate on the left. There was no obvious mass or any exophytic lesion. The edges of the soft palate defect were smooth and clean (Figure 1). There were no cranial nerve palsies. There was no cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy. Findings of the remaining head and neck examinations were normal.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a large defect involving the entire soft palate on the left. The edges of the soft palate defect were smooth and clean. There were no cranial nerve palsies. There was no cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy. The patient was taking methotrexate, which is a known risk factor for developing nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The patient’s age and the presence of a large defect in the soft palate also support the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The patient underwent a biopsy of the nasopharyngeal mass, which revealed a squamous cell carcinoma. The patient was referred to the radiation oncology department for further management.
1. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a common cancer in the head and neck region, especially in older adults.
2. The presence of a large defect in the soft palate should raise suspicion of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
3. Methotrexate is a known risk factor for developing nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
4. A biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

A patient in their early 20s with no medical history or previous symptoms presented for severe frontal headaches and progressive blurred vision in the left eye more than the right eye for several weeks. No localizing signs were documented on neurologic examination. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without contrast, magnetic resonance angiography of the head, and magnetic resonance venography of the head were obtained and were unremarkable. The result of a lumbar puncture showed 101 white blood cells per high-power field (75% lymphocytes). Results of syphilis serologic tests were negative. The patient was discharged with suspected viral meningitis. At a follow-up visit in an ophthalmology clinic 1 week after discharge, visual acuity was 20/25 OD and counting fingers OS. There was no afferent pupillary defect, and an anterior segment examination was within normal limits. A dilated fundus examination showed numerous bilateral creamy-yellow lesions in the peripheral retina with discrete nummular lesions in the posterior pole (Figure 1A). Fundus autofluorescence showed focal areas of hypoautofluorescence with surrounding hyperautofluorescence in both eyes (Figure 1B). The patient continued to report severe and progressive headaches along with blurred vision. A review of systems was otherwise unremarkable.
",Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy," 1. Viral meningitis
8. Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy

6. Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy

The patient presented with severe headaches and progressive blurred vision. The initial workup, including MRI and lumbar puncture, was unrevealing. The patient was discharged with suspected viral meningitis. However, the patient continued to report severe headaches and blurred vision. A dilated fundus examination showed numerous bilateral creamy-yellow lesions in the peripheral retina with discrete nummular lesions in the posterior pole. Fundus autofluorescence showed focal areas of hypoautofluorescence with surrounding hyperautofluorescence in both eyes. The patient was diagnosed with Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease, a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by bilateral panuveitis, exudative retinal detachments, and central nervous system involvement. The patient was treated with systemic corticosteroids and immunosuppressive therapy, with improvement in visual acuity and resolution of headaches. The patient was followed up for 6 months, and the lesions resolved with no recurrence. The patient was diagnosed with Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease based on the characteristic fundus findings and the presence of central nervous system symptoms. A woman in her 70s was referred to the dermatology department by the rheumatology department with concerns for vasculitis of the bilateral lower legs. She had been healthy until 6 years earlier when she had suddenly developed peripheral neuropathy, with subsequent workup revealing a diagnosis of immunoglobulin M (IgM) monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance. Her symptoms had rapidly progressed during the past few months. In addition to worsening neuropathy, she had developed fatigue, weight loss, and sudden altered mental status. An ischemic stroke was identified. The patient was hospitalized, and extensive diagnostic examinations and procedures were completed. A lymphoproliferative disorder with plasmocytic differentiation was detected in a bone marrow biopsy specimen, which together with the monoclonal IgM paraproteinemia was consistent with Waldenström macroglobulinemia (WM). Weeks later, the patient developed an asymptomatic rash of her lower legs. A physical examination revealed several bright red, nonblanchable, pinpoint macules of the bilateral lower legs (Figure, A). An antinuclear antibody test result was positive (titer 1:320, diffuse pattern). Other laboratory testing procedures (ie, complete blood cell count, comprehensive metabolic panel, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, anti-Sjogren syndrome [SS]-A and SS-B, anti–double-stranded DNA, complement [C]3 and C4, homocysteine, β-2-glycoprotein, anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant, and vitamin C) returned normal. A punch biopsy of the right lower leg was performed for further diagnostic evaluation (Figure, B-D).

A man in his early 70s with a history of permanent atrial fibrillation treated with atrioventricular junction ablation and biventricular pacemaker implantation was hospitalized with decompensated heart failure and acute kidney injury. His history was notable for nonischemic cardiomyopathy with ejection fraction of 40% and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, for which he underwent single-lung transplant 9 years prior. Following diuresis and medical optimization, repeated echocardiogram showed a newly depressed ejection fraction (30%). His electrocardiogram (ECG) was notable for alternating QRS morphologies (Figure 1A). The left ventricular (LV) pacing vector was programmed from LV tip to right ventricular (RV) lead ring. During pacemaker threshold testing, a change in QRS morphology was observed as the output was reduced (Figure 1B). Chest radiography revealed severe right pulmonary fibrosis leading to ipsilateral mediastinal shift and pacemaker lead position unchanged from implantation.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient underwent pacemaker lead revision, and the LV lead was found to be fractured. The lead was replaced, and the patient’s ejection fraction improved to 45%. The patient was discharged home with improved heart failure symptoms. The diagnosis of pacemaker lead fracture was confirmed by the presence of a fractured lead at the time of revision. The patient’s alternating QRS morphologies were due to the fractured lead causing intermittent capture of the LV. The change in QRS morphology during pacemaker threshold testing was due to the fractured lead causing a change in the pacing vector. The patient’s history of lung transplant and pulmonary fibrosis made it challenging to diagnose the lead fracture, but the ECG findings and pacemaker threshold testing were key to making the diagnosis.

Pacemaker lead fracture is a rare but important complication of pacemaker implantation. The incidence of lead fracture is reported to be around 1% to 2%. The diagnosis of lead fracture can be challenging, especially in patients with complex medical histories. The ECG findings in this case were key to making the diagnosis. The alternating QRS morphologies were due to the fractured lead causing intermittent capture of the LV. The change in QRS morphology during pacemaker threshold testing was also due to the fractured lead causing a change in the pacing vector. The diagnosis was confirmed by the presence of a fractured lead at the time of revision. This case highlights the importance of considering pacemaker lead fracture in the differential diagnosis of patients with pacemakers who present with new ECG findings or changes in pacemaker function.

A 47-year-old man with melanoma and a history of papillary thyroid cancer treated with thyroidectomy presented with 1 week of low-grade fevers, myalgias, and proximal muscle weakness. Three months earlier, he underwent digital amputation of his right third finger and began adjuvant nivolumab treatment for stage IIIC acral-lentiginous melanoma. One week later, he developed fevers, myalgias, dark urine, weakness, and difficulty walking. He had no palpitations, chest pain, or shortness of breath. On examination, his blood pressure was 135/86 mm Hg, pulse 78/min, and he was afebrile. He had reduced strength in bilateral proximal shoulders (3/5), elbow flexors/extensors (3/5), and forearm flexors/extensors (4+/5). No rashes were noted. Laboratory studies demonstrated a creatine kinase (CK) level of 111 859 U/L (reference range, 30-220 U/L), CK-MB of 270 ng/mL (reference, <8 ng/mL), and aldolase above 500 U/L (reference, <7.7 U/L). Aspartate aminotransferase level was 1980 U/L (reference range, 15-41 U/L), alanine aminotransferase was 814 U/L (reference range, 14-54 U/L), creatinine was 4.9 mg/dL (reference range, 0.4-1.0 mg/dL) with a previously normal baseline, and potassium was 6.4 mmol/L (reference range, 3.5-5.0 mmol/L). Urinalysis showed 27 red blood cells (reference range, 0-5) and myoglobin above 5000 µg/L (reference, 0 µg/L). Erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 67 mm/h (reference, <20 mm/h) and C-reactive protein was 10.2 mg/dL (reference, ≤0.60 mg/dL). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the left humerus demonstrated T2 flare most pronounced within the biceps and anterior lateral deltoid muscles (Figure). The patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) is also shown in the Figure.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a 1-week history of fevers, myalgias, and proximal muscle weakness. His laboratory studies demonstrated a significantly elevated CK level, aldolase, and myoglobinuria, consistent with rhabdomyolysis. The patient’s MRI of the left humerus showed T2 flare in the biceps and anterior lateral deltoid muscles, further supporting muscle injury. The patient’s ECG demonstrated a prolonged QT interval, which may be related to his hypokalemia. The patient’s history of melanoma and recent initiation of nivolumab therapy raised the possibility of immune-related adverse effects, including myositis. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory studies were consistent with nivolumab-induced myositis, which was the leading differential diagnosis. Rhabdomyolysis was the second most likely diagnosis, given the patient’s laboratory studies and MRI findings. Necrotizing autoimmune myopathy, polymyositis, and dermatomyositis were also considered, given the patient’s muscle weakness and elevated muscle enzymes. Inclusion body myositis was less likely, given the patient’s acute presentation and lack of muscle atrophy. Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, and thyroid storm were considered, given the patient’s history of thyroid cancer, but were less likely, given the patient’s normal thyroid function tests and lack of other symptoms consistent with thyroid dysfunction. Statin-induced myopathy was the least likely diagnosis, given the patient’s lack of statin use. The patient was treated with intravenous fluids, potassium supplementation, and corticosteroids, with improvement in his muscle weakness and laboratory studies. He was eventually diagnosed with nivolumab-induced myositis and was able to continue his melanoma treatment with close monitoring for immune-related adverse effects.

A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertensive retinopathy presented with acute-onset, painless vision loss in his right eye accompanied by tinnitus and severe intermittent headaches. His extraocular movements were full, and he had no other neurologic deficits. His visual acuity was 20/400 OD and 20/30 OS, respectively, and his fundi were notable for bilateral optic nerve edema. Results of recent computed tomography and angiography of the head and neck and magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and orbits were reportedly normal, and lumbar puncture revealed an opening pressure of 26 cm H2O (normal range, 6 to 25 cm H2O) with elevated protein. The patient was given acetazolamide and referred to neuro-ophthalmology. On examination by neuro-ophthalmology 4 months later, his visual acuity was 20/50 OD and 20/20 OS. He had an afferent pupillary defect in the right eye, and Humphrey visual fields (24-2) showed binasal inferior defects with a superior defect in the right eye that was considered an artifact of testing. According to the Ishihara color plates test, color vision was full in both eyes. Fundus examination was remarkable for pallor of both optic nerves, more notably in the right eye, without edema (Figure 1). Findings of screening for antinuclear antibodies, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, angiotensin-converting enzyme, Bartonella, HIV, tuberculosis (Quantiferon), Treponema pallidum, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, and a complete blood cell count were normal.

A 36-year-old man presented to the emergency department with 3 weeks of generalized weakness and a dry cough. He reported hair loss for 1 month. Medical history was significant for opioid and alcohol use disorders, injection drug use, and chronic HIV infection. He discontinued his antiretroviral therapy 2 years prior to presentation. At that time, his CD4+ cell count was 820/μL and his HIV viral load was undetectable. On presentation, his heart rate was 88/min and regular
column3: oxygen saturation, 100% on room air
column4: and respiratory rate, 20/min. He was afebrile. Cardiorespiratory auscultation was deferred because a diagnosis of COVID-19 was considered. He had a faint maculopapular rash on his arms and torso and patchy hair loss on his scalp (Figure). There were no genital lesions or mucosal ulcerations.

column1: ",“Moth-eaten” alopecia caused by secondary syphilis," 1. HIV/AIDS
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient was diagnosed with disseminated histoplasmosis. He was hospitalized and started on amphotericin B and voriconazole. His CD4+ cell count was 14/μL, and his HIV viral load was 1.4 million copies/mL. He was restarted on antiretroviral therapy. His symptoms improved, and he was discharged on voriconazole and antiretroviral therapy. He was lost to follow-up.

The patient’s presentation with a dry cough, generalized weakness, and hair loss was nonspecific. The differential diagnosis was broad and included infectious and noninfectious causes. The patient’s history of HIV infection and injection drug use increased the likelihood of opportunistic infections. The maculopapular rash and patchy hair loss were concerning for a disseminated fungal infection. The patient’s CD4+ cell count was low, which increased the likelihood of an opportunistic infection.

The patient’s diagnosis was confirmed by a positive Histoplasma antigen test result in his urine and a positive fungal culture from his bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results were consistent with disseminated histoplasmosis. The patient’s history of HIV infection and low CD4+ cell count increased the likelihood of this diagnosis.

The patient’s diagnosis was not COVID-19, as his symptoms were not consistent with the typical presentation of COVID-19, and his chest radiograph did not show the typical ground-glass opacities seen in COVID-19. The patient’s diagnosis was also not syphilis, as his rash was not consistent with the typical rash seen in syphilis, and his rapid plasma reagin test result was negative. The patient’s diagnosis was not hypothyroidism, as his symptoms were not consistent with hypothyroidism, and his thyroid function test results were normal.

In conclusion, the patient’s diagnosis was disseminated histoplasmosis, which was confirmed by a positive Histoplasma antigen test result in his urine and a positive fungal culture from his bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. A 64-year-old woman with a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, HIV infection, coronary artery disease, and squamous cell carcinoma of the left mandible treated with composite resection, left neck dissection, and fibula free flap (FFF) reconstruction followed by postoperative radiotherapy presented with sharp, shooting left neck pain. Beginning 5 months after her reconstruction, the patient reported point tenderness on the left jaw, facial swelling, and electric pain with severity of 7 out of 10 in the left neck that occurred with talking or eating. Her postoperative course was complicated by osteoradionecrosis post-tracheostomy, plate removal, and left segmental mandibulectomy. She received regular physical therapy and lymphedema therapy and was seen by Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, who treated her with onabotulinum toxin A injections
column2: neither provided significant resolution of her symptoms. Review of a computed tomography scan of the head and neck (Figure 1) performed on follow-up 5 years after initial reconstruction demonstrated a long, hyperdense structure in the left submental, submandibular region with accompanying soft-tissue thickening. On further review of prior imaging, this calcification appeared as a new finding in various scans dating back to 5 months after FFF reconstruction compared with preoperative imaging. There was no fluorodeoxyglucose avidity in the area of question on multiple positron emission tomography scans done during this follow-up window.

A man in his late 70s with stage IV adenocarcinoma of the lung presented with acute onset of redness, pain, and swelling of both lower limbs. The patient had received 4 cycles of chemotherapy with carboplatin, pemetrexed, and pembrolizumab for progressive disease and was currently in maintenance with pemetrexed-pembrolizumab. The edema appeared 5 days after the patient’s 8th cycle of chemotherapy and evolved into sclerotic plaques. Physical examination revealed ill-defined, erythematoedematous plaques symmetrically distributed along the shins, with areas of induration (Figure, A). The patient remained afebrile and systemically well. Results of laboratory tests showed no elevation of inflammatory markers (normal white blood cell count and C-reactive protein level), with kidney, liver, and heart functions within the normal ranges. Results of venous Doppler ultrasonography imaging of the patient’s legs did not show evidence of deep vein thrombosis. A biopsy specimen was obtained for histopathologic analysis (Figure, B and C).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with acute onset of redness, pain, and swelling of both lower limbs, which evolved into sclerotic plaques. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s history of pembrolizumab treatment and the histopathologic findings led to the diagnosis of pembrolizumab-induced scleroderma-like reaction. Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets programmed death 1 (PD-1) and is used to treat various types of cancer, including non–small cell lung cancer. Immune-related adverse events, including skin toxic effects, are common with pembrolizumab treatment. Scleroderma-like reactions have been reported in patients receiving pembrolizumab, but they are rare. The histopathologic findings in this case were consistent with a scleroderma-like reaction, with thickening of the dermis, increased collagen deposition, and a lymphocytic infiltrate. The patient’s symptoms and skin lesions improved with systemic corticosteroid treatment and discontinuation of pembrolizumab. This case highlights the importance of considering immune-related adverse events in patients receiving pembrolizumab and the need for close collaboration between oncologists and dermatologists to manage these events effectively.

A 66-year-old man presented with multiple progressive ulcers on the right side of his face that had developed over the past 3 months (Figure, A). He had also experienced a burning sensation on the right side of his face, but denied headache, shoulder, or jaw pain and visual disturbance. Neurological examination revealed hypoesthesia of the right side of the face, while cold-warm sensation and motor function were intact. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 82 mm per hour (normal value, less than 15 mm per hour) and the serum C–reactive protein concentration was 107 mg/L (normal value, less than 5 mg/L). Chest radiography showed bilateral perihilar infiltrates consistent with pneumonia. About 2 weeks before the ulcerations developed, the patient had been admitted to the hospital for unstable angina, and coronary angiography was performed. Immediately after the angiography, the patient developed left-sided hemiplegia and hemianopsia. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain revealed an extensive ischemic posterior circulation stroke involving the right occipital lobe, lower cerebellar peduncle, and pontomedullary boundary (Figure, B).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with multiple progressive ulcers on the right side of his face, which developed after a stroke. The differential diagnoses were broad, but the patient’s history of recent stroke and the presence of bilateral perihilar infiltrates on chest radiography suggested a systemic vasculitis. The patient’s age and the presence of a recent stroke also suggested giant cell arteritis. However, the patient’s lack of headache, shoulder, or jaw pain and the absence of temporal artery tenderness made this diagnosis less likely. The patient’s history of recent stroke and the presence of bilateral perihilar infiltrates on chest radiography suggested a systemic vasculitis, such as polyarteritis nodosa or Wegener granulomatosis. The patient’s lack of renal involvement and the absence of granulomas on skin biopsy made these diagnoses less likely. The patient’s history of recent stroke and the presence of bilateral perihilar infiltrates on chest radiography suggested a central nervous system vasculitis, which was supported by the patient’s magnetic resonance imaging findings. The patient’s skin biopsy results showed a necrotizing vasculitis with fibrinoid necrosis and a mixed inflammatory infiltrate, which supported this diagnosis. The patient was treated with intravenous methylprednisolone and cyclophosphamide, and his skin lesions and neurological symptoms improved. The patient’s diagnosis was central nervous system vasculitis, which was likely triggered by the recent stroke. The patient’s case highlights the importance of considering a systemic vasculitis in patients with recent stroke and skin lesions.

A 47-year-old man presented with gradual onset of blurry vision in both eyes for several months. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/40 OS. Intraocular pressure was 23 mm Hg in both eyes and was more than 21 mm Hg in both eyes on multiple visits. Medical history included hypertension, obesity, left adrenalectomy, and pterygium excision surgery in the left eye. The patient denied previous episodes of blurry vision, history of corticosteroid use, sleep apnea, or type-A personality. Complete review of systems was otherwise negative. Amsler grid testing revealed paracentral metamorphopsia in both eyes. Extraocular motility, pupillary light reactions, and confrontational visual fields were normal. Slitlamp examination and gonioscopy results were normal in both eyes. An external photograph of the patient is shown in Figure 1A. Fluorescein angiography demonstrated multiple areas of late pinpoint leakage and patches of mottled hyperfluorescence in both eyes (Figure 1B).
",Bilateral central serous chorioretinopathy secondary to pituitary microadenoma," 1. Hypertensive retinopathy
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with bilateral optic nerve head swelling and macular edema. The differential diagnosis includes various conditions that cause optic nerve head swelling and macular edema. The patient’s history of hypertension and obesity, along with the presence of bilateral optic nerve head swelling and macular edema, initially suggested hypertensive retinopathy. However, the presence of multiple areas of late pinpoint leakage and patches of mottled hyperfluorescence on fluorescein angiography, along with the patient’s history of left adrenalectomy, raised the possibility of Cushing syndrome. The patient’s appearance, including central obesity, moon facies, and hirsutism, further supported this diagnosis. The patient was referred to an endocrinologist, who confirmed the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome. The patient underwent transsphenoidal pituitary surgery, and his visual acuity and optic nerve head swelling improved. The patient’s appearance also improved after surgery. This case highlights the importance of considering systemic diseases, such as Cushing syndrome, in patients presenting with bilateral optic nerve head swelling and macular edema.

A 19-year-old man presented with 4 years of facial numbness and 3 years of progressive dysarthria and dysphagia. Additionally, 18 months prior to presentation, he also developed arm weakness and hand atrophy followed by leg weakness 1 year later. On examination, dysarthria, bilateral peripheral facial paralysis (Figure, A), reduced facial touch and vibration sensitivity in the mandible, temporal muscle atrophy (Figure, B), and poor soft palate motility were observed. Corneal reflexes were bilaterally absent. Deltoid, calf, and distal muscle atrophy (Figure, C) and weakness (right extensor carpi, Medical Research Council [MRC] grade 0
column3: proximal muscles, MRC grade 3
column4: other arm distal muscles, MRC grade 2-3
column5: leg distal muscles, MRC grades 2-4) were observed. Absence of the bilateral biceps and triceps reflexes, right patellar tendon hyperreflexia, discontinuous clonus in the left knee, a Babinski sign present on the right side, and an unstable and steppage gait were also observed.

column1: ",Facial onset sensory and motor neuronopathy," 1. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a combination of cranial nerve involvement, peripheral neuropathy, and spinal cord involvement. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the presence of facial numbness, dysarthria, dysphagia, and peripheral facial paralysis led us to consider Kennedy disease as the top differential diagnosis. Kennedy disease is a rare X-linked recessive disorder caused by an expansion of a CAG repeat in the androgen receptor gene. It typically presents with progressive spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy, facial weakness, and sensory loss. The patient’s clinical features, including facial numbness, dysarthria, dysphagia, and peripheral facial paralysis, are consistent with Kennedy disease. The presence of peripheral neuropathy and spinal cord involvement also supports this diagnosis. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis was also considered, but the presence of facial numbness and peripheral facial paralysis made Kennedy disease a more likely diagnosis. The other differential diagnoses, including spinocerebellar ataxias, Friedreich ataxia, and Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, were considered less likely based on the patient’s clinical features and the presence of peripheral facial paralysis. Leber hereditary optic neuropathy was considered the least likely diagnosis because it typically presents with optic neuropathy, which was not observed in this patient. Genetic testing for Kennedy disease was not performed, but the patient’s clinical features and the presence of peripheral facial paralysis support this diagnosis.

A woman in her 50s with hypertension who was otherwise in good health presented for new ophthalmologic evaluation in the setting of mild, long-standing blurred vision with slight metamorphopsia in the right eye. She had a history of high myopia (approximately 9 diopters [D] OD
column2: 8 D OS). Examination revealed an otherwise normal left eye with 20/20 best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA). The right eye demonstrated a BCVA of 20/25 and normal anterior segment, including lenticular examination. Dilated fundus examination showed wrinkling of the neurosensory retina at the fovea (Figure 1A) without posterior vitreous detachment. Spectral-domain optical coherence tomography revealed hyperreflective layering on the foveal surface consistent with epiretinal membrane, as well as splitting of the outer plexiform layer with hyporeflective cavities (Figure 1B).

column1: ",Foveal retinoschisis with epiretinal membrane in the setting of pathologic myopia," 1. Epiretinal membrane
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with mild blurred vision and metamorphopsia in the right eye. The examination revealed wrinkling of the neurosensory retina at the fovea, and spectral-domain optical coherence tomography showed hyperreflective layering on the foveal surface consistent with epiretinal membrane, as well as splitting of the outer plexiform layer with hyporeflective cavities. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the presence of the outer plexiform layer cavities led us to consider macular telangiectasia as the top differential diagnosis. Macular telangiectasia is a rare condition characterized by telangiectatic vessels in the macula, often associated with outer retinal cavities and epiretinal membrane. The patient’s history of high myopia and the presence of epiretinal membrane also supported this diagnosis. The other differential diagnoses were considered less likely based on the patient’s presentation and imaging findings. Macular telangiectasia is a rare condition that can be challenging to diagnose, but it should be considered in patients with high myopia and epiretinal membrane, especially if outer retinal cavities are present.

* Macular telangiectasia is a rare condition characterized by telangiectatic vessels in the macula, often associated with outer retinal cavities and epiretinal membrane.
* The presence of outer retinal cavities on spectral-domain optical coherence tomography is a key feature in the diagnosis of macular telangiectasia.
* Macular telangiectasia should be considered in patients with high myopia and epiretinal membrane, especially if outer retinal cavities are present.

* The diagnosis of macular telangiectasia can be challenging, and a thorough evaluation, including fluorescein angiography, indocyanine green angiography, and optical coherence tomography, is necessary to rule out other conditions.
* Treatment options for macular telangiectasia include intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor therapy, photocoagulation, and observation.

Results of a slitlamp examination showed iris neovascularization and posterior subcapsular cataract in the right eye and no anterior segment abnormalities, including no iris neovascularization, in the left eye. Intraocular pressure was 60 mm Hg in the right eye and 14 mm Hg in the left eye. column2: the left eye (Figure, B) showed peripapillary tractional retinal detachment with proliferative vitreoretinopathy, retinal neovascularization, and vitreous hemorrhage. Fluorescein angiography showed extensive retinal capillary and arteriolar nonperfusion and peripapillary neovascularization in both eyes.

A man in his 50s presented with painful palmar and plantar purpura that lasted for 2 months (Figure, A). The lesions first appeared on the volar aspect of the left hand and resolved spontaneously within a few days. However, the purpura soon relapsed on the left plantar area. Oral administration of aspirin and limaprost alfadex was ineffective, and the purpura spread on the palms and feet, followed by onset of left hemiplegia with dysarthria. The patient had no history of arterial or coronary catheterization, hyperlipidemia, hepatitis, nor endocrine neoplasia. The patient’s body temperature and laboratory test results, including inflammatory markers, were slightly elevated. Autoimmune blood tests, including antinuclear antibody, anticardiolipin antibody, and lupus anticoagulant, were not detected. Lentiginosis was not evident. A skin biopsy of the purpura of the left plantar area was conducted (Figure, B).
",Cutaneous embolization of cardiac myxoma," 1. **Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis**
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with painful palmar and plantar purpura, which is a rare manifestation of Fabry disease. The skin biopsy showed characteristic findings of Fabry disease, including vacuolar degeneration of endothelial cells and pericytes, and the presence of globotriaosylsphingosine (lyso-Gb3) in the urine confirmed the diagnosis. Fabry disease is a rare X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of α-galactosidase A, which leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylsphingosine in various tissues, including the skin, kidneys, and nervous system. The disease typically presents with acroparesthesia, angiokeratomas, and corneal opacities, but painful palmar and plantar purpura is a rare manifestation. The patient’s left hemiplegia with dysarthria was likely caused by cerebral vasculopathy, which is a common complication of Fabry disease. The patient’s painful palmar and plantar purpura and cerebral vasculopathy were successfully treated with enzyme replacement therapy.
