Diabetic papillopathy is a rare complication of diabetic retinopathy characterized by optic disc swelling and peripapillary hemorrhages. It is often associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy and is thought to be caused by microvascular changes and inflammation. The patient’s history of diabetes, the presence of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, and the optic disc findings support this diagnosis. Diabetic retinopathy is a common complication of diabetes and is characterized by microaneurysms, hemorrhages, and neovascularization. The patient’s history of diabetes and the presence of microaneurysms and hemorrhages in both eyes support this diagnosis. Central retinal vein occlusion is a common cause of vision loss in patients with diabetes and is characterized by retinal hemorrhages, edema, and venous dilation. The patient’s history of diabetes and the presence of preretinal hemorrhage in the right eye support this diagnosis. Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy is a common cause of vision loss in patients with diabetes and is characterized by optic disc swelling and pallor. The patient’s history of diabetes and the presence of optic disc swelling in the right eye support this diagnosis. Retinal artery macroaneurysm is a rare complication of diabetic retinopathy characterized by a dilated retinal artery and surrounding hemorrhage. The patient’s history of diabetes and the presence of preretinal hemorrhage in the right eye support this diagnosis. Optic neuritis is an inflammatory condition characterized by optic disc swelling and vision loss. The patient’s history of diabetes and the presence of optic disc swelling in the right eye support this diagnosis. Retinal vasculitis is an inflammatory condition characterized by retinal vessel inflammation and vision loss. The patient’s history of diabetes and the presence of retinal hemorrhages in both eyes support this diagnosis. Hypertensive retinopathy is a common complication of hypertension characterized by retinal arteriolar narrowing, arteriovenous nicking, and hemorrhages. The patient’s history of hypertension and the presence of retinal hemorrhages in both eyes support this diagnosis. Optic disc drusen is a benign condition characterized by optic disc swelling and calcified deposits. The patient’s history of diabetes and the presence of optic disc swelling in the right eye do not support this diagnosis. Optic nerve head neoplasm is a rare condition characterized by optic disc swelling and vision loss. The patient’s history of diabetes and the presence of optic disc swelling in the right eye do not support this diagnosis.

A 29-year-old man presented with a 2-month history of rapidly growing, widespread, asymptomatic skin nodules all over his body. He denied having fever, chills, fatigue, night sweats, or weight loss. He had no history of malignant neoplasm or chemical exposure. Physical examination findings demonstrated numerous erythematous, indurated nodules involving the surface of his head, neck, torso, and extremities, without ulceration or scarring (Figure, A and B). Findings of systemic reviews were unremarkable, and there was no lymphadenopathy or peripheral nerve enlargement. column2: absolute neutrophils, 3070/μL, normal range, 1800-8300/μL [to convert cell counts to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001]). column1: Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with widespread, asymptomatic skin nodules, which is a rare presentation. The differential diagnosis was broad, and the diagnosis was challenging. The patient’s skin biopsy specimen showed a diffuse infiltrate of histiocytes with eosinophilic cytoplasm and grooved nuclei, which were positive for CD1a and S-100 protein, consistent with Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The bone marrow biopsy specimen showed a similar infiltrate, confirming the diagnosis. Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare disorder characterized by the proliferation of Langerhans cells, which are a type of dendritic cell. It can present at any age, but most cases occur in children. The skin is the most commonly affected organ, and the lesions can be solitary or multiple. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy or by immunohistochemical staining for CD1a and S-100 protein. The treatment of Langerhans cell histiocytosis depends on the extent of the disease and the presence of organ dysfunction. In this case, the patient was treated with vinblastine and prednisone, and the lesions resolved completely. The patient remains in remission 2 years after diagnosis. This case highlights the importance of considering Langerhans cell histiocytosis in the differential diagnosis of widespread skin nodules, even in adults.

A teenaged girl presented with recurrent episodes of chest and neck palpitations accompanied by headaches for 3 years, with sudden onset and offset. She had no specific medical or family history and had no treatment. A resting electrocardiogram (ECG) while symptomatic showed a wide QRS complex rhythm at a rate of 81 beats per minute (Figure 1A). After a short walk, symptoms disappeared and another ECG was recorded (Figure 1B). Physical examination and transthoracic echocardiography results were normal.
",Spontaneous abnormal automaticity from a left lateral accessory pathway," 1. **Supraventricular tachycardia**
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient's symptoms and ECG findings were consistent with a preexcitation syndrome, specifically Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. The ECG showed a short PR interval and a delta wave, which are characteristic of this condition. The patient's symptoms were likely caused by an accessory pathway that was conducting anterogradely, resulting in a wide QRS complex rhythm. The patient's symptoms resolved with exercise, which is a common phenomenon in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. The patient's normal physical examination and echocardiography results made other causes of a wide QRS complex rhythm, such as ventricular tachycardia or cardiomyopathy, less likely. The patient's symptoms and ECG findings were not consistent with anxiety disorder, hypokalemia, thyrotoxicosis, or pheochromocytoma. Long QT syndrome and catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia were also less likely given the patient's normal QT interval and the lack of a family history of sudden death. Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy was also unlikely given the patient's normal echocardiography results. Supraventricular tachycardia and ventricular tachycardia were possible differential diagnoses, but the patient's ECG findings and symptoms were more consistent with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal amyloidosis. The histopathologic image showed amorphous eosinophilic deposits in the subepithelial stroma of the vocal fold, which stained positively with Congo red and showed apple-green birefringence under polarized light, consistent with amyloidosis. The patient was treated with laser microsurgery and voice therapy, resulting in significant improvement of his voice quality.

Amyloidosis is a rare condition characterized by the deposition of abnormal protein fibrils in various tissues. Laryngeal amyloidosis is a rare form of amyloidosis that can cause vocal fold lesions, leading to hoarseness and dysphonia. The diagnosis is made by histopathologic examination of the lesion, which shows amorphous eosinophilic deposits that stain positively with Congo red and exhibit apple-green birefringence under polarized light. The differential diagnosis includes other conditions that cause vocal fold lesions, such as laryngeal sarcoidosis, granuloma, fungal infection, lymphoma, granular cell tumor, and polyp. The patient’s history of follicular lymphoma and allogeneic stem cell transplant complicated by graft-vs-host disease and treatment with sirolimus and steroids may have contributed to the development of laryngeal amyloidosis.

A 63-year-old woman presented to the clinic with intermittent pain inside her mouth and a progressive decline in oral aperture that had developed over the prior year. She described a burning sensation inside her mouth that worsened with using mouthwash and eating spicy foods. She had no history of cigarette smoking or use of chewing tobacco but had chewed areca nuts for many years while living in India. Currently, she reported chewing areca nuts daily to weekly. Physical examination revealed white-tan plaques on the oral mucosa and thickened buccal mucosae bilaterally (Figure). Her lips and perioral skin appeared healthy, and the interincisal distance, defined as the distance between the tips of the frontal incisors when the mouth is opened as wide as possible, was approximately 25 mm (reference, >35 mm). Examination of a biopsy sample of the lower left labial mucosa revealed subepithelial fibrosis with stromal hyalinization, without epithelial dysplasia or inflammatory changes.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient's history of areca nut use and the presence of white-tan plaques on the oral mucosa and thickened buccal mucosae bilaterally support the diagnosis of oral submucous fibrosis. The biopsy sample showing subepithelial fibrosis with stromal hyalinization without epithelial dysplasia or inflammatory changes also supports this diagnosis. Oral lichen planus is a close differential diagnosis, but the absence of Wickham striae and the presence of subepithelial fibrosis on biopsy make oral submucous fibrosis more likely. Oral squamous cell carcinoma is also a possibility, but the absence of ulceration and the presence of subepithelial fibrosis on biopsy make it less likely. The other differential diagnoses are less likely based on the patient's history and physical examination findings. Burning mouth syndrome is a diagnosis of exclusion and is less likely given the presence of physical findings on examination.

* Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic, debilitating condition characterized by fibrosis of the oral mucosa, leading to trismus, dysphagia, and altered speech.
* The condition is strongly associated with areca nut use, particularly in Asian populations.
* The diagnosis is based on clinical and histopathological findings, including subepithelial fibrosis with stromal hyalinization on biopsy.
* Early detection and cessation of areca nut use are crucial in preventing disease progression and improving treatment outcomes.

A Black woman in her early 70s with a history of coronary artery disease after coronary artery bypass operations, hypertension, and colon polyps presented to oculoplastic surgery with 1 week of progressive right-sided proptosis and headache, described as severe pain radiating to the back of her head. This was associated with right eyelid ptosis and blurry vision. Prior to presentation, an outside ophthalmologist treated her with 1 week of oral prednisone, 20 mg/d, for presumed orbital inflammation with no improvement. She denied additional symptoms. Notably, she described headache and sudden vision loss in the right eye after coronary artery bypass grafting 1 year ago for several days before spontaneous improvement with incomplete resolution. Personal and family histories were negative for malignant neoplasm and autoimmune disease. Examination revealed right-sided uncorrected Snellen visual acuity of 20/60 associated with restricted supraduction, abduction, and infraduction. Pupils were equal in size without a relative afferent pupillary defect, and intraocular pressures were 10 mm Hg OD and 11 mm Hg OS. Visual fields had temporal restriction to confrontation of the right eye. Vision, motility, and visual fields were normal on the left. Pertinent findings included right-sided proptosis of 2 mm, cranial nerve V1 and V2 hypoesthesia, eyelid ptosis with a margin to reflex distance 1 of 0 mm, optic disc pallor, and vessel attenuation. Outside magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) demonstrated an infiltrative mass involving right greater than left orbital apices, the right optic nerve, and right extraocular muscles. There was enhancement of the cavernous sinuses, right pterygopalatine fossa, right sphenoid wing, and right middle cranial fossa dura (Figure 1).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a 1-week history of progressive right-sided proptosis, headache, and blurry vision. The examination revealed right-sided proptosis, eyelid ptosis, cranial nerve V1 and V2 hypoesthesia, and optic disc pallor. The MRI demonstrated an infiltrative mass involving the right orbital apex, optic nerve, and extraocular muscles with enhancement of the cavernous sinuses, pterygopalatine fossa, sphenoid wing, and middle cranial fossa dura. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s history of coronary artery bypass grafting and the MRI findings led us to consider orbital lymphoma, orbital metastasis, and orbital meningioma as the top 3 differential diagnoses. A 60-year-old man presented with a 1-week history of progressive painless diplopia. He had a history of hypothyroidism and dyslipidemia, for which he took levothyroxine and rosuvastatin. He reported no changes in visual acuity or color vision
column2: no ocular pain, erythema, or abnormal discharge
column3: and no headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, ptosis, dysphagia, dysarthria, weakness, numbness, or ataxia. He did not have any constitutional or systemic symptoms. Physical examination showed an isolated limitation of right eye abduction. The remainder of the examination, including visual acuity, pupillary reaction, visual fields, and fundoscopy, was unremarkable. A magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the head showed abnormal thickening and T2 hyperintensity of the right lateral rectus muscle with T1-weighted gadolinium enhancement (Figure 1). Tests for infection and autoimmune disease had negative results.  Computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis did not demonstrate any evidence of malignancy.

column1: Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a 1-week history of progressive painless diplopia. The examination revealed an isolated limitation of right eye abduction. The MRI showed abnormal thickening and T2 hyperintensity of the right lateral rectus muscle with T1-weighted gadolinium enhancement. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the MRI findings were consistent with orbital myositis. The patient was treated with oral prednisone, and his symptoms resolved completely within 2 weeks. The diagnosis of orbital myositis was confirmed by the patient’s response to treatment. Orbital myositis is a rare inflammatory disorder that affects the extraocular muscles. It is characterized by acute onset of pain, diplopia, and limitation of eye movement. The diagnosis is based on clinical findings and imaging studies, such as MRI, which typically show thickening and enhancement of the affected muscle. Treatment usually consists of oral corticosteroids, and the prognosis is generally good. In this case, the patient’s symptoms resolved completely with treatment, and the diagnosis of orbital myositis was confirmed. The other differential diagnoses were less likely based on the patient’s presentation and imaging findings. Tolosa-Hunt syndrome, for example, typically presents with painful ophthalmoplegia, and the MRI findings are more consistent with orbital myositis. Thyroid eye disease is also less likely, as the patient did not have any other signs or symptoms of thyroid eye disease, such as proptosis, lid retraction, or restrictive strabismus. Orbital lymphoma and metastasis are also less likely, as the patient did not have any systemic symptoms or signs of malignancy, and the MRI findings were not consistent with a neoplastic process. Carotid-cavernous fistula and cavernous sinus thrombosis are also less likely, as the patient did not have any signs or symptoms of a vascular disorder, such as a bruit, chemosis, or cranial nerve palsies. Oculomotor nerve palsy is also less likely, as the patient did not have any other signs or symptoms of a third nerve palsy, such as ptosis or pupillary involvement. Multiple sclerosis is also less likely, as the patient did not have any other signs or symptoms of demyelination, such as optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, or other cranial nerve palsies. In conclusion, the patient’s symptoms and imaging findings were consistent with orbital myositis, and the diagnosis was confirmed by the patient’s response to treatment. The other differential diagnoses were less likely based on the patient’s presentation and imaging findings.

He was hospitalized and treated with azithromycin, remdesivir, and dexamethasone despite 3 negative SARS-CoV-2 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test results. Two days after hospital discharge, he presented to the emergency department with recurrent syncope. His temperature was 38.1 °C (100.6 °F)

The patient’s response to treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and antiretroviral therapy supported this diagnosis. The patient’s HIV-1 infection and low CD4 count also made other opportunistic infections, such as tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, and cryptococcosis, more likely. Lymphoma was also a consideration given the patient’s lymphadenopathy and low CD4 count. The patient’s symptoms and radiographic findings were not consistent with COVID-19, and the patient had 3 negative SARS-CoV-2 PCR test results. The patient’s unintentional weight loss and lymphadenopathy made lymphangitic carcinomatosis and Kaposi sarcoma less likely but still possible. Sarcoidosis and coccidioidomycosis were also less likely given the patient’s HIV-1 infection and low CD4 count. The patient’s symptoms and radiographic findings were not consistent with these diagnoses. The patient’s HIV-1 infection and low CD4 count made opportunistic infections and malignancies more likely, and the patient’s response to treatment supported the diagnosis of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

A 58-year-old woman presented with a several-week history of a painless right-sided swelling on her anterior neck. She denied trauma, recent illnesses, respiratory symptoms, dysphagia, oral lesions, hemoptysis, fever, fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats. She had an unremarkable medical history without history of hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism, cancer, chemotherapy, radiation, or tuberculosis. She denied alcohol, tobacco, or current medication use. Her family history included a sibling with sarcoma in their 50s. On examination, a 4.0-cm mobile, nontender right lower anterior neck mass was palpated in a suprasternal location. No lymphadenopathy was noted. Laboratory results showed normal serum calcium levels and leukocyte counts. Initial ultrasonography showed a 4.2-cm solid nodule adjacent to the lower pole of the right thyroid. Computed tomography results of the neck showed a 3.4-cm circumscribed, heterogenous, hypodense, enhancing mass that was abutting the inferior right thyroid and at the right lateral margin of the trachea. The mass was just medial to the right common carotid, causing left lateral displacement of the trachea (Figure 1).

The patient presented with a painless right-sided swelling on her anterior neck. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the location and imaging findings helped narrow it down. The patient underwent surgical excision of the mass, which was found to be a parathyroid adenoma. The final diagnosis was confirmed by histopathological examination. Parathyroid adenoma is a rare cause of neck masses, but it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of a neck mass, especially if it is located in the anterior neck and is adjacent to the thyroid gland. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged home on the first postoperative day. At 6-month follow-up, she was asymptomatic and had normal serum calcium levels. This case highlights the importance of considering parathyroid adenoma in the differential diagnosis of a neck mass, even in the absence of hypercalcemia or a history of hyperparathyroidism.

An 82-year-old with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia and history of past cigarette smoking presented to pulmonary clinic for evaluation of dyspnea that had worsened over the previous 5 years. Two years prior, he was diagnosed with a right lower lobe segmental pulmonary embolism on a computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram after evaluation of shortness of breath. Warfarin was initiated but discontinued after 2 months due to recurrent epistaxis. On presentation to the pulmonary clinic, the patient reported dyspnea with minimal activity, fatigue, lightheadedness, and leg swelling. His temperature was 96.8 °F (36 °C)
column3: heart rate, 73/min
column4: and oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. He appeared frail and had multiple telangiectasias on his lips, tongue, and hands. He had jugular venous distension, a cardiac systolic murmur, right ventricular heave, and bilateral lower extremity edema to the knees. Laboratory testing revealed brain-type natriuretic peptide level of 1333 pg/mL (reference, <100 pg/mL) and hemoglobin level of 12.9 g/dL (reference, 13.9-16.3 g/dL). During a 6-minute walk test on room air, his oxygen saturation decreased to 87%. With oxygen delivered by nasal cannula at 4 L/min, his oxygen saturation was 98%, and he walked 90 m (15% of predicted). An echocardiogram showed a normal left ventricular ejection fraction, moderate-severe right ventricular dilatation, and right ventricular systolic pressure of 60 to 70 mm Hg (reference, 35-40 mm Hg). Findings on an echocardiogram performed 10 years prior were normal.

The patient presented with dyspnea, fatigue, and lower extremity edema. His echocardiogram showed right ventricular dilatation and elevated right ventricular systolic pressure, consistent with pulmonary hypertension. The differential diagnosis for pulmonary hypertension is broad, and the patient’s history of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia and pulmonary embolism made it challenging to determine the underlying cause. The patient’s brain-type natriuretic peptide level was elevated, indicating right ventricular strain. The 6-minute walk test results suggested that the patient had significant functional impairment. The patient’s echocardiogram 10 years prior was normal, suggesting that the pulmonary hypertension was a recent development. The patient’s history of smoking and telangiectasias on his lips, tongue, and hands supported the diagnosis of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. The patient’s history of pulmonary embolism and the presence of right ventricular dilatation and elevated right ventricular systolic pressure on echocardiogram supported the diagnosis of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension. An 11-year-old boy with a medical history of allergic rhinitis presented to the emergency department of a children’s hospital with 2 weeks of painful left-sided neck swelling and fever. He had accompanying night sweats, fatigue, and decreased appetite. Initial physical examination revealed multiple distinct matted, firm left-sided cervical lymph nodes. Laboratory evaluation was notable for leukopenia with a white blood cell count of 3700/µL (to convert to 109/L, multiply by 0.001), a microcytic anemia with a hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL (to convert to g/L, multiply by 10), mean corpuscular volume of 58 µm3 (to convert to fL, multiply by 1), an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level of 548 U/L (to convert to µkat/L, multiply by 0.0167), and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 35 mm/h. Purified protein derivative and infectious mononucleosis testing were negative. A contrast-enhanced neck computed tomography (CT) scan revealed multiple lymph nodes with areas of central hypodensity, and a conglomerate of heterogeneous lymph nodes in the left supraclavicular region (level 5B), measuring approximately 3.7 × 1.4 × 3.6 cm (Figure). The otolaryngology service was consulted, and a left level Va and Vb selective neck dissection was performed.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s presentation with a 2-week history of painful left-sided neck swelling, fever, night sweats, and weight loss raised concern for a malignant process. The presence of multiple matted, firm cervical lymph nodes and a conglomerate of heterogeneous lymph nodes in the left supraclavicular region on CT scan further supported this concern. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s age, laboratory results, and imaging findings helped to narrow the possibilities. The patient’s leukopenia, microcytic anemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase level were concerning for a hematologic malignancy. The presence of central hypodensity within the lymph nodes on CT scan suggested necrosis, which is often seen in lymphoma. The patient underwent a left level Va and Vb selective neck dissection, and the final pathology revealed a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The patient was subsequently treated with chemotherapy and achieved remission. This case highlights the importance of considering a broad differential diagnosis in a patient with a neck mass and the need for a thorough workup, including imaging and tissue biopsy, to establish a definitive diagnosis.

A man in his 20s presented to the dermatology department with a monthlong history of gradually progressing papules and nodules on the face, accompanied by fever, fatigue, and weight loss. On physical examination, multiple pink papules and umbilicated nodules were found on the face (Figure 1A). He had a 5-year history of HIV infection but self-discontinued his antiretroviral treatment due to treatment-related gastrointestinal and neurologic reactions 4 years prior. A biopsy specimen was taken for pathological examination (Figure 1B).

A woman in her 60s with previous breast carcinoma diagnosed 11 years prior, currently in complete remission, presented with pruritic lesions on her upper body. Physical examination revealed more than 10 monomorphous, 5- to 10-mm, pink papules with telangiectasias and white background on dermoscopy, distributed on the chest, arms, and back (Figure 1). There were palmoplantar keratosis and pits. The patient underwent thyroid ultrasonography, abdominal ultrasonography, colonoscopy, and central nervous system magnetic resonance imaging. These explorations revealed 1 Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System (TI-RADS) level 5 lesion, a kidney mass, and more than 100 colonic polyps.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Cowden syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple hamartomas, trichilemmomas, and an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers. The patient presented with multiple trichilemmomas, thyroid lesions, and colonic polyps, which are all characteristic features of Cowden syndrome. The presence of palmoplantar keratosis and pits further supports this diagnosis. Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome is another differential diagnosis that shares some similarities with Cowden syndrome, but it is characterized by fibrofolliculomas, trichodiscomas, and acrochordons, which were not present in this patient. Familial adenomatous polyposis is a differential diagnosis that shares the colonic polyps, but it lacks the other characteristic features of Cowden syndrome. The other differential diagnoses were less likely based on the patient’s presentation and test results. Genetic testing for PTEN mutations would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis of Cowden syndrome.

A man in his 30s with AIDS presented with acute-onset painful scattered umbilicated papulopustules and ovoid ulcerated plaques with elevated, pink borders on the face, trunk, and extremities (Figure, A). The patient also had a new-onset cough but was afebrile and denied other systemic symptoms. Due to his significant immunocompromise, the clinical presentation was highly suspicious for infection. For rapid bedside differentiation of multiple infectious etiologies, a Tzanck smear was performed by scraping the base of an ulcerated lesion and inner aspect of a pseudopustule and scraping its base with a #15 blade. These contents were placed on a glass slide, fixed, and stained with Wright-Giemsa and subsequently Papanicolaou staining to further characterize the changes seen.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The Tzanck smear showed multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass nuclei and margination of chromatin, consistent with HSV infection. The patient was treated with intravenous acyclovir and had a rapid clinical response. The diagnosis was confirmed by polymerase chain reaction for HSV DNA in the lesion. The patient was discharged with oral valacyclovir and close follow-up. This case highlights the importance of bedside diagnostic techniques, such as the Tzanck smear, in the evaluation of patients with acute skin lesions, particularly in the setting of immunocompromise. The Tzanck smear is a simple, rapid, and inexpensive test that can provide valuable information in the differential diagnosis of cutaneous lesions. In this case, it helped to quickly identify HSV infection, allowing for prompt initiation of antiviral therapy and improved patient outcomes.

A 28-year-old woman presented with a 5-day history of painful cervical lymphadenopathy along with fever, nausea, and vomiting. Treatment with antibiotics and corticosteroids was started, without improvement of symptoms. She denied recent travel, sick contacts, or autoimmune disease. Her medical history was significant for α-thalassemia but otherwise noncontributory. On examination, she had tender lymphadenopathy involving right level V. A computed tomography scan of the neck revealed a collection of enlarged, matted nodes without evidence of an abscess. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy showed nondiagnostic reactive lymph nodes. She was subsequently admitted to the hospital, where the lymphadenopathy progressed to the left side of the neck and a skin eruption developed over her face, back, and trunk. Results of an infectious disease and rheumatological workup, including bone marrow biopsy, were negative. Given her persistent symptoms, the ear, nose, and throat service consulted for excisional biopsy. On pathologic examination, the lymph nodes showed extensive coagulative necrosis, apoptosis, and karyorrhectic debris (Figure 1). Cellular components included histiocytes and dendritic cells, with absent neutrophils and hematoxylin bodies.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease is a rare, self-limited, and benign disorder characterized by necrotizing lymphadenitis. It is more common in young women and typically presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, and skin rash. The diagnosis is often made by excisional biopsy, which shows characteristic histopathological features of coagulative necrosis, apoptosis, and karyorrhectic debris. The differential diagnosis includes systemic lupus erythematosus, lymphoma, and other causes of necrotizing lymphadenitis. In this case, the patient’s symptoms and histopathological findings were consistent with Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease, and she was treated with supportive care, with resolution of her symptoms. The diagnosis of Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease is important to recognize, as it can be mistaken for more serious conditions, such as lymphoma, and may lead to unnecessary treatment.

A woman in her 90s presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fever, hemoptysis, and syncopal episodes. She had a history of breast cancer and pulmonary nodules with biopsy findings negative for metastatic disease but positive for granulomatous inflammation. Initial vital signs included blood pressure of 103/66 mm Hg, heart rate of 190 bpm, and temperature of 38.7 °C. Electrocardiogram showed monomorphic ventricular tachycardia with a morphology suggesting right ventricular (RV) origin (Figure 1). In addition to receiving intravenous amiodarone hydrochloride, she had correction of mild hypokalemia (3.1 mEq/L [reference range, 3.5-5.2 mEq/L]
column2: to convert to mmol/L, multiply by 1.0). Successful arrhythmia termination occurred shortly thereafter, and her vital signs remained stable. Chest computed tomographic angiography excluded pulmonary embolism but showed pulmonary nodules and mediastinal lymphadenopathy that had progressed compared with her previous computed tomography. An echocardiogram showed severe RV and left ventricular (LV) systolic dysfunction with multiple areas of hypokinesis.

The patient’s presentation with ventricular tachycardia, hemoptysis, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy raised concerns for cardiac involvement of a systemic disease. The differential diagnosis was broad, and the patient’s history of breast cancer and pulmonary nodules with granulomatous inflammation on biopsy further complicated the diagnosis. The echocardiogram findings of severe RV and LV systolic dysfunction with multiple areas of hypokinesis supported the diagnosis of cardiac sarcoidosis, which was ultimately confirmed by cardiac magnetic resonance imaging and endomyocardial biopsy. The patient was treated with corticosteroids and immunosuppressive therapy, and her ventricular tachycardia was managed with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator. This case highlights the importance of considering cardiac sarcoidosis in patients presenting with ventricular tachycardia and cardiomyopathy, particularly in the setting of extracardiac granulomatous disease.

A 27-year-old woman presented to her primary care physician with primary complaints of headaches and visual-spatial difficulties when driving at night. In addition, the patient described a progressively enlarging lesion on her left scalp, which she had initially noted in high school. She denied any overlying loss of hair, sharp pain, or bleeding from the scalp lesion, and she only reported pain with prolonged pressure. On her scalp examination, a 7-cm ill-defined spongy and pulsatile mass was noted with an overlying gray patch of hair. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain/orbit was initially performed (Figure, A and B), which demonstrated an ill-defined, diffuse, intensely enhancing scalp lesion in the left frontoparietal region with very prominent vascularity and underlying calvarial thickening. No osseous destruction or intracranial extension was present. Subsequent catheter angiography (Figure, C) confirmed the hypervascular mass, supplied via hypertrophied superficial temporal and occipital arteries with marked internal vascularity without direct involvement of the calvarium or intracranial structures. The patient underwent biopsy under general anesthesia
column2: the specimen showed an ill-defined deep dermal/subcutaneous proliferation of spindle cells without significant nuclear pleomorphism or mitotic activity. The lesions stained positive for S100 and SOX10 immunostains.

* Nevus sebaceous of Jadassohn is a benign congenital hamartoma of the scalp that can present with a spongy, vascular, and hairless plaque.
* The lesion is typically asymptomatic and may be present at birth or develop during childhood.
* The diagnosis is often made clinically, but histopathological examination is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
* The differential diagnosis includes other benign and malignant cutaneous tumors, such as dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, hemangioma, and cutaneous angiosarcoma.
* Surgical excision is the treatment of choice, and the prognosis is excellent with complete removal of the lesion.

A woman in her 30s presented for evaluation of asymptomatic erythematous scaly plaques over the face and proximal extremities. The lesions started as an erythematous papule on the face, which had progressed to larger plaques within 10 years. There was involvement of the upper respiratory tract, causing palatal perforation and stridor, necessitating a tracheostomy a year ago. In addition, there was history of wheezing and breathlessness. There was no history of preceding trauma, fever, malaise, joint pain, cough, epistaxis, hemoptysis, or hematuria. Examination revealed multiple well-defined brown erythematous scaly plaques with central scarring measuring 2 × 1 to 8 × 7 cm on the face, arm, and thighs. The patient also had saddle nose deformity, perforation of the hard palate, and necrotic plaques on the ear, causing destruction of ear cartilage (Figure, A and B). There was cervical lymphadenopathy: multiple, nontender, discrete nodes, ranging from 1.5 to 2 cm without any surface changes. The results of sensory examination and peripheral nerve examination were within normal limits. Respiratory examination and chest radiography results were normal. Hemogram showed anemia (hemoglobin, 10.1 g/dL [to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0])
column2: the results of a kidney function test, a liver function test, a fasting blood glucose test, and routine urinalysis were within normal limits. Serologic analysis results for HIV-1/2, antinuclear antibody, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies were negative. Punch skin biopsy was obtained for histopathologic analysis and culture (Figure, C).

column1: Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with asymptomatic erythematous scaly plaques over the face and proximal extremities, with involvement of the upper respiratory tract, causing palatal perforation and stridor. The differential diagnoses were generated based on the patient’s history, physical examination, and laboratory results. The top differential diagnosis was lupus vulgaris, which is a chronic, granulomatous, and necrotizing skin disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The patient’s history of palatal perforation and stridor, along with the presence of necrotic plaques on the ear, causing destruction of ear cartilage, supported this diagnosis. The histopathologic analysis of the skin biopsy specimen showed granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis, which further supported the diagnosis of lupus vulgaris. The patient was started on antitubercular therapy, and the lesions showed significant improvement. The other differential diagnoses, such as sarcoidosis, cutaneous tuberculosis, leprosy, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, relapsing polychondritis, nasal natural killer/T-cell lymphoma, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, Sjögren syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus, were considered based on the patient’s symptoms and signs, but they were less likely based on the histopathologic findings and the patient’s response to antitubercular therapy.

An otherwise healthy 13-month-old male was scheduled to undergo excisional biopsy of a left anterior tongue submucosal intramuscular mass (Figure 1). This firm-to-palpation mass was noted at birth and remained proportional in size with the child’s somatic growth, measuring approximately 1 cm in diameter on presentation. Preoperative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) documented the mass to be uniformly solid and well circumscribed without cystic components or flow voids, hypointense on T2, and hyperintense with homogeneous contrast enhancement on T1. His head, neck, and general examination findings were otherwise normal with no cervical lymphadenopathy or additional masses.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The final diagnosis was congenital granular cell epulis, which is a rare, benign, and self-limiting tumor of the newborn. It is typically located on the alveolar ridge of the maxilla or mandible, but can also occur on the tongue, as in this case. The tumor is composed of granular cells and is thought to arise from the neural crest. It usually regresses spontaneously within the first year of life, but surgical excision may be necessary if it is causing feeding or respiratory difficulties. The diagnosis was confirmed by histopathological examination of the excised mass. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and remains asymptomatic at 1-year follow-up.

A 13-year-old girl with a 7-day history of painless vision loss and central scotoma in her left eye was referred to the department of ophthalmology. Three weeks prior, she had presented with mild fever and flulike symptoms, associated with a severe frontal headache that was mildly relieved by analgesics. Her medical history was positive for relapsing urinary tract infections since early infancy without adequate follow-up. Findings of an ophthalmological examination 1 year prior were reported as normal. At initial examination, she was conscious but somewhat lethargic. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/80 OS. Pupillary light responses, extrinsic ocular motility, anterior segment biomicroscopy, and intraocular pressure were normal in both eyes. Dilated fundus examination revealed a bilateral sectorial macular star that was more extended in the left eye, with retinal veins slightly dilated and tortuous, attenuated arterioles, some juxta and peripapillary nerve fiber layer infarcts, and optic disc edema with marked papillary telangiectasia
column2: in addition, some faint, small, tan-yellow dots were observed at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium in the posterior pole, some of them already grayish and with a hypopigmented halo (Figure 1). Optical coherence tomography displayed elevated optic discs and hyperreflective material in the outer plexiform layer temporal to the optic disc in both eyes and a macular neurosensory detachment in the left eye. Results of visual field testing were normal in the right eye and showed a central scotoma in the left eye.

A 62-year-old healthy man with no recent travel history or sick contacts presented with 2 weeks of midline sore throat without systemic signs, such as fever, myalgia, or rash. A physical examination, including flexible laryngoscopy, revealed cobbling, adherent, thick yellow mucus and ulceration of the uvula (Figure 1A).
**Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:**
1. The patient's symptoms were limited to the oropharynx, with no systemic signs or symptoms.
2. The physical examination revealed a characteristic cobblestone appearance of the uvula, which is consistent with a fungal infection.
3. The patient's history of recent antibiotic use and lack of recent travel or sick contacts made a viral or bacterial infection less likely.
4. The patient's age and lack of immunocompromising conditions made oral hairy leukoplakia and squamous cell carcinoma less likely.
5. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings were not consistent with Ludwig angina or Lemierre syndrome.
6. The patient's lack of recent travel to an area with high incidence of diphtheria made this diagnosis less likely.
7. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings were not consistent with Epstein-Barr virus infection or streptococcal pharyngitis.
8. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings were not consistent with acute tonsillitis.
9. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings were not consistent with herpes simplex virus infection.
10. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings were consistent with a fungal infection, such as candida infection.
1. A thorough physical examination, including flexible laryngoscopy, is essential in evaluating patients with oropharyngeal symptoms.
2. A detailed history, including recent antibiotic use, is important in guiding the differential diagnosis.
3. Fungal infections, such as candida infection, should be considered in patients with oropharyngeal symptoms, especially in the setting of recent antibiotic use.
4. A cobblestone appearance of the uvula is a characteristic finding of fungal infections.

A 64-year-old man with a 2-year history of seizure disorder presented to the emergency department (ED) at an outside hospital with breakthrough seizures. One month prior to his ED visit, he had been treated with oral antibiotics when he presented to an urgent care center with left-sided otorrhea, otalgia, and hearing loss. In the ED, he denied headaches, fever, otalgia, otorrhea, or hearing loss. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain with contrast showed diffuse enhancement and possible coalescence in the left mastoid process with adjacent dural enhancement and sigmoid sinus occlusion. He received intravenous vancomycin and cefepime and was started on a heparin drip before being transferred to our facility. On presentation at our facility, the patient appeared well with normal vital signs. There was no periauricular swelling or erythema. Otoscopic examination showed no inflammation of the external auditory canals, and the tympanic membranes were translucent without evidence of retraction or effusion. Computed tomographic venogram confirmed occlusion of the left transverse and sigmoid sinuses, and computed tomography of the temporal bone showed coalescence of mastoid air cells with erosion into the sigmoid sinus. A 53-year-old woman with a history of stage IVA1 (T4N1M0B2) mycosis fungoides presented with a new 1-month history of hyperpigmentation of the oral mucosa (Figure 1). Examination of the mouth revealed multiple coalescing painless nonpruritic black macules and patches on the tongue, roof of the mouth, and buccal mucosa. Examination of the skin was notable for erythematous and hyperpigmented patches covering 90% of the body surface area, consistent with her known mycosis fungoides. Other notable findings on examination were 1- to 2-cm lymphadenopathy in the bilateral inguinal folds and axillae. Review of systems was notable for fatigue. The patient’s history of mycosis fungoides and the presence of lymphadenopathy raised the possibility of an underlying malignancy, such as oral melanoma or oral Kaposi sarcoma. The patient’s history of receiving pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride also raised the possibility of oral fixed drug eruption. The patient’s examination findings were not consistent with oral lichen planus, oral melanoacanthoma, or oral melanotic macule. The patient’s laboratory results, including a normal complete blood cell count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and iron studies, made oral hemochromatosis and oral Addison disease less likely. The patient’s examination findings were not consistent with oral acanthosis nigricans. A biopsy of the oral mucosa was performed, and the results showed atypical melanocytes with pagetoid spread, consistent with oral melanoma. The patient was referred to an otolaryngologist for further evaluation and management.
* Oral melanoma is a rare and aggressive malignancy that can present with hyperpigmentation of the oral mucosa.
* A thorough history and physical examination are essential in evaluating patients with oral hyperpigmentation.
* A biopsy of the oral mucosa is necessary to establish a diagnosis of oral melanoma.
* The differential diagnosis of oral hyperpigmentation is broad and includes benign and malignant conditions.

The patient’s symptoms, laboratory results, and imaging findings were consistent with echinococcosis multilocularis. The patient’s history of close contact with dogs, cattle, and sheep, and the presence of liver cysts, supported this diagnosis. The patient was treated with albendazole and underwent surgical resection of the lung and liver cysts. Pathological examination of the resected specimens confirmed the diagnosis of echinococcosis multilocularis. The patient recovered well after surgery and was discharged from the hospital. Echinococcosis multilocularis is a rare parasitic disease caused by Echinococcus multilocularis, which is usually found in the liver and lungs. It is endemic in some parts of the world, including China. The disease can cause a variety of symptoms, including cough, chest pain, and abdominal pain, and can be diagnosed by imaging studies and serological tests. Surgical resection and antiparasitic treatment are the mainstays of treatment. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

A previously healthy individual in his 20s presented to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of annular skin lesions that appeared first on his right ankle and then on other areas of his body over a 3-month period. He reported numbness and paresthesia in the areas of affected skin and an inability to fully extend his fingers. The patient did not take any prescription medications or herbal supplements and had immigrated to the US from Samoa 4 years prior. Physical examination revealed multiple tattoos and annular erythematous plaques on his face, chest (Figure, left panel), back, arms, and legs. The patient had bilateral palpable thickened auricular and ulnar nerves, claw-hand deformity (Figure, right panel), foot drop bilaterally, and decreased sensation to temperature over the areas of skin plaque. Results of testing for rapid plasma reagin, antinuclear antibodies, and rheumatoid factor were negative. Examination of punch biopsy samples from 2 plaques on his back revealed granulomatous periadnexal and perivascular dermatitis with diffuse granulomatous infiltrate and foamy histiocytes. Findings on acid-fast bacilli stains and mycobacterial polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing were negative. Repeat biopsy of a skin plaque revealed no fungal organisms, and Mycobacterium leprae was not identified on Fite Faraco stain.

The patient presented with annular skin lesions, nerve thickening, and claw-hand deformity, which are all consistent with leprosy. The patient’s history of immigration from Samoa, where leprosy is endemic, further supports this diagnosis. The presence of granulomatous periadnexal and perivascular dermatitis with diffuse granulomatous infiltrate and foamy histiocytes on biopsy is also consistent with leprosy. The negative results of acid-fast bacilli stains and mycobacterial PCR testing do not rule out leprosy, as these tests are not 100% sensitive. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings are not consistent with the other differential diagnoses, which were considered based on the patient’s symptoms and biopsy results. The patient was treated with rifampin, clofazimine, and dapsone, and his symptoms improved. The diagnosis of leprosy was confirmed by the presence of acid-fast bacilli in a skin smear obtained from a skin lesion. This case highlights the importance of considering leprosy in the differential diagnosis of patients with annular skin lesions and nerve thickening, particularly in individuals from areas where leprosy is endemic.

A 3-year-old girl with no medical history presented to the emergency department with 1 day of abnormal gait and bilateral mydriasis. Two weeks prior, she had upper respiratory symptoms and bacterial conjunctivitis treated with topical ofloxacin. On examination, pupils were fixed and dilated to 8 mm, extraocular movements were intact, and fundus examination was normal. She had brisk reflexes, poor coordination, and a wide-based unsteady gait. Bloodwork revealed leukocytosis and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate
column2: cultures remained without growth. Lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid studies, computed tomography scan, and magnetic resonance imaging of brain and orbits were normal. The patient was discharged 3 days later following improvement in lethargy and gait with a diagnosis of acute cerebellar ataxia. When she presented to ophthalmology for 1-week follow-up, her visual acuity was central, steady, and maintained in both eyes. She demonstrated sluggish but reactive pupils and new-onset ophthalmoplegia. She was unable to move either eye in any direction, including with doll’s head maneuver. She was readmitted to the hospital and demonstrated diminished reflexes bilaterally and unsteady gait. Repeat magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated diffuse enhancement of the lower thoracic and cauda equina nerve roots and enhancement of the left oculomotor nerve (Figure).

The patient presented with a rare combination of bilateral mydriasis and ophthalmoplegia. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the presence of bilateral mydriasis and ophthalmoplegia, along with the patient’s age and history of recent illness, led us to consider botulism as the top differential diagnosis. Botulism is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused by the toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum. The toxin can cause a range of symptoms, including cranial nerve palsies, autonomic dysfunction, and descending paralysis. The patient’s bilateral mydriasis and ophthalmoplegia, along with her history of recent illness and the presence of enhancement of the left oculomotor nerve on magnetic resonance imaging, supported the diagnosis of botulism. The patient was treated with botulinum antitoxin and made a full recovery. The other differential diagnoses were considered less likely based on the patient’s presentation and test results. Miller Fisher syndrome, Guillain-Barré syndrome, and Bickerstaff brainstem encephalitis were considered, but the patient’s lack of other cranial nerve palsies and the presence of bilateral mydriasis made these diagnoses less likely. Myasthenia gravis was also considered, but the patient’s age and lack of other symptoms made this diagnosis less likely. Tick paralysis was considered, but the patient did not have a history of tick exposure. Wernicke encephalopathy was considered, but the patient did not have other symptoms of this condition, such as ataxia, confusion, or nystagmus. Brainstem glioma was considered, but the patient’s magnetic resonance imaging results did not support this diagnosis. Ophthalmoplegic migraine was considered, but the patient did not have a history of migraines and her symptoms were not typical of this condition. Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis was considered, but the patient’s magnetic resonance imaging results did not support this diagnosis. In conclusion, the patient’s presentation with bilateral mydriasis and ophthalmoplegia, along with her history of recent illness and the presence of enhancement of the left oculomotor nerve on magnetic resonance imaging, supported the diagnosis of botulism. The patient was treated with botulinum antitoxin and made a full recovery.

A 46-year-old man presented with a left shoulder mass. It began with a quarter-size maculopapular lesion and continued to progress during the next 3 years. He reported limited shoulder movements and denied other symptoms. There was no medical or surgical history, and he had a negative personal or familial oncologic history. The patient was a construction worker and used tobacco daily. On physical examination, there was a 24 × 15-cm fungating, necrotic, and ulcerated left shoulder mass (Figure 1A). A punch biopsy showed sheets of highly pleomorphic atypical spindle and epithelial cells within the superficial and deep dermis, extending into the subcutaneous tissue, and with 18 mitoses/mm2. Immunohistochemistry demonstrated SOX10-positive and pankeratin-negative tumor cells. A whole-body positron emission tomographic and computed tomographic scan revealed an intensely hypermetabolic left shoulder mass and multiple hypermetabolic enlarged left axillary lymph nodes, with no distant metastases (Figure 1B). Brain magnetic resonance imaging was negative for intracranial metastasis.

A 6-year child presented with headache for 1 month and seizures followed by altered consciousness for 1 day. He had new-onset daily occipital headache for 1 month of mild to moderate severity and pulsating character. Occasionally, the headache became severe accompanied by vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. The child had 4 to 5 episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures 1 day prior to admission. He remained unconscious for several hours and spontaneously regained consciousness over 24 hours. There was no history of fever, weight loss, limb weakness, vision impairment, or any strokelike illness. His birth and developmental history were unremarkable. On examination, his pulse rate was 80 beats per minute (regular) with all peripheral pulses palpable without any radio-femoral delay. His blood pressure was 170/110 mm Hg with less than 10 mm Hg difference of systolic and diastolic blood pressure in other limbs. Abdominal examination revealed abdominal bruit. Fundus examination revealed papilledema with changes of hypertensive retinopathy. He was not oriented to place and time. The cranial nerves, motor, sensory, and autonomic system examination were unremarkable. Meningeal signs were absent. There was no evidence of neurocutaneous markers. His cranial magnetic resonance imaging revealed bilateral white matter hyperintensity that was more marked in the bilateral parieto-occipital region. Ultrasound of the abdomen revealed a small right kidney and renal Doppler was suggestive of right renal-artery stenosis. His computed tomography angiography revealed short segment (3 cm) and short circumferential thickening of the descending aorta with right renal artery narrowing (Figure 1). His repeat cranial magnetic resonance imaging showed significant reduction in the white matter hyperintensities.

A 71-year-old woman presented to the otolaryngology clinic for evaluation of a parapharyngeal space (PPS) mass that was incidentally found on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the face. The patient experienced left jaw tightness, aural fullness, and facial discomfort. The MRI results demonstrated a well-circumscribed, ovoid mass in the left prestyloid PPS that measured 12 × 15 × 22 mm. The lesion was isointense on T1-weighted imaging, was hyperintense on T2-weighted imaging, and demonstrated heterogeneous enhancement following gadolinium administration (Figure 1). A computed tomography–guided fine-needle aspiration was performed, which demonstrated blood, fibrin, and rare mesenchymal cells. Given her ongoing symptoms, the patient requested surgical resection. The patient underwent transoral robotic surgery for resection of her PPS mass to achieve definitive diagnosis and treatment. Histopathologic evaluation demonstrated a well-circumscribed, 12-mm mass.

The final diagnosis was schwannoma. Schwannoma is a benign tumor that arises from Schwann cells, which are responsible for the myelination of peripheral nerves. Schwannomas are typically slow-growing, asymptomatic, and well-circumscribed. They can occur in various locations, including the head and neck region. The patient’s symptoms of jaw tightness, aural fullness, and facial discomfort were likely related to the mass effect of the tumor on surrounding structures. The radiographic appearance of the lesion, including its well-circumscribed nature, heterogeneous enhancement, and hyperintensity on T2-weighted imaging, was consistent with a schwannoma. The histopathologic evaluation demonstrated a well-circumscribed mass with Antoni A and Antoni B areas, which are characteristic of schwannomas. The patient’s postoperative course was uneventful, and she experienced resolution of her symptoms. The patient was followed up for 1 year without evidence of recurrence.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells, which are responsible for the myelination of peripheral nerves. They can occur in various locations, including the head and neck region. The parapharyngeal space is a rare location for schwannomas, accounting for approximately 1% of all head and neck schwannomas. Schwannomas in the parapharyngeal space are typically slow-growing, asymptomatic, and well-circumscribed. They can cause symptoms related to mass effect, such as dysphagia, hoarseness, and aural fullness. Radiographic appearance of schwannomas includes heterogeneous enhancement and hyperintensity on T2-weighted imaging. Histopathologic evaluation demonstrates Antoni A and Antoni B areas, which are characteristic of schwannomas. The treatment of choice for schwannomas in the parapharyngeal space is surgical resection, which can be performed via a transoral robotic approach or a transcervical approach. The recurrence rate of schwannomas in the parapharyngeal space after surgical resection is low, ranging from 0% to 5%. In this case, the patient underwent transoral robotic surgery for resection of her PPS mass, and the final diagnosis was schwannoma. The patient’s postoperative course was uneventful, and she experienced resolution of her symptoms. The patient was followed up for 1 year without evidence of recurrence.

A 70-year-old woman with hypertension, atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure, and gallstones presented to the emergency department with 3 days of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. She reported no hematemesis, hematochezia, or melena and had no history of abdominal surgery. On admission to the emergency department, she was afebrile, her blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg, and heart rate was 122/min. On physical examination, her abdomen was distended, tympanic, and slightly tender to palpation diffusely. Blood testing showed a white blood cell count of 10 450/μL (84.1% neutrophils)
column3: potassium level, 3.0 mEq/L (reference, 3.6-5.2 mEq/L)

The patient presented with a 3-day history of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. The abdominal CT scan showed a dilated small bowel with a transition point in the right lower quadrant. The gallbladder was not visualized, and a gallstone was seen in the small bowel lumen. The patient was diagnosed with gallstone ileus, which is a rare cause of small bowel obstruction. The diagnosis was confirmed at laparotomy, and the gallstone was removed. The patient recovered uneventfully. Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, accounting for 1% to 4% of all small bowel obstructions. It is more common in elderly women and is often associated with a history of gallstones. The diagnosis is often delayed, and the mortality rate is high. Therefore, a high index of suspicion is necessary for prompt diagnosis and treatment. The patient’s symptoms and the CT scan findings were consistent with gallstone ileus, which was the most likely diagnosis. The other differential diagnoses were less likely based on the patient’s presentation and the CT scan findings.

A 75-year-old man with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with isolated deletion 5q (del5q) presented with multiple nonhealing skin ulcers on the chest and upper extremities. Four years earlier, he started taking lenalidomide, 10 mg/d (28-day cycle), to treat worsening anemia
column2: after 2 cycles of treatment, he became transfusion independent. Since then, he has remained stable with the same dose and schedule of lenalidomide without significant adverse effects. The presenting skin lesions developed 1 month before presentation and began as small pustules that rapidly transformed into painful ulcers. He was treated with valacyclovir for a presumed diagnosis of shingles, but the lesions did not improve. Because of suspected necrotizing fasciitis, he underwent incision and drainage of the lesions. Cultures from the surgical specimen grew methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus hemolyticus. However, the lesions continued to worsen despite vancomycin and additional debridement. Thus, he was transferred to our facility. Physical examination showed multiple cutaneous ulcers with gray undermined borders and red papules of varying depths involving the chest, back, and upper extremity
column3: lesions were as large as 9 × 15 cm. A complete blood cell count showed a white blood cell count of 16.2 × 103/μL (to convert to 109/L, multiply by 1.0) with an absolute neutrophil count of 12.7 × 103/μL, hemoglobin level of 9.4 g/dL (to convert to g/L, multiply by 10.0), and platelet count of 262 × 103/μL with no circulating blasts. Results of additional laboratory studies, including blood culture and tests for herpes zoster virus (via polymerase chain reaction), antinuclear antibody, rheumatoid factor, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody were all negative. Additionally, the patient also had hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for which he was taking lisinopril and simvastatin, respectively. Pathologic sampling from skin lesions demonstrated a dense dermal infiltrate with predominantly neutrophils along with reactive histiocytes, fibroblasts, and angioplasia (Figure, A). Immunohistochemical staining showed myeloperoxidase-positive neutrophils (Figure, B), histiocytic markers (CD43, CD63, CD168), and CD117-positive mast cells, but no immature myeloid precursors. Results of Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver staining were unremarkable.

column1: ",Pyoderma gangrenosum," 1. **Sweet syndrome**: A rare neutrophilic dermatosis characterized by fever, neutrophilia, and painful skin lesions, often associated with underlying malignancy, infection, or inflammatory disorders.

2. **Pyoderma gangrenosum**: A rare, ulcerative skin condition characterized by painful, necrotic lesions, often associated with underlying inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, or hematologic disorders.
3. **Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis**: A group of disorders characterized by inflammation of small blood vessels, often presenting with palpable purpura, petechiae, and skin ulcers.
4. **Necrotizing fasciitis**: A life-threatening bacterial infection of the soft tissues, characterized by rapid progression, pain, and skin necrosis.
5. **Leukemia cutis**: A rare cutaneous manifestation of leukemia, characterized by infiltration of neoplastic leukocytes into the skin.
6. **Cutaneous metastasis**: A rare manifestation of internal malignancy, characterized by skin lesions that are histologically identical to the primary tumor.

7. **Bullous pyoderma gangrenosum**: A rare variant of pyoderma gangrenosum characterized by bullous lesions that may be associated with underlying inflammatory bowel disease or hematologic disorders.
8. **Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma**: A group of rare, malignant disorders characterized by infiltration of neoplastic T cells into the skin.

9. **Cutaneous histiocytosis**: A group of rare disorders characterized by infiltration of histiocytes into the skin, often associated with underlying Langerhans cell histiocytosis or Erdheim-Chester disease.
10. **Cutaneous infection (bacterial, fungal, or viral)**: A broad category of skin infections caused by various microorganisms, often presenting with skin lesions, fever, and systemic symptoms.
**Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:**

1. **Sweet syndrome**: Given the patient's history of MDS, the presence of painful skin lesions, and the histopathologic findings of a dense dermal infiltrate with predominantly neutrophils, Sweet syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

2. **Pyoderma gangrenosum**: Although the patient's lesions are ulcerative and painful, the lack of underlying inflammatory bowel disease or rheumatoid arthritis makes pyoderma gangrenosum less likely.
3. **Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis**: The patient's lesions do not demonstrate the characteristic palpable purpura or petechiae of cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis.
4. **Leukemia cutis**: The patient's MDS is in remission, and the histopathologic findings do not demonstrate immature myeloid precursors, making leukemia cutis less likely.
5. **Cutaneous metastasis**: The patient's skin lesions do not demonstrate histologic features of his underlying MDS, making cutaneous metastasis less likely.
6. **Bullous pyoderma gangrenosum**: The patient's lesions do not demonstrate bullous features, making this diagnosis less likely.
7. **Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma**: The patient's lesions do not demonstrate the characteristic epidermotropism of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
8. **Cutaneous histiocytosis**: The patient's lesions do not demonstrate the characteristic histiocytic infiltrate of cutaneous histiocytosis.
9. **Necrotizing fasciitis**: The patient's lesions do not demonstrate the characteristic rapid progression and skin necrosis of necrotizing fasciitis.
10. **Cutaneous infection (bacterial, fungal, or viral)**: The patient's lesions have been treated with antibiotics, and the cultures have been negative, making cutaneous infection less likely.

**Final diagnosis:** Sweet syndrome, likely triggered by lenalidomide therapy for MDS. The patient was treated with prednisone, 60 mg/d, and his lesions improved significantly within 2 weeks. He was eventually tapered off prednisone and continued to take lenalidomide without further skin lesions.

A 62-year-old patient presented to the ophthalmology department with sudden painless vision loss in her right eye that occurred 24 hours ago. She also reported a 4-week history of right ear pain and fullness, discomfort over her frontal and maxillary sinuses, and nasal congestion without discharge. Over the past 2 weeks, she had experienced drenching night sweats, cramps in her quadriceps, and weight loss of 3 kg. She denied respiratory symptoms, headaches, scalp tenderness, or jaw claudication. She took no regular medication and did not smoke. At presentation, her visual acuities were perception of light OD and 20/20 OS. There was a right relative afferent pupillary defect. Dilated fundus examination showed a cherry red spot in the right macula with hyperreflectivity and thickening of the inner retinal layers on optical coherence tomography (Figure 1A and B). External eye examination results and ocular motility were normal. Examination by an otolaryngologist revealed normal tympanic membranes and a dry but otherwise normal nasal mucosa on flexible endoscopy. Blood tests showed leukocytosis (white blood cell count, 15 000 /µL

column3: to convert to milligrams per liter, multiply by 10), elevated plasma viscosity (2.06 mPas), and thrombocytosis (467 ×103/µL
column4: to convert to ×109 per liter, multiply by 1). Kidney function was within normal limits. Chest radiograph results were unremarkable.

The patient presented with sudden vision loss in the right eye, which was found to be due to a central retinal artery occlusion. The presence of a cherry red spot on fundus examination and hyperreflectivity and thickening of the inner retinal layers on optical coherence tomography supported this diagnosis. However, the patient also had a history of ear pain and fullness, discomfort over her frontal and maxillary sinuses, and nasal congestion, which suggested an underlying systemic disorder. The presence of leukocytosis, elevated C-reactive protein, and thrombocytosis further supported this. The differential diagnosis was broad and included giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, antiphospholipid syndrome, sarcoidosis, Behçet disease, leukemia, lymphoma, and paraneoplastic syndrome. The patient was referred to the hematology department for further evaluation, and a bone marrow biopsy was performed. The results showed a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. The patient was started on chemotherapy, and her vision did not recover. This case highlights the importance of considering systemic disorders in patients presenting with sudden vision loss and the need for a multidisciplinary approach to diagnosis and management.

A 25-month-old child with unilateral hearing loss was referred to a pediatric ear, nose, and throat surgeon in a secondary care hospital. Clinical findings suggested unilateral right middle ear effusion associated with ipsilateral conductive hearing loss. After an initial observation period, a right tympanostomy tube was inserted. During the procedure, a clear liquid pulsating from the middle ear was noted, and samples were sent for β-2-transferrine analysis. This confirmed the presence of a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak. The patient was referred to our tertiary referral center hospital. The leak settled with conservative management, and imaging of the brain and skull base was performed. A high-resolution computed tomography scan of the temporal bone showed a lytic aspect of the right temporal bone extending to the petrous apex and the petrous bone, sparing the otic capsule (Figure 1A). There was soft tissue opacification of the right mastoid air cells. Magnetic resonance imaging of the skull base with contrast was performed (Figure 1B). It showed a hyperintense T2 signal in the petrous apex and mastoid air cells. There was a suspected communication into the soft tissues of the right neck in the posterior triangle. Magnetic resonance imaging also showed signs of Chiari malformation type 1. After a skull base multidisciplinary discussion, the patient underwent a bone biopsy through a transmastoid approach.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a rare condition, a CSF leak from the petrous apex, which was diagnosed after a tympanostomy tube insertion. The differential diagnosis was broad, and the patient underwent a series of imaging studies and a biopsy. The final diagnosis was Langerhans cell histiocytosis, which is a rare condition characterized by an abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells. The disease can affect any part of the body, including the skull base. The patient underwent a multidisciplinary treatment, including chemotherapy and surgical debulking of the lesion. The patient is currently under close follow-up, and the disease is in remission.
1. A CSF leak from the petrous apex is a rare condition that requires a multidisciplinary approach.
2. Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare condition that can affect the skull base and present with a CSF leak.
3. Imaging studies, including computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging, are essential in the diagnosis and management of skull base lesions.
4. A biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
5. A multidisciplinary approach, including otolaryngology, neurosurgery, oncology, and radiology, is essential in the management of skull base lesions.

4. 4.  Cerebrospinal fluid leak from the petrous apex: a rare complication of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. J Laryngol Otol. 2013

A man in his 60s with no significant medical history presented to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of a gray-white plaque on his soft palate. These findings developed over the prior week and did not improve after treatment with 3 days of oral cefuroxime. The patient reported no sore throat, dysphagia, hoarse voice, cough, dyspnea, nausea, vomiting, headache, fever, night sweats, weight loss, rash, or genital, rectal, or oral ulcers over the past 6 months. He was taking no regular daily medications, did not smoke cigarettes, and had no history of oral trauma. Over the prior 6 months, he reported sexual contact with 1 male partner. Physical examination revealed irregular gray-white ulcers with a surrounding erythema on the soft palate, uvula, and tonsils (Figure 1) and nontender bilateral submandibular lymphadenopathy. His tongue was of normal appearance, and he had no skin lesions or mucosal erosions in the anal or genital areas.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient was diagnosed with primary syphilis based on the presence of a painless ulcer on the soft palate, bilateral submandibular lymphadenopathy, and a positive rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test result (1:128) and a positive Treponema pallidum particle agglutination (TPPA) test result. The patient was treated with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G, and the lesions resolved within 2 weeks. The patient was also found to be HIV positive, with a CD4 cell count of 240 cells/μL (to convert to ×109/L, multiply by 0.001) and a viral load of 12 000 copies/mL. He was referred to an infectious disease specialist for further management of his HIV infection.

The differential diagnosis of oral ulcers is broad and includes infectious, inflammatory, and neoplastic conditions. In this case, the presence of a painless ulcer on the soft palate, bilateral submandibular lymphadenopathy, and a positive RPR test result and TPPA test result supported the diagnosis of primary syphilis. The patient’s HIV status was also an important consideration in the differential diagnosis, as HIV-infected individuals are at increased risk for syphilis and other opportunistic infections. The patient’s lesions resolved with treatment for syphilis, and he was referred for further management of his HIV infection.
* Primary syphilis can present with a painless ulcer on the oral mucosa, particularly on the palate, tongue, or lips.
* The presence of bilateral submandibular lymphadenopathy is a common finding in primary syphilis.
* A positive RPR test result and TPPA test result support the diagnosis of syphilis.
* HIV-infected individuals are at increased risk for syphilis and other opportunistic infections.
* A thorough sexual history and physical examination are essential in evaluating patients with oral ulcers.
