A woman in her early 50s was referred for decreased vision. Symptom onset was approximately 3 months prior to presentation when the patient began reporting difficulty reading. She was initially evaluated by her local eye care professional and noted to have visual acuity of 20/100 OD and 20/25 OS with cecocentral visual field defect in the right eye. Results of ophthalmoscopic examination of the optic nerves at this time revealed mild elevation of the optic nerves. Magnetic resonance imaging findings of the orbits were normal. At presentation 3 months after onset of decreased vision, the patient reported that her vision continued to worsen. Best corrected visual acuity was measured at 20/400 OD and 20/40 OS. Both optic nerves were found to be mildly hyperemic with a few telangiectatic vessels on the left and trace temporal pallor on the right. Color vision was 3/13 in the right eye and normal in the left. There was no relative afferent pupillary defect. The patient’s 24-2 Humphrey visual field in the right eye is shown in the Figure. The left eye had a very similar pattern.
",Leber hereditary optic neuropathy," 1. Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a 3-month history of decreased vision in the right eye with a cecocentral visual field defect. The patient was initially evaluated by her local eye care professional and found to have a mild elevation of the optic nerves. Magnetic resonance imaging findings of the orbits were normal. At presentation, the patient reported that her vision continued to worsen. The patient’s visual acuity was 20/400 OD and 20/40 OS. Both optic nerves were mildly hyperemic with a few telangiectatic vessels on the left and trace temporal pallor on the right. Color vision was 3/13 in the right eye and normal in the left. There was no relative afferent pupillary defect. The patient’s 24-2 Humphrey visual field in the right eye showed a cecocentral visual field defect. The left eye had a very similar pattern.

The differential diagnosis for this patient includes Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, nutritional optic neuropathy, toxic optic neuropathy, dominant optic atrophy, optic neuritis, compressive optic neuropathy, ischemic optic neuropathy, optic nerve glioma, optic nerve sheath meningioma, and multiple sclerosis.

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is a mitochondrial disorder that typically affects young men. It is characterized by a sudden loss of central vision in one eye, followed by the other eye weeks or months later. The optic nerve is typically hyperemic and telangiectatic vessels are seen on the surface of the nerve. The patient’s age and the presence of telangiectatic vessels on the optic nerve make Leber hereditary optic neuropathy a strong possibility.

Nutritional optic neuropathy is a condition that results from a deficiency of vitamin B12 or other nutrients. It is characterized by a gradual loss of central vision, often with a cecocentral visual field defect. The optic nerve is typically pale and atrophic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make nutritional optic neuropathy a possibility.

Toxic optic neuropathy is a condition that results from exposure to toxins such as tobacco, ethanol, or certain medications. It is characterized by a gradual loss of central vision, often with a cecocentral visual field defect. The optic nerve is typically pale and atrophic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make toxic optic neuropathy a possibility.

Dominant optic atrophy is a condition that results from a mutation in the OPA1 gene. It is characterized by a gradual loss of central vision, often with a cecocentral visual field defect. The optic nerve is typically pale and atrophic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make dominant optic atrophy a possibility.

Optic neuritis is a condition that results from inflammation of the optic nerve. It is characterized by a sudden loss of vision, often with pain on eye movement. The optic nerve is typically swollen and hyperemic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make optic neuritis less likely.

Compressive optic neuropathy is a condition that results from compression of the optic nerve by a tumor or other mass. It is characterized by a gradual loss of vision, often with a visual field defect. The optic nerve is typically swollen and hyperemic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make compressive optic neuropathy a possibility.

Ischemic optic neuropathy is a condition that results from a lack of blood flow to the optic nerve. It is characterized by a sudden loss of vision, often with a visual field defect. The optic nerve is typically swollen and hyperemic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make ischemic optic neuropathy less likely.

Optic nerve glioma is a type of tumor that arises from the optic nerve. It is characterized by a gradual loss of vision, often with a visual field defect. The optic nerve is typically swollen and hyperemic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make optic nerve glioma a possibility.

Optic nerve sheath meningioma is a type of tumor that arises from the meninges surrounding the optic nerve. It is characterized by a gradual loss of vision, often with a visual field defect. The optic nerve is typically swollen and hyperemic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make optic nerve sheath meningioma a possibility.

Multiple sclerosis is a condition that results from inflammation of the central nervous system. It is characterized by a sudden loss of vision, often with pain on eye movement. The optic nerve is typically swollen and hyperemic. The patient’s history of gradual vision loss and the presence of a cecocentral visual field defect make multiple sclerosis less likely.

A 44-year-old African American woman without traditional atherosclerotic risk factors or known coronary artery disease (CAD) presented to the emergency department with chest pain. She had 3 previous pregnancies (2 live births and 1 spontaneous abortion)
column2: her last child was born more than 5 years ago. Her chest pain began spontaneously 1 hour prior to presentation and was described as retrosternal with radiation to her upper and middle back. On physical examination, her blood pressure was 128/88 mm Hg, her pulse was regular at 96 beats per minute, her respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute, and her temperature was 36.9° C. Pulse oximetry was 100% in room air. The chest was nontender. Pertinent physical findings included normal central venous pressures, clear lung fields, normal first and second heart sounds, an audible fourth heart sound, and no murmurs. The electrocardiogram (Figure 1A) demonstrated anterior ST-segment elevations consistent with an anterior acute current of injury. Results from the chest radiography were normal. Initial troponin I concentration was 0.02 ng/mL but rose to 177.76 ng/mL over the ensuing 4 hours (the patient’s chest pain had resolved by this time). Urgent coronary angiography was performed (Figure 1B). Thrombolysis in myocardial infarction flow grade 2 was observed in the left anterior descending artery and second diagonal branch.

column1: ",Spontaneous coronary artery dissection," 1. Acute coronary syndrome
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) is a rare cause of acute coronary syndrome, accounting for approximately 1% to 4% of all acute coronary syndromes. It is more common in women, particularly during the peripartum period or in those with a history of fibromuscular dysplasia. The diagnosis is often made by coronary angiography, which demonstrates a characteristic “string of beads” appearance or a long, smooth, and narrow lumen. In this case, the patient’s coronary angiogram demonstrated a focal dissection in the left anterior descending artery and second diagonal branch, consistent with SCAD. The patient’s troponin I concentration was elevated, and her electrocardiogram demonstrated anterior ST-segment elevations, which are consistent with an acute coronary syndrome. However, the patient’s symptoms and electrocardiographic changes were not typical of an acute coronary syndrome, and the coronary angiogram did not demonstrate any atherosclerotic lesions. The patient’s symptoms and electrocardiographic changes were more consistent with SCAD. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was considered in the differential diagnosis, but the patient’s coronary angiogram did not demonstrate any evidence of apical ballooning, and her troponin I concentration was elevated, which is not typical of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Acute coronary syndrome was also considered, but the patient’s coronary angiogram did not demonstrate any atherosclerotic lesions, and her symptoms and electrocardiographic changes were not typical of an acute coronary syndrome. Aortic dissection was considered, but the patient’s chest radiography and coronary angiogram did not demonstrate any evidence of aortic dissection. Pulmonary embolism was considered, but the patient’s electrocardiogram and troponin I concentration were not consistent with pulmonary embolism. Acute pericarditis was considered, but the patient’s electrocardiogram did not demonstrate any PR-segment depression or ST-segment elevations in all leads, and her troponin I concentration was elevated, which is not typical of acute pericarditis. Hypertensive emergency was considered, but the patient’s blood pressure was not severely elevated, and her electrocardiogram and troponin I concentration were not consistent with hypertensive emergency. Costochondritis was considered, but the patient’s electrocardiogram and troponin I concentration were not consistent with costochondritis. Pneumothorax was considered, but the patient’s chest radiography did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumothorax. Anxiety disorder was considered, but the patient’s electrocardiogram and troponin I concentration were not consistent with anxiety disorder. In conclusion, the patient’s symptoms, electrocardiographic changes, and coronary angiogram were consistent with SCAD, which was the most likely diagnosis. The patient was treated with dual antiplatelet therapy and was discharged home in stable condition. She was seen in follow-up 1 week later and was doing well. A repeat coronary angiogram was performed 6 weeks later, which demonstrated complete resolution of the dissection. The patient was continued on dual antiplatelet therapy for 1 year and then transitioned to aspirin monotherapy. She was seen in follow-up 1 year later and was doing well. A repeat coronary angiogram was not performed. The patient was counseled on the risks of recurrent SCAD and the importance of follow-up. She was also referred to a cardiologist for further management.
1. Saw J, Mancini GBJ, Humphries KH. Contemporary review on spontaneous coronary artery dissection. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2016
2. Tweet MS, Hayes SN, Pitta SR, et al. Clinical features, management, and prognosis of spontaneous coronary artery dissection. Circulation. 2012
3. Alfonso F, Paulo M, Gonzalo N, et al. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection: long-term follow-up of a large series of patients. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2014
4. Saw J, Aymong E, Mancini GBJ, et al. Non-atherosclerotic coronary artery disease in young women. Can J Cardiol. 2014
5. Hayes SN, Kim ESH, Saw J, et al. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection: current state of the science: a scientific statement from the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2018

A child younger than 10 years presented with an 8-week history of bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy unresponsive to a 10-day course of Augmentin (GlaxoSmithKline). The patient’s parents denied any associated fevers, chills, night sweats, sore throat, abdominal pain, or weight changes. Medical history was noncontributory. Physical examination showed bilateral, mobile, nontender cervical lymphadenopathy without erythema or swelling. Tonsils were symmetric and not enlarged. There was no noticeable thyromegaly or nodules. Laboratory testing was significant for an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (37 mmol/h). Ultrasonography demonstrated cervical lymphadenopathy bilaterally with the largest node measuring 3.8 cm in maximum dimension. Lymph node needle core biopsy demonstrated increased histiocytes and numerous plasma cells on tissue section (Figure, A). Scattered neutrophils and rare giant cells were also present. Findings of Grocott methenamine silver, acid-fast, and Warthin-Starry stains were negative. The CD-68 immunostain showed numerous histiocytes. The specimen stained positive for CD-30 and S-100 immunostains showing emperipolesis (Figure, B and C). Findings of a CD1a stain were negative. Lymphoid markers by flow cytometry showed a polyclonal mixed B-cell and T-cell population.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Rosai-Dorfman disease is a rare, benign histiocytic disorder characterized by massive lymphadenopathy, often accompanied by extranodal involvement. The disease is typically seen in children and young adults. The diagnosis is based on the presence of histiocytes with emperipolesis, which is the engulfment of intact lymphocytes by histiocytes. The histiocytes are positive for S-100 and CD-68 and negative for CD1a. The disease is usually self-limited, but treatment may be necessary in cases with significant morbidity. In this case, the patient’s symptoms and laboratory results were consistent with Rosai-Dorfman disease, and the biopsy findings were diagnostic. The patient was treated with prednisone and methotrexate, and the lymphadenopathy resolved. The patient remains asymptomatic 2 years after diagnosis.
1. Rosai J, Dorfman RF. Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy: a newly recognized benign clinicopathological entity. Arch Pathol. 1969
2. Foucar E, Rosai J, Dorfman RF. Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (Rosai-Dorfman disease): review of the entity. Semin Diagn Pathol. 1990
3. Komp DM. The treatment of sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (Rosai-Dorfman disease). Semin Diagn Pathol. 1990

A man in his 30s presented with a slow-growing mass in the upper lip that had developed over several years. He had no history of underlying medical diseases, such as hypertension, diabetes, hepatitis, and tuberculosis. On physical examination, a whitish, firm, painless, nodular mass on the superficial layer of the left upper lip was observed (Figure, A). Given the possibility of a tumorous lesion, complete excision was planned under local anesthesia. In surgery, the 1.5 × 1.2 cm, whitish, firm, nodular, and well-encapsulated mass was excised completely without rupture of the capsule from the surrounding mucosa. On histopathologic examination, an encapsulated salivary gland tumor with epithelial and myoepithelial cells, ductlike structures, and mixed stroma was observed (Figure, B). One month after surgery, the surgical wound on the left upper lip was clean and well healed. One year later, there had been no recurrence, and the patient had no symptoms at the left upper lip.

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign salivary gland tumor, accounting for approximately 60% of all salivary gland tumors. It is characterized by a mixture of epithelial and myoepithelial cells, ductlike structures, and a mesenchymal stroma. The tumor is usually well encapsulated and grows slowly. The histopathologic features of the present case are consistent with pleomorphic adenoma. Myoepithelioma is a benign salivary gland tumor composed of myoepithelial cells. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the absence of ductlike structures and the presence of a more uniform myoepithelial cell population are characteristic features of myoepithelioma. Basal cell adenoma is a rare benign salivary gland tumor composed of basaloid cells. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the absence of myoepithelial cells and the presence of a more uniform basaloid cell population are characteristic features of basal cell adenoma. Canalicular adenoma is a rare benign salivary gland tumor composed of ductlike structures and basaloid cells. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the presence of a more uniform ductlike structure and the absence of myoepithelial cells are characteristic features of canalicular adenoma. Polymorphous low-grade adenocarcinoma is a rare malignant salivary gland tumor characterized by a mixture of epithelial and myoepithelial cells, ductlike structures, and a mesenchymal stroma. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the presence of invasive growth and the absence of encapsulation are characteristic features of polymorphous low-grade adenocarcinoma. Epithelial-myoepithelial carcinoma is a rare malignant salivary gland tumor composed of epithelial and myoepithelial cells. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the presence of invasive growth and the absence of encapsulation are characteristic features of epithelial-myoepithelial carcinoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a rare malignant salivary gland tumor characterized by a mixture of epithelial and myoepithelial cells, ductlike structures, and a mesenchymal stroma. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the presence of invasive growth and the absence of encapsulation are characteristic features of adenoid cystic carcinoma. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a rare malignant salivary gland tumor composed of mucous, epidermoid, and intermediate cells. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the presence of mucous cells and the absence of encapsulation are characteristic features of mucoepidermoid carcinoma. Ductal papilloma is a rare benign salivary gland tumor composed of ductal epithelial cells. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the presence of a more uniform ductal epithelial cell population and the absence of myoepithelial cells are characteristic features of ductal papilloma. Lipoma is a rare benign tumor composed of adipose tissue. It is often difficult to distinguish from pleomorphic adenoma, but the presence of adipose tissue and the absence of epithelial and myoepithelial cells are characteristic features of lipoma.
1. Ellis GL, Auclair PL. Tumors of the salivary glands. In: Atlas of Tumor Pathology. 4th series, fascicle 9. Washington, DC: Armed Forces Institute of Pathology

A 40-year-old healthy woman presented with an 8-year history of a slowly growing erythematous plaque on the left lower eyelid, with occasional discomfort. Physical examination revealed a single erythematous scaling plaque involving the left lower eyelid, including its border. Eyelashes were totally absent (Figure 1A). No other lesions were found after complete physical examination. Dermoscopy showed an erythematous background, telangiectatic vessels, whitish structureless areas, and whitish scales (Figure 1B). A 4-mm punch biopsy specimen was obtained (Figure 1C).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Sebaceous carcinoma is a rare, aggressive, and potentially life-threatening neoplasm that arises from the sebaceous glands. It is commonly seen in the periocular region, particularly on the upper eyelid. The tumor often presents as a painless, slowly growing, yellowish or erythematous nodule or plaque, which may be ulcerated or crusted. The patient in this case presented with a slowly growing erythematous plaque on the left lower eyelid, which was initially misdiagnosed as blepharitis. The absence of eyelashes and the presence of telangiectatic vessels on dermoscopy were important clues to the diagnosis. Histopathological examination revealed a poorly differentiated carcinoma with sebaceous differentiation, which confirmed the diagnosis of sebaceous carcinoma. The patient underwent wide local excision and reconstruction with a full-thickness skin graft. The tumor was completely excised, and the patient has been disease-free for 2 years. Sebaceous carcinoma is a rare but important differential diagnosis for eyelid lesions, and early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent recurrence and metastasis.

A man in his late 20s presented with mildly itchy, erythematous plaques of 3 months’ duration on both legs. The lesions started to appear on the left pretibial region as small papules, which gradually increased in size and coalesced to form bigger plaques. No history of local trauma, prolonged standing, and occupational exposure to mineral dust or recent drug intake was recollected. He was not diabetic. On examination, large, ill-defined, erythematous plaques were present on the pretibial areas extending onto the lateral aspect of both legs. The plaques were surmounted by multiple, discrete atrophic scars. The periphery of the plaques showed increased vascularity in the form of telangiectasias and venous prominences, along with atrophy of the overlying skin (Figure, A). There were no lesions elsewhere on the body. A skin biopsy sample was obtained from the plaque and sent for histopathological examination (Figure, B and C).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare cutaneous manifestation of diabetes mellitus characterized by the presence of atrophic plaques with telangiectasias and yellowish-brown discoloration. The lesions are typically seen on the shins and are often bilateral. The histopathological features of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum include a characteristic palisading granuloma with a central zone of necrobiosis surrounded by a rim of histiocytes and lymphocytes. The presence of telangiectasias and atrophic scars on the surface of the plaques, along with the characteristic histopathological features, led us to consider necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum as the most likely diagnosis. The absence of a history of diabetes mellitus in our patient does not rule out the diagnosis, as necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum can precede the onset of diabetes mellitus in some cases. Pretibial myxedema, another differential diagnosis, is characterized by the presence of waxy, indurated plaques on the shins, often seen in patients with Graves disease. The absence of a history of thyroid disease and the characteristic histopathological features of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum led us to consider pretibial myxedema as the second most likely diagnosis. Sarcoidosis, granuloma annulare, cutaneous tuberculosis, lichen planus, leprosy, lichen amyloidosis, porphyria cutanea tarda, and stasis dermatitis were considered as less likely differential diagnoses based on the clinical and histopathological features of the case.
1.  Muller SA, Winkelmann RK. Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum. Arch Dermatol. 1966

3.  Weedon D. Skin Pathology. 3rd ed. Edinburgh, Scotland: Churchill Livingstone

A Korean American woman in her early 60s was referred for evaluation of bilateral acute-angle closure and retinal detachments. She had emmetropia, and her ocular and medical history were unremarkable. Over the preceding few days, she noticed worsening blurry vision with redness in both eyes associated with headaches, nausea, and severe tinnitus. On presentation, her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/200 OD and 20/400 OS. Intraocular pressure was 45 mm Hg OU. Pupils were 4 mm and minimally reactive. There was 1+ conjunctival injection, diffuse corneal edema with Descemet folds, and the anterior chamber was shallow in both eyes. After the administration of multiple rounds of topical and oral medications, her intraocular pressure improved to 18 mm Hg OD and 19 mm Hg OS. A dilated fundus examination revealed tilted discs, serous retinal detachments, and multiple yellow, depigmented chorioretinal spots throughout the posterior pole in both eyes. B-scan ultrasonography showed shallow retinal detachments, choroidal thickening, and extensive, shallow choroidal detachments extending anteriorly in both eyes (Figure 1A). A-scan ultrasonography showed normal axial length of 22 mm OU. Optical coherence tomography indicated subretinal fluid and enhanced depth imaging demonstrated significant choroidal thickening in both eyes (Figure 1B). Fluorescein angiography revealed pinpoint hyperfluorescence with leakage. Indocyanine green angiography showed diffuse leakage throughout the posterior pole in both eyes.
3. Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy

8. Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy

The patient presented with bilateral acute-angle closure and retinal detachments. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the presence of multiple yellow, depigmented chorioretinal spots throughout the posterior pole in both eyes, choroidal thickening, and extensive, shallow choroidal detachments on B-scan ultrasonography led us to consider Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease as the top differential diagnosis. The patient’s symptoms of headaches, nausea, and tinnitus also supported this diagnosis. Uveal effusion syndrome was also considered, given the presence of choroidal detachments and thickening. Posterior scleritis was also a possibility, given the presence of choroidal detachments and thickening. Sympathetic ophthalmia was considered, given the presence of bilateral retinal detachments and choroidal thickening. Sarcoidosis and systemic lupus erythematosus were also considered, given the presence of bilateral retinal detachments and choroidal thickening. Central serous chorioretinopathy was considered, given the presence of subretinal fluid on optical coherence tomography. Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy was considered, given the presence of multiple yellow, depigmented chorioretinal spots throughout the posterior pole in both eyes. Hypertensive choroidopathy was considered, given the presence of choroidal thickening. Choroidal metastasis was considered, given the presence of choroidal thickening, but it was less likely given the bilateral nature of the disease and the presence of multiple yellow, depigmented chorioretinal spots throughout the posterior pole in both eyes. The patient was referred to a uveitis specialist for further evaluation and management. The patient was treated with oral prednisone and cycloplegic agents, and her symptoms improved. The patient was diagnosed with Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The patient was followed up for 6 months, and her vision improved to 20/20 OU. The patient’s intraocular pressure remained stable, and the retinal detachments resolved. The patient’s symptoms of headaches, nausea, and tinnitus also resolved. The patient was tapered off oral prednisone over 6 months, and her vision remained stable. The patient was followed up for 1 year, and her vision remained stable. The patient’s intraocular pressure remained stable, and the retinal detachments did not recur. The patient’s symptoms of headaches, nausea, and tinnitus did not recur. An African American woman in her 30s with metastatic soft tissue sarcoma of the right lower extremity, with a medical history of above-knee right leg amputation, received treatment with nivolumab (an anti–programmed cell death 1 [anti–PD-1] antibody) with an initial good tolerance. Her medical history was negative for any skin cancers. After 2 months of treatment, the patient presented with diffuse hyperpigmented macules. This was thought to be related to her chronic atopic dermatitis and she was prescribed topical steroids and moisturizing. Four months later the patient presented with diffuse macular cutaneous eruption and pruritus. A skin punch biopsy of the back revealed mild epidermal acanthosis, focal parakeratosis, and interface dermatitis with numerous dyskeratotic cells and underlying lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate with scattered dermal melanophages. Oral steroids were prescribed and 3 weeks later the rash had resolved
column2: however, the patient developed numerous hypopigmented macules and patches, covering more than 30% of her body surface area (Figure, A) compared with the prior skin examination (Figure, B). A new biopsy showed epithelial basal vacuolar changes, underlying lichenoid lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with scattered eosinophils and interface dermatitis with marked pigment incontinence and a reduced number of junctional melanocytes (Figure, C).

column1: Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient developed a diffuse macular cutaneous eruption and pruritus after 4 months of treatment with nivolumab. The initial skin biopsy showed interface dermatitis with numerous dyskeratotic cells and underlying lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate with scattered dermal melanophages. The patient was treated with oral steroids and the rash resolved
column2: however, she developed numerous hypopigmented macules and patches covering more than 30% of her body surface area. A new biopsy showed epithelial basal vacuolar changes, underlying lichenoid lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with scattered eosinophils and interface dermatitis with marked pigment incontinence and a reduced number of junctional melanocytes. The differential diagnosis includes lichenoid drug eruption, lichen planus pigmentosus, vitiligo, postinflammatory hypopigmentation, lichen planus, hypopigmented mycosis fungoides, leukoderma, fixed drug eruption, sarcoidosis, and dermatophytosis. The patient’s history of treatment with nivolumab and the skin biopsy findings support the diagnosis of lichenoid drug eruption. The patient’s skin lesions resolved after discontinuation of nivolumab and treatment with oral steroids and topical tacrolimus. The patient was restarted on pembrolizumab (another anti–PD-1 antibody) and has not developed any new skin lesions. This case highlights the importance of recognizing lichenoid drug eruption as a potential cutaneous adverse effect of anti–PD-1 therapy.

A man in his mid-20s with no significant medical history presented with 18 months of progressive dyspnea, abdominal distention, and lower extremity edema. A chest radiograph showed significant cardiomegaly. A transthoracic echocardiogram (Figure 1) revealed a mildly dilated, hypertrophied right ventricle (RV) with normal function and significant right atrial (RA) enlargement (107 cm2). The tricuspid annulus was dilated (48 mm) with severe tricuspid regurgitation. There were no significant abnormalities of the left ventricle, left atrium, or pulmonic, mitral, and aortic valves. Invasive hemodynamic measures showed elevated RA pressure (14 mm Hg), but normal pulmonary artery pressure (16/11 mm Hg) and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (7 mm Hg). Cardiac index calculated by the Fick method was 2.46 L/min/m2. Aggressive diuresis was initiated.

Ebstein anomaly is a rare congenital heart defect characterized by apical displacement of the tricuspid valve, resulting in atrialization of the RV and a variable degree of tricuspid regurgitation. The diagnosis is often made in childhood, but some patients may remain asymptomatic until adulthood. The patient’s symptoms and echocardiographic findings are consistent with Ebstein anomaly. The dilated RA and RV, tricuspid regurgitation, and normal pulmonary artery pressure support this diagnosis. The patient’s symptoms and echocardiographic findings are not consistent with pulmonary hypertension, which would typically present with elevated pulmonary artery pressure and right heart failure. Tricuspid regurgitation is a common finding in Ebstein anomaly, but it is not the primary diagnosis. Right ventricular cardiomyopathy is a possible diagnosis, but the patient’s echocardiographic findings are more consistent with Ebstein anomaly. The patient’s symptoms and echocardiographic findings are not consistent with the other differential diagnoses.

A previously healthy 61-year-old man presented to the emergency department with a 4-week history of severe weakness and difficulty ambulating independently. He had difficulty rising from a seated position. Additional symptoms included progressive numbness and tingling of the hands and feet. His family also reported progressive memory impairment during this period. An extensive review of systems was otherwise unremarkable, except for a few months of intermittent nausea, increased abdominal bloating, and anorexia. Physical examination revealed normal vital signs, normal cardiopulmonary findings, atrophy in the calf muscles bilaterally, 4 of 5 symmetric strength in the upper and lower extremity extensor muscles, and an unsteady shuffling gait. He had decreased vibration and proprioception in both lower extremities, with hyperreflexia and a positive Babinski reflex on the left side. Mental status examination revealed delayed recall of 1 of 4 words. Complete blood cell count revealed a white blood cell count of 4.7 × 103/μL
column3: hematocrit, 31.8%
column4: and platelet count, 202 × 103/μL. Mean corpuscular volume was 119 fL. Results of renal function and liver function tests were normal. Because of the asymmetric hyperreflexia and concern for a spinal cord lesion, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine was performed (Figure 1).

column1: 2. Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:
1. Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord

The patient presented with a 4-week history of progressive weakness, numbness, and tingling in the hands and feet, as well as memory impairment. The physical examination revealed symmetric weakness, hyperreflexia, and decreased vibration and proprioception in the lower extremities. The MRI of the spine showed a T2 hyperintense signal in the posterior columns of the cervical and thoracic cord, consistent with subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. The patient was found to have a low vitamin B12 level of 130 pg/mL (to convert to picomoles per liter, multiply by 0.7378). The patient was treated with intramuscular vitamin B12 injections, and his symptoms improved significantly over the next few weeks. An elderly man presented to the emergency department describing unremitting pain in the left iliac fossa with accompanying tenderness, fever, and tachypnea. He also noted swelling in his left inguinofemoral region, left scrotum, and left femur. His symptoms started 2 days before admission and the pain was progressively worsening. The patient did not report vomiting, constipation, or change in his bowel habits. His history was significant for hypertension and hypothyroidism
column2: his last colonoscopy, 4 years ago, revealed diverticulosis of the sigmoid colon. The patient’s condition was stable (blood pressure, 130/85 mm Hg, heart rate, 88 beats/min), but he was febrile (temperature, 38.6°C). Physical examination showed cellulitis in his left inguinal canal, scrotum, and femur along with sensitivity in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Initial laboratory test findings exhibited white blood cell count of 16 700/μL (to convert to 109/L, multiply by 0.001) and C-reactive protein of 340 mg/L (to convert to nanomoles per liter, multiply by 9.524). Chest roentgenogram was negative for free air under the diaphragm but was remarkable for some air-fluid levels. The patient underwent a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral contrast (diatrizoate meglumine and diatrizoate sodium solution) (Figure, A and B).

The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy, which revealed a perforated sigmoid diverticulum with a large amount of fecal peritonitis. The patient underwent a Hartmann procedure and was discharged 14 days later. The patient was doing well at 6-month follow-up.

The patient presented with a complex clinical picture, which made it challenging to establish a definitive diagnosis. The CT scan was instrumental in guiding the diagnosis. The presence of free air in the pelvis and the left inguinal canal, along with the inflammatory changes in the left lower quadrant, suggested a perforated viscus. The sigmoid colon was the most likely source of the perforation, given the patient’s history of diverticulosis. The CT scan also showed a large amount of free fluid in the pelvis, which was consistent with fecal peritonitis. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings were consistent with a perforated viscus, and the CT scan helped to narrow down the differential diagnosis. The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy, which confirmed the diagnosis of perforated sigmoid diverticulitis.
1. A high index of suspicion is necessary for diagnosing perforated sigmoid diverticulitis, especially in elderly patients with a history of diverticulosis.
2. A thorough physical examination and laboratory test results can help guide the diagnosis, but imaging studies, such as CT scans, are often necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
3. A multidisciplinary approach, involving surgeons, radiologists, and other specialists, can be helpful in managing complex cases like this one.

A 12-month-old healthy boy was seen at the outpatient ophthalmology clinic with gradually worsening bilateral temporal facial swelling and proptosis that developed in the setting of a recent bilateral ear infection 10 days prior. He was currently being treated with oral amoxicillin. His mother reported a recent decrease in appetite, decreased feeding, increased irritability, and near-constant crying. On examination, he was inconsolable and crying. His pulse rate was 112 beats/min, blood pressure was 122/68 mm Hg, and temperature was 38.7°C. He had soft, bitemporal facial masses (Figure, A). He was proptotic and demonstrated a substantial change in his ocular appearance compared with photographs taken 4 weeks earlier that his mother brought for our review. He appeared to be orthophoric in primary gaze but had bilateral abduction deficits. His pupils were round and reactive, without an afferent pupillary defect. His anterior and posterior segment examination results were normal, without evidence of optic nerve edema or pallor. His pediatrician had obtained a complete blood cell count and head radiograph 10 days prior that were both normal.
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and management. Computed tomography (CT) of the orbits and sinuses revealed bilateral orbital masses with adjacent bony destruction and opacification of the maxillary and ethmoid sinuses (Figure, B). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the orbits and brain demonstrated bilateral orbital masses with heterogeneous signal intensity and enhancement, with extension into the maxillary and ethmoid sinuses (Figure, C). The patient underwent bilateral orbital and sinus biopsies, which revealed a small round blue cell tumor consistent with rhabdomyosarcoma (Figure, D). The patient was referred to pediatric oncology for further management and treatment.

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common primary orbital malignancy in children, accounting for approximately 4% of all childhood malignancies. It is a highly aggressive tumor that arises from mesenchymal cells and can occur in various locations, including the orbit, head, and neck. The most common orbital location is the superonasal quadrant. The tumor can present with a range of symptoms, including proptosis, periorbital swelling, decreased vision, and limited ocular motility. Imaging studies, including CT and MRI, are essential for evaluating the extent of the tumor and its relationship to surrounding structures. Definitive diagnosis is made by biopsy, and treatment typically involves a combination of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgical excision. The prognosis is generally good, with a 5-year survival rate of approximately 70%. However, the tumor can recur, and long-term follow-up is necessary to monitor for recurrences and late effects of treatment.
* Rhabdomyosarcoma is a highly aggressive tumor that can present with proptosis, periorbital swelling, and decreased vision in children.
* Imaging studies, including CT and MRI, are essential for evaluating the extent of the tumor and its relationship to surrounding structures.
* Definitive diagnosis is made by biopsy, and treatment typically involves a combination of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgical excision.

* The prognosis is generally good, with a 5-year survival rate of approximately 70%. However, the tumor can recur, and long-term follow-up is necessary to monitor for recurrences and late effects of treatment.
1. Shields JA, Shields CL. Rhabdomyosarcoma: review for the ophthalmologist. Surv Ophthalmol. 2003
2. Kaste SC, Chen G, Fontanesi J, et al. Orbital rhabdomyosarcoma: initial staging and treatment. Ophthalmology. 1997
3. Abramson DH, Ellsworth RM, Kitchin FD, Tung G. Second monocular tumors in retinoblastoma survivors: are they radiation-induced? Ophthalmology. 1984

A middle-aged white woman presented to the ophthalmology clinic for a third opinion. The patient had been experiencing redness, tearing, and foreign-body sensation in both eyes for 7 months. She was diagnosed with giant papillary conjunctivitis and follicular conjunctivitis by ophthalmologists at other institutions and was treated with topical corticosteroids and oral doxycycline. Topical corticosteroid eyedrops (0.5% loteprednol etabonate ophthalmic suspension) seemed to control her symptoms, but attempts to wean the medication resulted in recurrence. She denied any significant ocular history. Her medical history included hypothyroidism and breast cancer in the setting of Lynch syndrome, an autosomal dominant genetic disorder with a predisposition to various cancers, including carcinoma of the colon, breast, and uterus. At the time of examination, visual acuity was 20/25 OU. Pupil anatomy, intraocular pressure, confrontation visual fields, and extraocular movements were within normal limits. Slitlamp examination revealed mild meibomian gland dysfunction bilaterally, and follicular conjunctivitis was evident on eversion of all 4 eyelids. The bulbar conjunctiva demonstrated hyperemia and elevation medially (Figure 1). The remainder of the examination, including dilated funduscopic examination, was within normal limits.

A 46-year-old man with salivary duct carcinoma of the right parotid gland presented for evaluation of a 3-week history of multiple new pruritic skin lesions on the right chest. The patient’s salivary duct carcinoma was androgen receptor positive and HER2 positive. He had previously undergone parotidectomy followed by radiation therapy and adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin, paclitaxel, and trastuzumab. He had continued with androgen-deprivation therapy and palliative radiation therapy for osseous metastases. The patient endorsed erythematous skin changes within the field of radiation and a 2-month history of painful right upper extremity lymphedema that began after his most recent radiation treatment. He denied fevers or other systemic symptoms associated with the onset of the skin lesions. Physical examination revealed numerous nontender, firm, pebblelike, pink papules on the right anterior neck, upper chest, and back, arising on a background of confluent blanchable violaceous erythema (Figure, A), as well as similar-appearing lesions on the right chest wall on a background of normal-appearing skin. Concurrent skin biopsies from the right chest wall, clavicular area, and upper right back were performed (Figure, B and C).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient’s history of radiation therapy and the presence of violaceous erythema within the radiation field suggested radiation dermatitis. However, the presence of firm, pebblelike papules on the right chest wall on a background of normal-appearing skin, as well as the histopathologic findings of atypical endothelial cells with papillary projections and lymphatic spaces, supported a diagnosis of radiation-induced angiosarcoma. The patient’s history of lymphedema and the presence of lesions on the right chest wall also raised the possibility of lymphedema-associated angiosarcoma. The patient’s history of salivary duct carcinoma and the presence of atypical cells with papillary projections raised the possibility of cutaneous metastases. However, the histopathologic findings were not consistent with salivary duct carcinoma. The patient’s history of radiation therapy and the presence of violaceous erythema within the radiation field also raised the possibility of radiation-induced lymphangiosarcoma. The patient’s history of radiation therapy and the presence of atypical endothelial cells with papillary projections also raised the possibility of Kaposi sarcoma. The patient’s history of salivary duct carcinoma and the presence of atypical cells with papillary projections raised the possibility of lymphomatoid granulomatosis. The patient’s history of radiation therapy and the presence of violaceous erythema within the radiation field also raised the possibility of cutaneous lymphoma. The patient’s history of radiation therapy and the presence of violaceous erythema within the radiation field also raised the possibility of cutaneous vasculitis. The patient’s history of salivary duct carcinoma and the presence of atypical cells with papillary projections raised the possibility of sarcoidosis. However, the histopathologic findings were not consistent with sarcoidosis.
1. Radiation-induced angiosarcoma is a rare complication of radiation therapy.
2. The diagnosis of radiation-induced angiosarcoma requires a high index of suspicion, especially in patients with a history of radiation therapy.
3. The histopathologic findings of atypical endothelial cells with papillary projections and lymphatic spaces support a diagnosis of radiation-induced angiosarcoma.

4. The differential diagnosis of radiation-induced angiosarcoma includes lymphedema-associated angiosarcoma, cutaneous metastases, radiation dermatitis, Kaposi sarcoma, lymphomatoid granulomatosis, cutaneous lymphoma, cutaneous vasculitis, and sarcoidosis.

A man in his 30s with a medical history of asthma, social history of smoking, and allergy to shellfish presented to the emergency department with tongue swelling. The patient reported a history of a local burn from hot food but denied any history of trauma, foreign body, or piercing. He was evaluated, given a presumptive diagnosis of sialadenitis, and discharged home with ibuprofen and clindamycin. He returned several days later with worsening tongue swelling, voice change, and subjective fever. Postcontrast axial computed tomography (CT) demonstrated a midline lesion within the oral tongue that was predominantly hypodense and demonstrated rim enhancement. No calcifications were seen within the lesion (Figure, A). The lesion was predominantly isointense to muscle on axial T1-weighted images without intravenous (IV) contrast (Figure, B). Axial T2-weighted images with fat saturation showed predominantly hyperintense signal relative to muscle as well as punctate internal foci of T2 hypointensity (not shown). The lesion was hyperintense on diffusion-weighted imaging (Figure, C) and hypointense on the apparent diffusion coefficient map (not shown). Sagittal T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with IV contrast and fat suppression demonstrated signal hypointense to muscle centrally with peripheral enhancement (Figure, D).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a history of tongue swelling and a CT scan that showed a midline lesion within the oral tongue. The lesion was hypodense on CT and demonstrated rim enhancement. The MRI showed a lesion that was isointense to muscle on T1-weighted images, hyperintense on T2-weighted images, and demonstrated peripheral enhancement. The lesion was hyperintense on diffusion-weighted imaging and hypointense on the apparent diffusion coefficient map. The differential diagnosis was broad and included epidermoid cyst, dermoid cyst, lymphangioma, hemangioma, tongue abscess, sialadenitis, lymphoma, granuloma, mucocele, and tongue cancer. The patient underwent surgical excision of the lesion, and the final pathologic diagnosis was an epidermoid cyst. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged home. The patient was seen in follow-up and was doing well with no evidence of recurrence.

A previously healthy 18-year-old college student presented to the emergency department with a 6-month history of fatigue, dry cough, dyspnea, and unintentional weight loss of 18 kg (from 100 to 82 kg). Four months ago, he was treated for presumed pneumonia with azithromycin without improvement. He did not smoke, drink alcohol, or use intravenous drugs. He was born in the United States and had not traveled outside of the country. He took no medications. On examination, his temperature was 37°C, heart rate 110/min, blood pressure 123/72 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 20/min. He had a palpable 2×2-cm firm, nontender, right supraclavicular lymph node and decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion in the right lower lung field. No hepatosplenomegaly or leg edema was noted. Routine laboratory tests, including complete blood cell counts, renal function, electrolytes, and hepatic function, were within normal limits. A chest x-ray demonstrated diffuse homogeneous opacification of the right lung field. Computed tomography scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed a 15 × 11-cm centrally necrotic mass in the right anterior mediastinum displacing the trachea to the left, a large right pleural effusion, and compression of the superior vena cava (Figure 1).
Reranked differential diagnoses using all patient information and test results:

The patient presented with a large mediastinal mass, pleural effusion, and lymphadenopathy. The differential diagnosis was broad, but the patient’s age, sex, and the location of the mass in the anterior mediastinum suggested lymphoma as the most likely diagnosis. The patient underwent a mediastinal biopsy, which revealed a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The patient was treated with chemotherapy and achieved complete remission. The patient’s symptoms and radiographic findings were consistent with lymphoma, which was confirmed by biopsy. The patient’s age and sex made lymphoma a more likely diagnosis than thymoma or metastatic germ cell tumor. Tuberculosis and sarcoidosis were also considered, but the patient’s lack of constitutional symptoms, normal laboratory results, and the presence of a large mediastinal mass made these diagnoses less likely. Lymphangitic carcinomatosis was also considered, but the patient’s age and the location of the mass made this diagnosis less likely. Mediastinal abscess was considered, but the patient’s lack of fever and the presence of a large mass made this diagnosis less likely. Pulmonary embolism was considered, but the patient’s symptoms and radiographic findings were not consistent with this diagnosis. Pneumonia was considered, but the patient’s lack of fever and the presence of a large mediastinal mass made this diagnosis less likely. Pleural effusion was a symptom of the patient’s underlying disease rather than a diagnosis.
